review.author: Cara M.
review.description: If you don't have an "in," don't come here. You will be chased away by the guard. If you are part of the "inside" the guard is an incredible gentlemen, dressed in an impeccably tailored suit, hat, who is very mysteriously wise. This is the place that inspired Harry Potter movie scenes and Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland. I visited a professor or "fellow" and was given an exclusive tour. What an incredible place. I left feeling very stupid, uneducated and American. The professors at Oxford are brilliant, leagues beyond Harvard, Yale, or any American University. It opened my eyes to modern human intellectual greatness.

review.author: R B.
review.description: It was very straightforward to visit and tour the grounds.  There was a nominal admission, and it was a fantastic experience.   We enjoyed seeing scenery inspirational to good literature as well as appreciating the historical significance.

review.author: GT W.
review.description: Reviewing as a tourist, not a student. The chapel here is stunningly beautiful. It's worth stopping in while exploring Oxford for that alone. No admission fee for this college as a tourist, so spend the 10 minutes or so exploring the grounds of this historic college.

review.author: Joe T.
review.description: Beautiful stain glass.  After awhile it is hard to remember which college is which.  For me, the distinctive chapels are a great memory of the different colleges.  Exeter College, the most I remember is the stain glass.

review.author: Qype User (Sharki…)
review.description:
Exeter is Oxford's fourth oldest college. It been around since 1314.
Its founder, Walter de Stapeldon was from Devon and was Bishop of Exeter and Treasurer of England under Edward II. He founded the College to provide an educated clergy for his diocese. During its first centuries, Exeter drew its members mainly from Devon and Cornwall.
A relatively small college in comparison to many others in Oxford.
Famous Alumni:
Sir Charles Lyell, the pioneering geologist.
J. A. Froude, the historian.
Two of the leading pre-Raphaelites, William Morris and Edward Burne-Jones. Important works by Morris and Burne-Jones are on view in the Morris Room and Chapel.
More recently:
J.R.R. Tolkien was an undergraduate.
The author of 'His Dark Materials Trilogy', Philip Pullman, another Exonian, based Jordan College on Exeter (Film release as 'The Golden Compass').
Inspector Morse collapsed on the lawn in the front quad!


 What 90% of visitors completely miss is up on the roof of the college. But you will have to stand in the middle of Broad Street to spot it:
A seven foot tall figure of a man cast in iron by internationally renowned artist Antony Gormley, will be straring back at you.
'Antony Gormley said that he hoped that the work would act as a point of reference in a city where scholarship and quotidian life intermingle. He said that the casual passer-by might ask What is that naked iron bloke doing up there? but might also be made to think of other relations with time and distance, with other destinies and destinations other than the immediate.' - So think on :-)


 Open to the public daily from 14:00 - 17:00. Entrance: Free
Tel: 01865 279600

review.author: Qype User (mood…)
review.description: One of three colleges on Turl Street, Exeter is very similar in appearance to many of the colleges in Oxford. It is only really worth a special trip if you're trying to see them all, though if you're passing by it's worth a look. There is an entrance to the college on Broad Street, but this is not accessible to the public.

review.author: Qype User (joekri…)
review.description: Amazing looking college - the chapel\nIs especially grandiose; look out for the 14th century tower opposite it, which is one of the oldest university buildings in any college

review.author: Ellen H.
review.description:
This place is awesome. They do market research studies and it's a great way to try out new products and made cash while doing it!
You sign up to participate in surveys online and then receive notifications of available studies.
Complete the survey and if you qualify, you get invited for a research study. Once there, you answer questions and try a wide variety of products such as toothpaste, cereal, coffee, etc. 
The staff is really friendly and you can take up to 4 surverys per quarter.

name: The Wharf Uncorked Food and Wine Festival

review.author: Roger B.
review.description: The third annual Wharf Uncorked Food & Wine Festival pretty well describes what you get.  Friday night is the wine pairing dinners.  This year there were six participating restaurants.  We had our dinner at Villaggio Grille who had teamed with Wagner Family Wines (Caymus).  Dinner was simply great.  Saturday afternoon is the wine and food tastings.  You give the ladies at entrance table your ticket (or show them your ticket on your phone) and you get a wrist band and a wine glass in return.  Then you head to the Rouse's tent where you get one of those plastic plates with a slot for your wine glass so you have a free hand to eat with.  Then you pile some of Rouse's food on your plate.  From there, you go from tent to tent, sampling food, wine, and some spirits.  One tent was dedicated to cooking demos from renowned chefs.  I won one of the items at the silent auction benefiting the Make A Wish foundation.  Happy about that.  There were several TVs set up so people won't miss the 'bama football game.  We had a good time and will probably try to come back next year.

name: Kumon Math and Reading Center of Auburn - Opelika

review.author: Reviewer P.
review.description: I visited Auburn High School for the first time this weekend, and the campus was clearly a coalescing of 21st century education. The building was brand-new, and the cleanliness of the building matched its newness. The hallways were long and wide to hold the presumably large student body. My only complaint would be the glass walls that separate the classroom from the hallways, as it could be a safety concern. Overall, Auburn High School definitely resonates as the future of education.

review.author: Courtney D.
review.description: There is a reason that Auburn City Schools consistently have some of the highest test scores in the state- the educators they hire are exemplary and truly have a passion for the children they work with. Year after year I am increasingly more impressed with the experiences our children have in this school system. As a former educator, I recognize the dedication and discipline these teachers and administrators exhibit. This is truly an amazing school system!

review.author: Django B.
review.description: Very poorly managed.  I mean the middle school principle is a criminal .  Went here for six years and and the only good people who were working there left after a while.  Go figure. Never let your kid attend this school system.  If I never had to step foot in Drake Middle School again it would be too soon.  They have a 0 tolerance bullying policy but when someone is actually bullied the teachers could care less.  They want to just be friends with kids who have money.

review.author: Teresa K.
review.description: Always awesome massages! Student or staff, I love this place for massage. You can go in in a ball of knots and come back out in a puddle of loose muscles.

review.author: Holly S.
review.description: Taylor is a expert at what she does! I get immediate relief after seeing her for a deep tissue massage and cupping. Every three weeks I let her do her magic and I'm addicted! Taylor is the best around!

review.author: Suzanne W.
review.description: I received a gift certificate to Better Bodies, which I was unable to use until 15 months later (3 months following expiration). However, I called to make the appointment before the GC expired, and was told that they would honor it anyway. A week before my appointment, I called to double check since I didn't want to be surprised by a higher price, and spoke to a different person who refused to honor the GC. I cancelled my appointment at that time. To my dismay, the day of my appointment, the sweet massage therapist called asking where I was since the woman on the phone had not actually cancelled my appointment. In the end, they lost money since they could have filled the empty schedule spot, and I lost a great massage. Incredibly disappointed with the customer service at what I heard was a place with the best massages in town.

review.author: Katie O.
review.description: Taylor did my massage and I absolutely loved it! The center is an older historic house in down town Opelika. It gives it a homey and intimate feel. Definitely going back!

review.author: Samson B.
review.description: Very rude staff, didn't say anything on how to detail the drawing I made, and were on their phones for most of the time! No wonder not many people reviewed this place. It is trashy and I'm never coming back!

review.author: Regina D.
review.description: I have painted here several times and I love it! It's so much fun plus you actually make a painting that you'll

review.author: Denise H.
review.description: Went there with my son & a large group of elementary aged kids from a summer camp. Was really impressed with how organized and prepared they were to handle the group and help them paint. Was a super fun experience and my son really loved it. Simple instructions and cute. Would definitely recommend and come again.

review.author: Sandy F.
review.description: This was the most comprehensive CPR class I've ever taken. I loved the fact that you can do it at your own pace,  at the comfort of your own home or wherever there's internet access. I felt very prepared the day of the practical test, which was very fast and easy to do! I highly recommend this method of learning to acquire those necessary life saving skills.

review.author: Robert J.
review.description: Emerald Cove is a very caring place with a warm and friendly environment. Upon entering the center you'll know you're at the right place when it comes to all the things you're looking for in a child care program. Learning is an essential part of each child's day and the opportunity to enjoy reading before kindergarten is a plus. Good positive character skills are just as important within the core of learning which when developed promotes healthy relationships and Emerald Cove believes in the "power" of caring for others. Emerald Cove offers a core curriculum designed to offer each child the opportunity to grow and develop while harnessing their inner potential.

name: Little Sunshine's Playhouse and Preschool of Ozark

review.author: Debra B.
review.description: I had wrote a review a few years ago on this daycare. Since my review they have changed management and have made so many changes for the better.  I love that they listened.  I am not sure how to delete my first review experience.  I want to say that this is a great place and would recommend them to take care of your little one.

review.author: Megan S.
review.description: My daughter loves this school!! And so do I  10/10 I don't know how much I have to write for a yelp review! But all the teachers are amazing! I am\nVery thankful I found this school. My daughter has learned so much in the time she has been going there.

review.author: Brandon B.
review.description: If you want to learn about the Austrian School of Economics then look no further. This Mises Institute has a rich history and is a place full of immense knowledge. Their many libraries contain books on everything related to politics, philosophy, history, and economic science. The staff is very friendly and the faculty is incredibly knowledgeable. In addition, the book store has an incredible selection of books that you can purchase, many of which are unique hardcover copies , all at a very reasonable price. The Mises Institute is incredibly intellectually stimulating and a must for anyone interested in free minds and free markets.

review.author: Nyron V.
review.description:
You wanna learn about economics and stop being a lazy ass you need to listen to Von Mises. They affiliated with great philosophizers like Raul Paul who run for prez and Israel Kirschner and Garret North. I started to read about Australian economics in a correctional facility and learned all about how the system works and how the government prints and prints money and devalue what in your wallet, but we gonna send a brotha to the pen for ten for stealing a wallet? Sheeit! I got to hear a lecture here a number of years ago and though I didn't get all the lingo, I damn well got the flow. I was inspired to talk to brothas and sistahs about melting down they gold chains and they teeth grills as a hedge against Bernuky's printing of dough. This is a flow I wrote in honor of Von Mises. Dig it:
       Speakin' truth to power, from Vienna to Valhalla,
       Keeping it real, from Zoroaster to Allah, 
       A bicycle,
       A trycicle
       Can't beat the business cycle.
       Inflation: The end of the nation.
       Stagflation: Anticipation.
       Capitalism, the savior of the nation.
       Keynsianism: the ruination of the nation.
       Quantitative Easing: A total illusion.
       Big Government, leads to doom.
       Gold: The solution of the resolution.
       Free markets: the only solution.

Peace. Love. Free markets.

review.author: Walter B.
review.description: I am a big fan of the Mises Institute. It constitutes the world's leading scholarly enterprise dedicated to studying Austrian economics, the economics of Menger, Bohm Bawerk, Hayek, Mises and Rothbard. They offer for free an electronic library, free access, that will knock your socks off.

review.author: Kim S.
review.description: It's so nice to have a quilt shop nearby. Everybody is kind and helpful. If you're looking for item they don't carry,  Debbie may order it for you!

review.author: Marissa G.
review.description: Amazing place!! Very high quality! Can't recommend enough if you're looking to start diving. The staff is incredible and everyone is so nice and willing to go above and beyond to make sure you succeed and enjoy the sport. Super helpful and friendly and very professional. Loved my experience!

review.author: Alan C.
review.description: I can only speak to this place around the swimming lessons they offer for kids. They seem to be very patient but effective in teaching the little ones to swim. Each week there seems to be improvemnet. The facilties are setup perfectly for children. They have bleachers for the parents while they wait. Overall, it has been a great experience.

review.author: Kirby M.
review.description: Coming from much larger city like St. Louis this dive shop in Springfield is nothing short of amazing.  The dive shop itself has a huge show room and they even have their own pool with a 14 foot deep end.  The staff  are very friendly and extremely knowledgeable.  I got a private four dive session with full gear rental for less than $300.  Andrew was my instructor and is just a flat out super cool guy.  So much so that I'm looking at going on one of their group dive trips mainly to dive with him again.  They even found a mask for my girlfriend who has been diving for years with mask issues.  I highly recommend them for people just getting into the sport or veterans alike.  Thanks again Andrew!!

review.author: Craig R.
review.description: Easily the nicest dive shop in the Springfield area. It is always very clean and the staff is always very friendly and professional. They offer swim classes for kids as well as scuba diving instructions.

review.author: Abby J.
review.description: Diventures has reached out to my mother and has made amends. My mother recently told me she has attended 5 classes and "loves it". Thank you for contacting her and being proactive so that she could have a good experience.

review.author: Shannon V.
review.description: If your looking for glitz and want to boast on how much money you spend on diving gear and courses, tbis is the place for ya.

review.author: Shane G.
review.description: Pretty good bathrooms... they always smell great. Give the bathroom guy a raise! So, definitely 10 out of 10 would recommend.

review.author: Beth R.
review.description: Being snowbirds, we are so happy to have found this Rec Center. The class offerings is so plentiful, something for everyone. Water aerobics, water palates & deep water running are my favorites. Bonnie is a fantastic instructor, a cross between a drill Sargent and teacher. She makes sure your form is correct, gives helpful hints and keeps things moving. Beth explains the reason for for the different components of her routine.  Wish I could take them back to Michigan!

review.author: Terry B.
review.description: Great staff very clean, love it! Hours are fine, equipment, pool always top notch!\nAlways sanitizer, restrooms and entire facility excellent. Unbelievable price for locals. Always friendly pro staff!

review.author: Traci J.
review.description: I would give them a zero but it's not an option!\n\nFirst off let me say this....I have been a member at many gyms over the years that have been excellent. Bodenhamer has a ways to go.....front desk staff is rude and smug and God forbid you ask them to look up your membership in the event your forgot your card. Try to call in and schedule anything and you will be sent to a voicemail or told to go to the website. Equipment is nice, however the machines are on top of each other. Pool is very nice, when it is actually open and available for open swim. Classes are full of old people and not a very big selection of classes for younger more active/fit individuals. This gym definitely caters to the older crowd as they offer senior discounts. They cater to tourists and locals who won't pay for a full membership as they let anybody in for $5...good luck playing basketball because the gym is full of a bunch of rowdy thugs who just come and pay $5 when they want to play some pickup ball with a bunch of buddies (who aren't members either). We paid for a year up front or I would have already cancelled....

review.author: Tammy H.
review.description: I am a local resident and I tried to get a new yearly membership today. Here's how that went: I wanted to do the family plan so my kids could have access to a gym and try to be healthier. I was told my 24 & 26 year old kids had to have their own membership because of their ages. I was told I couldn't do the couple plan with my 24 year old because she's still considered too young. So she's too old to be a kid, but she's too young to be the other half of my couple? What's wrong with these people? What happened to a family friendly environment that encourages healthier lifestyles? They need to be more specific and put the rules in the fine print on the website. What does it matter how old your family is as long as I'm paying the monthly fees for the family plan. What exactly do they consider family if you can't include your children in your family plan? Very disappointed. This place will never receive a penny of my money.

review.author: Nicole A.
review.description: Nice new Cybex equipment, great class lineup and indoor pool. Great place for the family!

review.author: Thomas C.
review.description: This facility is clean, well-equipped and extensive. I just signed up for a year's membership and was surprised at how affordable it is. I also have a YMCA membership in another town, so I have a good basis for comparison. As far as another reviewer's comments on staff, I have found them to be friendly and helpful.

review.author: MaryL B.
review.description: This place is great facility with many different memberships to meet the demands of the locals and tourists alike. I had a two month membership. I found the classes tailored to all abilities. My favorite class was yoga. Each instructor had something different to offer. This is a recreation department not a health club...bring your own yoga mat. If you plan to take a shower you will also need to bring a towel and hairdryer from home. The only improvement this facility could make is putting in more electrical sockets in the women's locker room. There is something for everyone to do here from young children to elderly.

review.author: Mike R.
review.description: This place is a joke. It would be embarrassed by any decent gym or YMCA. Overpriced with sub-par equipment. The staff have a bad attitude and rarely-if ever-give you a smile or decent service. They reflect the "it's the only thing around so take it or leave it" mentality. The only thing that saves this as a rec center is that it is the only game in town.

review.author: Jill W.
review.description: Wonderful facility for enjoying working out, swimming, tennis, jogging, racquet ball, etc.  Also has a variety of water aerobic classes, yoga classes , pilate classes, kickboxing classes, etc.  Friendly staff and instructors.  All classes are included in the price of membership.  Great value!

review.author: Angela R.
review.description: My first helicopter ride today and it was well worth it. Great flight and great experience. Definitely would recommend Lost Bay Helicopters!

review.author: Nikita S.
review.description: Had amazing time with pilot Mike and much appreciated meeting with Rachel, business owner, highly recommend checking them out if you are in town for a weekend, totally worth the price!

review.author: Justin E.
review.description: Most of these guys are ex military and I always try to support vets and vet businesses and this business is the exact reason why. They run it the way a business should be with great precision and outstanding customer service with Rachael keeping everything and everyone in order.\nGreat experience and I highly recommend them!

review.author: Shelby G.
review.description: My daughters been dying to fly so when I seen their ad pop up on fb while we were on vacation I jumped on it. I wish I hadn't the pilot didn't say a word to us when we got in which made it kind of awkward in my opinion. My 7 year old daughter sat in the front with him she was so excited it was her first time flying and it was a surprise birthday present for her. I've went on a helicopter ride down here a few years ago and it was great the guy talked to us the whole time asked where we were staying so we could fly by and wave I'll be taking her there if we ever want to go again. When we got done she was like why didn't he say hi how are you or bye have a nice day i hope you enjoyed it when we got out that was awkward. i asked which way we were going and he told me left down the beach and across state park and thats the only thing he ever said. The lady that walks you to the helicopter was super nice and friendly.  Luckily my daughter still enjoyed it and it wasn't a total bust for her.

review.author: Katherine L.
review.description: I can't believe that I'm the first to review.  For about a hundie, the two of you can have the most incredible tourist thing.  The pilot (is adorable) is knowledgeable, gives competent instructions without terrifying you, then lifts you off of the tarmac before you can start to panic about being hoisted 500 feet off terra firma in a glass bubble glued to a beer can.  The panic lasts only a couple seconds, then ... OMG.  Just.  Wow.  It's a short trip around the Gulf Shores city, beach and state park.  The pilot loves his little neck of the woods and ADORES his machine.  He is happy to share info and explain intricacies of his aircraft.  And ...  drumroll .... you get to wear those cool headphones with microphones attached.  Do this tourist thing.  Its fun to go hang around the airport, too.  \n\nAFTERTHOUGHT:  It is not, in fact, a beer can.  It's an amazing, well-kept, well-loved flying machine.  I did not mean to make it sound otherwise.

review.author: Kathleen A.
review.description:
CSU offers a variety of degrees and truly provides support all along the way. I was fortunate enough to get my MS in Occupational Healy & Safety from this wonderful inst. All classes were online and any time I had a question, there was someone on the other end of the phone to help walk me through things. Shout out to my former advisor Luke who always took time to answer my questions. 

 Not only does the curriculum and advising get five stars but so does graduation! It's a pretty awesome event where students from all over the world come together to celebrate.

Additionally, with respect to Safety degrees and careers, this school always represents at conferences and conventions in the industry. I know I can stop by their exhibitor booth and say hi. Everyone is friendly and helpful and they always put together great networking events to help current students and alumni meet other people in the field. Paul and Ernie- you are both awesome to say hello to during NSC and ASSP conferences.

How could I almost forget about graduation?!? People from all over the world coming together to celebrate. The staff put on an amazing event and I met some people that I am still friends with! Definitely a must when you finish your degree. Make the weekend into a fun beach vacation to celebrate.

If you are on the fence in deciding whether or not to further your education at CSU, I can tell you that my experience was amazing and I will go back when I am ready to get another degree!

review.author: Youknow M.
review.description: Hi everybody! In my forties I thought it was too late to go back, I was so wrong, and glad that I did.  Online schooling is a challenge as one needs to think outside the box and sometimes be a mind reader of what their professors might be looking for.  I recieved both my BS and MBA at Columbia Southern University and learned confidence in areas and schools of thought that I did not have before.  The courses will challenge you and the college is at a great price.  And before any of you go running away at the challenge, remember that the challenge is what you learn from and need to overcome.  In many of the programs you will learn more than your education, and will find a staff that has your success in mind.  The extra things I learned were patience, professionalism, and the courage to seek clarity like a pro and within academic policies and chains of command.  They are flexible and even had life flexible terms that you can choose from.  Although only a nationally accredited institution and a member of the Distance Education and Training Council, they are as of 2022 under review for being regionally accredited. \n They also have an alumni association that students can be recommended to.  Check them out.  Good luck to all of you on your degree pursuits, and good luck to CSU on becoming regionally accredited.  ~Sincerely, a CSU Knight Ambassador.

review.author: Donna S.
review.description: Great experience with this school. Consistently well-structured courses and support.

review.author: Dru T.
review.description:
Affordable tuition, excellent teachers and staff, very willing to work with your schedule to help you succeed.  MILITARY FRIENDLY to the max.  I really hope they get Regional Accreditation soon so their credits will transfer and be recognized at a higher level.  They are currently Nationally Accredited by the DEAC, the same accreditation as the "free" college, University of the People.  I put quotes around free because at UoP, the online courses are free but the final exams are $100 to take and receive credit for the course. 

From what I was told by my advisor at CSU, they are working diligently towards a Regional Accreditation sometime in the near future.

Once that is achieved I will highly recommend this school. In the meantime, I can definitely say I like their platform and I like where they are going!

review.author: Blanca G.
review.description: My only regret is not looking into this doctoral program before I signed up for it. No real guidance and while interviewed I should of listened to the negativity. My counselor didn't bother to guide me as the school  instructed and truly went into deaf ears. My Masters Degree was awesome with Richard Beatty as my counselor. Just be very careful this school uses tokenism lots and lie. Don't care about the student and if your not a match they play one as stupid. I even had a professor say ,"Your in the wrong class, go back to junior college." Well I am in the University. I was humilated, disrespected and harrassed. Now I found a better place. BECAREFUL HERE.

review.author: Michelle B.
review.description: Fellow alumni from this college. Man oh man if you think online college is easy boy you are so wrong! This school had me working my butt off blood sweat and tears but in the end I get to see that pretty degree plaque on my wall. Totally worth it.

review.author: Megan H.
review.description: I am currently attending CSU and I must say I absolutely love this school. I never like doing essay's and research papers but now I am excellent at them. They professors are great and the amount of time given to complete assignments is great also. I have recommended this school to a few people already, and plan to return to achieve my Masters.

review.author: Todd C.
review.description: They now have the GSP.  A little late for me but new BS grads will get to skip the ASP \n\nhttps://www.columbiasouthern.edu/blog/october-2017/columbia-southern-university-program-recognized-by

review.author: Gil B.
review.description: Not a bad school, my issue is the national accreditation.  Hard to transfer credits from this school, but not impossible.  Overall pleased.

review.author: Tuan N.
review.description: I loved this school and really think it's the most affordable online degree program. Yes it requires a lot of writing and extensive research on most assignments but most of the instructors are lenient and understanding. They will work with you if you really want to achieve a good grade.  In my opinion it's a great school to earn your degree and it's very doable with my busy full time job. Highly recommend!

review.author: Brian S.
review.description: No stars. This place is terrible please don't enroll here. So I was enrolled in the fire science program and had to take time off came back to finish my degree and they changed it to fire administration and had to take one more class than needed before. Unfortunately I was unable to get back into the program and finish. I start up again take a class and unfortunately personal issues come up again. Try again to finish and sign up a week ago, I needed to be "reevaluated" and even though nothing changed and I was still going for the same degree they screwed me over and instead of 24 credit to graduate now I need 30 and they are not even for anything good just a math and humanities class. Really?? And no one has helped me just basically said that's the way it is. Hate this place no help and I wasted so much time effort and money on this scamming bunch of people saying they are for education. Hope they go out of business because they only care about your money. Go somewhere else because no matter what you want to do there is another college that will be much better.

review.author: Mark M.
review.description: I am enrolled in the MS Occupational Health and Safety.  Seems like they are trying to teach you the proper way to write an APA research paper rather than to make sure that you are learning the subject matter. English prof and engineering prof whom I dealt with have zero people skills and seem to want the student to feel small and inferior to them. I will eventually finish my degree, but there has to be a university that treats their students better. I'm in my late 50s and I will never need the skill of properly writing an APA research paper.

review.author: Connie S.
review.description: Great university.  From a former student, my advise is that you do not get student loans.  Pay as you go and finish with NO DEBT.  For a very source of information Google "Dave Ramsey" and learn how to manage your money, how to avoid debt and pay off what you currently owe.  A university degree is personally meaningful, but make it a personal goal - not necessarily a career goal.

review.author: steve m.
review.description: Great school with good people. Attended my wife's graduation this week and CSU showed us s great time. Go Knights!

review.author: John B.
review.description: Graduated with a Master's degree in Human Resource Management. It was cost efficient, the classes were great. Received credit for prior graduate coursework. It's an accredited college with the Department of Education. I'm glad I chose CSU as my graduate school. Go Knights!!

review.author: Mitchell J.
review.description: Taking online classes, most of the teachers are great resources. Word of warning, keep in contact with your advisor and student services rep. They are helpful if you do run in to problems with professors or course work.

review.author: Sara S.
review.description: For the most part I don't have a problem with the home office staff. But some of the professors need to work on their people skills.

review.author: James C.
review.description: I received my bachelor's degree from here.  I think High School had a harder curriculum.  The chewbacca defense works when submitting essays to about 90% of the staff here.  If you want an easily attainable nationally accredited degree without having to exert basically any effort then this is your place.  Its pretty expensive too, but I don't mind.  The American Taxpayer paid my tuition!

review.author: Caren O.
review.description: Great online university! Flexible hours and exceptional student services!

review.author: Shaun F.
review.description: Columbia Southern University is an excellent university. I have to disagree with the person who said that this college is as easy as or easier than high school. Yes, most of the work you submit is essays; however, that is the challenging part.  The coursework is very rigorous. I have attended both a b&m college as well as CSU, so I can attest that this college is definitely harder. You can't plagiarize essays because they use Turn It In for many of the classes and major points are deducted if the redundancy rate is too high. I have had this happen, even when none of my material was plagiarized. So, I had to learn to use more of my own words and and not quote so much material. If you can easily write essays, you might consider this university easy. However, if you struggle with writing and thoughts don't come as easily to you, like me, then you might have a different view of this school. In one class alone, I had to write 18 essays. It would be much easier to have multiple choice, like I did in high school or like I did when I went to my b&m college.  However, I will say that I have retained more information through my coursework at CSU than I have at any other school. I retain more information when I have to write than when I have to just memorize information for a short term. There is no extra credit or making up assignments. If you don't do the work, you will not get a good grade. I would recommend this university to any working adult who does not have time to go to college the traditional way. If you enjoy independent learning and don't have to be in a classroom,  you will like CSU.  I am a senior at CSU, graduating this year. I do not feel like my degree is being handed to me; I have worked hard for the degree that I will receive. This journey has been more time consuming and stressful than I could have ever imagined, but well worth it!

review.author: Ginette P.
review.description:
Initially I had no interest in visiting the university but since it was part of our tour it ended up not being a bad choice. 
The university is rich in history the grounds are beautifully kept one building is nicer than the other great architecture.
Part of it's history seems to come from the fact that it is the oldest English university to date with some of the earliest records of teaching going back to the 1090's. 
Something interesting we came to find out was that the university was used as a filming location for the Harry Potter movies, pretty cool to see if you are fan. 
Seems like this location is pretty popular for filming as we were on tour there were film crews there, don't recall what show it was.
Overall its a beautiful area with plenty of space to roam around in if part of your tour it's nice to check it out.

review.author: Bradley N.
review.description:
What would William Carlos W. Yelp?

"the yellow walls"
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/uncS0tQ7W-r8v9194a5faw?select=eu4zU-AE3ZbjpTQB3QCdkw

so much depends
upon 
pale yellow 
walls
wet with 
rain
beneath a lead
sky.

review.author: Mia S.
review.description: While I attended school, I saw them filming parts of The Golden Compass. This school is filled with so much history, and the buildings have a golden hue when it's sunny. The different colleges have great character, except my dorm room looked like it was the same since the 14th C when it was first built. My friends room was nice and modern, I guess I lucked out. The dining common food was okay, it definitely lacked taste on some nights, but it may be because I ordered vegetarian meals every night. Most of the dining halls are harry potter-esque, seeing as how it was filmed in the vicinity. \n\nLove this place, love the countryside, I would live in the UK if I could.

review.author: David F.
review.description: Blackcurrant and soda was mediocre. Very overpriced too at 0.23gbp. Got a free dessert but it tasted like coffee which I don't like.

review.author: Qype User (koschk…)
review.description: St. Catz, as it is known by students, is one of the larger colleges and a little further away from the grand, old buildings in the centre, both in terms of distance and in terms of style. But it is worth making the 15 minute trek from High Street, as the college was designed and built in the 1960s by the prominent Danish designer and architect Arne Jacobsen. While it is, unfortunately, not possible to admire the interior features, all of which were also the work of Jacobsen, if you are not a student, the college is a so called open college, meaning that there is 24 hour access to the quad (rather unusually for Oxford, this is a round piece of grass). From here, you can explore the amazing architecture and interesting gardens. Do avoid the new blocks, however, as these are a bit of an eye-sore despite the claim that their design was based on that of Jacobsen.

review.author: Miranda B.
review.description: We stayed for a week doing a summer program in the continuing education program.  Highlights were being in this incredible school and town, and particularly dining in the great hall each night.  The "dorm" facilities are what you'd expect from a very old, historic place ... so-so.  We were in the "penthouse" up 65 stairs, with 2 twin beds, no AC (usually not needed), and a tiny private bathroom (many floors have shared  baths).  I'm glad I had the experience but probably won't repeat for a decade or so.  The program is only in the summer (it's called "the Oxford Experience") and the town is jam packed.  But on campus in the evenings it's peaceful and beautiful and Evensong in the cathedral and croquet in the Master's garden is wonderful.

review.author: Qype User (mood…)
review.description: St Catherine College, or St Catz as it's referred to is one of the more interesting colleges; simply due to the fact that it's architecture is quite distinct from the rest of the University. Built in the 70s, the design is modern (for that era). Although it is worth a visit if you are in the area, it has less of a traditional feel as compared to the rest of the university colleges.

review.author: Qype User (Flic…)
review.description:
The Bridge of Sighs brings many tourists. Legend says that it's so named because students have to cross it in order to sit their exams; whether or not this is true is questionable - perhaps in the dim and distant past. Nowadays it's more likely to be rapturous sighs of admiration from clusters of tourists. The bridge has seen several traverses from keen climbers - the hardest method being the hand traverse. This is, of course, stricly against college regulations and CCTV cameras are now in place to prevent such mischief.


 Hertford itself has a reputation for being welcoming, egalitarian and down-to-earth, but still has typical Oxford architecture, a whopping great library and a lovely big dining hall. The dining hall is in a light-coloured wood and very well-lit, so it feels very welcoming whilst still retaining its grandness.


 Hertford's proximity to the Bodleian library makes it an excellent place to pop into for a view of a typical college whilst on the tourist trail.

review.author: Qype User (mood…)
review.description: Hertford college is located close to Radcliffe Square and is most famous for it's Bridge of Sighs, modelled on a similar bridge in Venice. To be honest, the interior of the college is very similar to many of the other Oxford colleges, but make sure you get some snaps of the bridge! The Sheldonian theatre, Old Bodleian and Radcliffe Camera are very close by.

name: Faulkner State Community College Gulf Coast Campus

address.streetAddress: Broad Street\nen plein centre de l'université

review.author: Mike C.
review.description: Wonderful history college...the beautiful old building cares lots of good memories...

review.author: M L.
review.description:
What can you do with £1.50? Down payment on a G&B almond chocolate bar? Deposit on an M&S sandwich?


 Or, give it to the pleasant fellow in the little cubicle at the entrance to Trinity College, Oxford and take yourself on a mini tour round the grounds, popping into the chapel and the dining room en route.


 Not a round the world trip this, but cheaper than paying the tuition fees.


 Really nice to see the imposing quadrangles and the old buildings steeped in learned history. Fun dodging the serious students scurrying to their tutorials and it's relaxing to gaze at the ornate ceiling of the ancient chapel.


 Make yourself at home in the Harry Potteresque dining room with the long bench tables, wood panelling and fusty straight laced portraits frowning at the young students' indiscretions.


 See if you can spot the shadow of Charles Dance and wonder if this is where the inspiration for the TV series began. Spicy.


 The gardens are spacious and very pleasant.


 Recommended.

review.author: Qype User (Flic…)
review.description:
Trinity is one of the quintessential Oxford colleges. Not quite as grand as Christchurch or Magdalen, it is perhaps in a slightly more central location and is right near where some of the walking tours of Oxford start. The great thing about Trinity is that it's surrounded by iron railings, so you can see into it without having to pay.


 Despite being near the centre of town, it's got a surprising amount of open space in it, with several large quads, the standard beautiful Oxford gardens and even a patch of woodland, which makes a refreshing change from the very obviously cultivated grass.


 The chapel is reputedly the first neoclassical one of its kind, partly designed by Christopher Wren (who also designed St. Paul's Cathedral). The West tower shows the college's age. The statues on top represent astronomy, theology, medicine and geometry - perhaps the main subjects when the college was founded.


 The buildings are old and grand. If you get a chance to look round, the dining hall is very pretty, with portraits and old wooden benches and tables. The college also has a squash court hidden away near the dining hall. Access is annoying because of the electronic gate system, but the porters are very friendly. There are two porters' windows: as far as I can tell, one is for students and the other for visitors, but I get it wrong every time!

review.author: LaSha G.
review.description: I learned a lot during my summer study abroad experience, but the thing that's sticks out the most in my mind, is the fact that I learned that Oxford, is not just one big university, as one might think of it in the states.  It's actually a series of 39 smaller colleges, each with their own separate campuses and facilities and educational specialties -- one of those colleges being named St. Johns.  But let's be honest here, you don't really want to tell new acquaintances and potential employers that you studied at St. John's College for the summer, you want the reaction you get from telling them you studied at Oxford.  And therefore, the misconception continues...\n\nI had a great time studying here, although I won't comment too much on the curriculum or teachers, since I was a part of specialized summer program.  However, the grounds were well kept and immaculate.  The architecture was historic and gorgeous...and the dorm rooms were crazy big.  At least mine was...I had so much damn space in that room, it was like I had a studio apartment all to myself.  There's a pub on campus, that's pretty spacious and well stocked, and there's a few kebab vans on the street near campus that serve late night greasy stuff, including the very popular cheesy chips (i.e.  fries).  1am food for drunkards....UK style.

review.author: Qype User (joekri…)
review.description: Staggering architecture, world-class teaching and a vibrant student body, located right in the middle of Oxford, within easy walking distance of attractions like the Ashmolean museum. An exceptional college in an exceptional university

review.author: GT W.
review.description: Reviewing as a tourist, not a student. The dining hall is the filming site for the Hogwarts dining hall in Harry Potter. We had friends at the college and were able to join them as guests for dinner service, which was surprisingly good and very efficiently served. The ambiance is extraordinary. There is also a tiny pub tucked away in front of the dining hall that serves a beer specifically made for Christ Church College. \n\nThe Tom Quad, their central grounds, is well kept and expansive - more open and palatial than the other colleges. There is a large tower here as a landmark, Tom Tower, a Christopher Wren work (the architect of St. Paul's in London). It's worth stopping in.

review.author: Arya K.
review.description: Beautiful place to visit. Highly recommend getting the audio recording so you know all the history.

review.author: Diane H.
review.description:
I think that just because Harry Potter was filmed here, made it worth visiting. Initially I though the great hall was filmed at the Uni of Oxford, but apparently from reading reviews, this is part of Uni of Oxford! I saw the "dining hall" it was magnificent...and the hallway where they filmed harry and ron talking to Professor M and the quidditch field or something of that sort. 

If you love HP, definitely visit...if you are a student, get that student discount!! Price is still high though..at 5.50 with student discount... reg is 7 pounds.. yikes...

hate the price, but love that i can see where HP was filmed!

review.author: Qype User (Flic…)
review.description:
Walking into Christ Church for the first time is an undeniably breathtaking moment. The first thing you see is a huge quad of impeccably trimmed grass surrounding a fountain, all bordered by grand buildings.


 Christ Church is one of the most famous Oxford colleges. Its alumni include thirteen British prime ministers and Einstein was a guest student. The impressive builings have been used in Harry Potter (the dining hall is where students eat daily), Brideshead Revisited and the Golden Compass, and it's easy to see why.


 It's the only college in the world which also counts as a cathedral, which is well worth visiting. Check out the quads, especially Tom Quad and Blue Boar quadrangle. It's best to visit when the hall and cathedral are open.


 Prices:


 Adults: £4.90
Family: £9.80
Concessions: £3.90
Under 5s: Free


 It's cheaper if the hall or cathedral are not open.
Price includes illustrated information guide.

review.author: Lee P.
review.description: Our group of forty from Arizona had a private tour of Christ Church and gardens! Our guides were so very knowledgeable and entertaining! References to the Harry Potter books and movies were abundant! The dining hall was quite impressive! Must of us got a chuckle out of the marble quotes wherein misspellings were simply adjusted by adding a letter as an afterthought... rather than ruining the entire marble slab to start over! So much history! We also delighted in the "silence" signage for testing taking place! Quite an amazing tour!

review.author: John H.
review.description: The visitor's self walking tour inside the college is quite short for 8#s, but I'm still glad I did it. Would love to dine in that hall one day. The architecture is just amazing if you're in to that.

review.author: Amy H.
review.description: Food at christ church is slightly below average compared to standards at other colleges. They only have good food on guest nights.

review.author: Qype User (kas7…)
review.description:
If you are a tourist or even a resident of oxford then this is one place you will want to visit. It is very beautiful - especially on a sunny day, and you will enjoy it. The buildings are grand and overly beautiful - and the grounds are well tended and lovely to wonder around.


 I would recommend bringing a picnic and having it in the ground if the weather permits it.


 Try and visit when the 'Harry Potter' hall is open - the kids will love seeing it. It is very big and grand, the students have breakfast there on sunday mornings.


 Remember to bring your camera!

review.author: Qype User (tim_ba…)
review.description:
Christ Church is an extremly popular College within Oxford University with 600 students. Christ Church Catherdral is also extremly well know as it sports world famous boy & girls choirs. The buildings as historic as they are, are a sight not to be missed.


 If you have a day in Oxford be sure to visit Christ Church. An small entrance fee may be charged to explore the College and its spectacular gardens. But it is worth every penny especially if you just want some chill out time or a lunch break... the scenary is beautiful.

review.author: mel s.
review.description: Good place to grab a tour. Find the Alice in Wonderland window in the Great Hall (go outside of dining hours). Instead of taking the tour, consider just attending the regular Cathedral service, which is as high church as you can find.

review.author: Honora M.
review.description: I actually got to stay here for a week as part of a summer school program for adults called the Oxford Experience. For about 1200 pounds, you get room, full board and tuition in a course of your choosing (you couldn't stay in Oxford for a week with all meals alone for that...). Courses range from King Arthur and Jane Austen to the Beatles and murder mysteries; you are sure to find something fascinating. But the real star is Christ Church (you don't say College, just Christ Church, and its nickname is "the House"). Buildings that date from many centuries back, that you actually live in for a week, and you take three meals a day in the dining hall up the staircase they used in the Harry Potter movies. Awesome. I was so disappointed that Dumbledore wasn't there presiding over the high table. But it was terrific. Such history. And the best part was being there after the college gates were shut and locked and you were on the inside. The place was yours to wander around...fantastic. But if you can't do the program for a week, at least visit for the day.

review.author: Qype User (damien…)
review.description: christ church is a amazing college and also has a lovely cathedral .\nthe college is in a prime location in oxford and a well recognised name in oxford.\nthis location is perfect for looking at the beautiful architecture and perfect for sight seeing for tourists.

review.author: Qype User (joekri…)
review.description: Another architecturally incredible Oxford college - its dining hall and grand staircase were used as sets for the Harry Potter films. It's easy to see why this remains one of Oxford's top tourist attractions.

review.author: Tiffany W.
review.description: I loved it here! I did a group tour and we walked around oxford university and learned a lot about this place. A lot of films were shot here like Harry Potter, Transformers, inspector Morse, The Golden Compass, & lots more. \n\nThis place has gotten so touristy that you have to pay for everything (bathrooms, entrances, etc).

review.author: Marlon T.
review.description:
If you google "best universities in the world", Oxford is always near the top. Saying you're an Oxford man means something!

Anyway, I came to check out the university/town a part of a long day tour. It's a nice town with tons of history. You could easily spend a couple days here exploring the nooks/crannies and secrets of the city (Harry Potter filming locations, Albert Einstein's blackboard writing, etc.).

Maybe one day your child will be graduating from this amazing institution!

review.author: Norah S.
review.description: Got my masters in analytical literature. I wrote my dissertation on the effect of nuance on the discourse of minutiae. Great experience and loved to experience all of Oxford. Go Ox!

review.author: Kenisha D.
review.description: Oxford university sits in the nice town of Oxford. I easily walked the entire town. I took a walking tour and leaned about the history of the university and the different colleges. I also got to see fun locations where the Harry Potter movie was filmed.

review.author: Bee M.
review.description:
The hallowed grounds of the intellects.  This place is beautiful. The campus and surroundings around the area are serene but at the same time chaotic - I think it's because of all the tourist that go there.

The Radcliff Camera is incredible - I can definitely be spoiled studying in that hall.

I may want to come back when to spend some time just walking the grounds instead of being on a tour as I didn't get the chance to see The Great Hall and other landmarks due to time constraints.

review.author: Kevin W.
review.description:
Such a beautiful campus!

Oxford was the last leg of my tour from Evan Evans. 

The campus buildings are so pretty! The architecture was wonderful. You can get lost just walking around staring at all the buildings. 

There are a few Harry Potter sites here as well. The Great Hall is the big one.

Be careful of the cobble stone streets. Very easy to trip.

Ton of small pubs around to grab a pint.

Did not think I would enjoy walking around here as much as I did.

review.author: GT W.
review.description:
Reviewing as a tourist, not a student.

This is a phenomenal university to visit as a tourist. Many in the UK are not worth visiting, but Oxford really has a lot to offer non-students in the way of tours, access to campus grounds, libraries, chapels, museums, and more. There is enough here to warrant at least two full days of exploration. We went on the college grounds of about six or so different colleges, which comprise Oxford University. Each is unique with its own gardens, traditions, and quirks. For walking tours, we did Footprints Tours (an independent group). 

Many of the colleges charge a small admission fee to walk onto their quad (grounds) while others ban visitors altogether. It just depends. Since they are all clustered together, you can explore them easily at your leisure.

review.author: Dan Z.
review.description:
The Good: its Oxford!!!!

The Bad: you kidding? No bad here.

The Rest: Had a great time on a college visit with my daughter! Really enjoyed the close by tavern I will review separately. I was so
Impressed with the upkeep and history here.

review.author: Jason L.
review.description:
The history of Oxford is a bit over whelming. There were many famous government, playwrites, economists, and leaders that are alumni dating back to the 13th century. It is one of oldest English University made up of many sub colleges. This also a town that is possibly one of the most expensive areas to live. There is a big Oxford and Cambridge rivalry similar to the US version of Princeton and Harvard or maybe Brown. 

Don't quote me on historical accuracy. I sound like a bloody Yankee from across the pond. I am very new to the English culture. The casual dress is more refine than California and everyone speaks in proper English. I must really speak slowly and try not to use too many slang words or American idioms. The first night on the town my group ran in to a local Oxford curling team and we got a picture and I said the word awesome. They laughed because I'm sure I sound like a Ninja Turtle to them. I was taught the word Mate! As a cool lingo. Socal represent! Speaking of Southern California  I will always use the word "hella" and get a similar odd reaction.

I find visiting the Rewerly House for a study Abroad Program great so far. It is only day 2, I work up for an early 6am morning walk in the 36 degrees Fahrenheit whether it is so worth it and beautiful. A bit chilly for me, but a great way to cure Jet Lag and a night on the town visiting many local pubs. It is free of smog with unlimited drinkable clean water. It is the opposite of California. We had a 4 year drought we don't have a winter. Temperature ranging from 60 to 80 degrees year round. 

I cannot wait to learn from one of the most prestigious University in England. I will not reference Harry Potter but I am in the right place. I hope to expand my knowledge and meet more locals.

Cheero!

review.author: Thomas A.
review.description: A great experience receiving a guided tour of one of Europe's premier centers of learning.  The university is located within the city of Oxford, not as an addition to our enclave next door.  This type of integration into the local community makes for an interesting relationship between the institution and the local population.  We enjoyed the sites and the history.

review.author: Heather R.
review.description: Our tour guide was alumni so we were able to go to his college area and he gave us unique insight into the University. We were able to purchase Harry Potter merchandise and see unique architecture, it was nice.

review.author: Tasty T.
review.description: Now as an Alumni of Oxford, I think back not so long ago, but in high school I always wanted to attend Oxford. When I was fortunate enough to attend in graduate school, the tutorial system is exquisite and the education that I could not have asked for anything better. I am pleased to be an Alumni and part of such an amazing institution.

review.author: Qype User (Willow…)
review.description:
A lot of tourists arrive in Oxford and ask where the university is. Well, in answer to that, it is all over the city. Colleges and departments can be found everywhere and many colleges are open to the public at certain times during the day.


 If you want to see the 'gown' part of the city at its best then try and visit during exam time or matriculation (a Saturday in mid October) when the students and academics can be seen walking around in sub fusc (academic dress/gowns).

review.author: Qype User (Flic…)
review.description:
Oxford University...admire it or loathe it, it's undeniably famous and one of the main reasons people visit Oxford. It's inextricably tied up with the layout of Oxford: the magificent old buildings, the traditions, the culture and many of the inhabitants are related to the university and its spin-off education centres, shops and attractions.


 It's the oldest university in the English-speaking world, dating back to the 11th century. In England its main rival is Cambridge, which was actually set up by some Oxford students in the 13th century. It remains one of the leading universities in the world for teaching and for research, and combines the old with the new.


 Many people come to Oxford thinking there is one set area called 'Oxford University'. In fact, the university is a myriad of buildings, consisting mainly of colleges (there are around 30), which are semi-independent entities like schools with their own traditions, accommodation, libraries (especially the Bodleian) and teaching. There are also libraries, chapels, museums, music rooms and theatres, as well as administrative centres. Many of the buildings are really old, with amusing gargoyles on, towering steeples (Oxford is known as 'the city of dreamy spires') and are sites where great literary, political and scientific figures throughout history made various discoveries and creations.


 Nowadays the university is more active than ever and it's worth popping along during term time to see students wearing their gowns (which some of them wear to dinner, and all to exams), academics in full academic dress on their way to various ceremonies, and to watch the rowing and punting, both of which Oxford is famous for. There are some famous students, such as the actress who plays Hermione in Harry Potter and Bilawal Bhutto, son of murdered Benazir Bhutto. Oxford students are stereotypically rich, public school educated and very intelligent. In reality, there is a good mix of people from different backgrounds, but there's still a high proportion of pashminas, chinos, V-neck jumpers and modern-day Einsteins.

review.author: Qype User (Ninja3…)
review.description: Its an amazing place. The Architecture is beautiful and must see. At just an hour on the train from london or an hour an 40mins on the bus how can you not see it if you are in London?\nThe nightlife is nothing to write home about, but its not there for its nightlife!

review.author: Qype User (damien…)
review.description: This university is one of the best in the country the academic results prove that.\nwhat also proves this is the amazing and famous architecture would make any student or person truely inspired to do good.\nthis is also a fave with the tourists and is a popular destination in oxford.

review.author: Jo W.
review.description:
Since 2013, Jesus College has been the venue for the Oxford Conference of Corsetry. As sad as I am that OCOC will never happen again in this venue (if ever), I am very happy I made it to the very last one.

Jesus College is absolutely stunning, and I am so happy that I had the honor to stay here for a night. My dorm room in Building #17 (which had libraries in the buildings, and dorm rooms on the 3rd and 4th floor) was wonderful, with two rooms! One rather large room with a desk and a wardrobe, and a second room with a bed, drawers, and a bedside table. There was a bonus room: a private bathroom complete with a private shower! They also provided towels, and like a hotel, complimentary shampoo, conditioner, and soap, in a little Jesus College baggie that I was more than happy to take home. Both main rooms also had large windows that opened up, complete with a gorgeous view overlooking Oxford, complete with a gargoyle next to my window. Being neighbors with the Radcliffe Camera and Bodleian Library, I really felt as though I was looking out from a window in Hogwarts.

The main rooms where the panels and workshops were hosted for our conference were the Habakkuk Room and the Periodicals Room. We also had the JCR for our welcome talk, tea breaks, corset show and tells, and closing talk. We also had complimentary meals (breakfast, lunch, AND dinner!) and ate in a gorgeous dining hall that felt like a miniature of the Hogwarts Great Hall. The food was delicious and beautifully presented as well. One of my favorite desserts were the slices of pistachio cakes with rose frosting that was offered during lunch. Oh, so lovely! My taste buds were in Heaven.

The staff was incredibly kind and helpful too. At one point, I accidentally left my key card in my room, and locked myself out of my room. I went to the front desk, and they were so helpful in getting me a new key card that I could use as soon as lunch was over. Thank you so much, staff! Check in and check out was quick and easy too.

Although I am sad OCOC will never happen here again, I am happy that I had the experience to BE here, to marvel over the beauty of Jesus College, to sleep here, explore the halls, eat here, and connect with a community of some of the the world's most skilled and dedicated corset enthusiasts. What happy memories. Thank you, Jesus College, for being the home for Oxford Conference of Corsetry.

review.author: Qype User (mothsa…)
review.description: One of Oxford's hidden gems, Jesus College is tucked away on Turl Street. It is a small College, founded by Elizabeth I in 1571 (the only Elizabethan college in Oxford). The first quad contains the chapel, which is small but has wonderful stained glass in the east window and also a bust of Lawrence of Arabia, one of the college's most famous old member. The Principal's Lodgings, which has a distinctive shell porch over the door, is also in this quad. The entrance to the Hall is off the passage through to second quad. The Hall contains portraits of some of the college's benefactors and famous old members, including ex-Prime Minister Harold Wilson. Second quad has a marvelous wisteria on one of the walls, so be sure to check this out if you are visiting in May. Many people, like me, think Jesus is one of the prettiest colleges in Oxford.

review.author: Sha C.
review.description: Learning goes on here! Grandparents' Day a wonderful experience, nice to be appreciated!

review.author: J Z.
review.description: There are many exceptional academic high schools here in the desert. At Xavier it's the commitment to the total growth of my child that has impressed me, couldn't be more satisfied with the academics and culture of this community.

review.author: Karl A.
review.description: Small local college but don't let that fool you. As an alumni (2002) I can not even begin to explain how great this school is. With that, I'm really here to review their basketball. Even with it being a small school it continuously churns out a quality product. If you have a child learning basketball and are in the area come by and check out a game. The prices as just right and their isn't a bad seat in the house. NCAA Division 1 MAAC conference. Concessions and swag available at reasonable prices. You will not regret it. Also...free parking.

review.author: Wandy R.
review.description: excellent my son is studying and he says he likes so far everything well a magnificent deal with the coordinators I have no complaints the university does not do magic with the students the students are what they have to do their work

review.author: Mary O.
review.description: They genuinely do not care about students at this school. I have been told by advisors that my mental health issues shouldn't affect my school work, continuing by saying that I'm not "good enough" but if I worked harded I could be. Now that corona is happening they won't respond to student's emails or allow students to collect their belongings.

review.author: John K.
review.description: Good solid college education.

review.author: Rosemary D.
review.description: Wonderful! Although I haven't been there yet, I have enjoyed browsing through their website. I will be visiting in the near future.

review.author: Kai-Michelle C.
review.description: So I came here to teach a dance class while the children were out of school for winter break.  They offered a nice variety of art classes.  The children were sectioned off by age group and got an opportunity to have 3 different art classes.  The kids were sweet and the staff very nice as well.  When I have children they will definitely be apart of a camp like this.  Out of school, but learning can be fun in any magnitude.

review.author: Mary L.
review.description: My daughter is a fourth Grade student at Colonial Elementary School in Pelham, NY. For her 10th Birthday Party she wanted to do something fun and creative with her friends. Her and her sister have been taking art classes at the Pelham Art Center since they were little beans. My daughter was set on having a party where they made things out of clay.. so that's what we did... Hey, you only  turn 10 once!!! They made "sandcastles" out of clay and I was amazed with the final product. Instead of painting the castles, they sprinkled sand on them, and it looked like a real sandcastle!! Her friends were thrilled that they got to take something home with them. Everyone had a great time and the best part was that I didn't have to clean up after!!!

review.author: Ben S.
review.description: Sarah Lawrence was VERY MUCH almost where I went to college. It was in my top three after Hampshire College in Amherst, MA & Emerson College in Boston, MA. I LOVE SLC: the campus, the proximity to NYC, the academics and the study abroad options were ALL to my liking. \n\nFor me, I wanted to be further away from home (which was Brooklyn, NY) and I wanted to go to college up in New England on a more rural campus. However, SLC was solidly in my top three for sure. I would have made it work out for me.

review.author: Ben S.
review.description: I first attended SUNY Albany and then SUNY Purchase for my undergraduate. I came here for my master's in teaching. It's an expensive school, but the experience is exactly what you want college to be: lots of things to do (activities, clubs), lots of music, art, interesting people, close proximity to the city, and great guest lectures (Temple Grandin, for example was amazing).\n\nThe Art of Teaching program was wonderful. The professors help you develop what I'll call a golden confidence that allows you to keep your sanity in the face of challenging elementary school administrations/teacher evaluations. Since graduating, I have landed jobs working at public, charted, and private schools. Many schools recognize an SLC diploma as something very valuable and unique; for good reason. I can't stress enough the great experience I had while attending this school, and I recommend it to anybody who wants a well-rounded education.

review.author: SarahZane M.
review.description: Social scene- kinda tough. sharp, creative minds abound- but it is true that you might meet someone at a party and have a great time and great convo- and for whatever awkward SLC reason- you simply ignore each other the rest of the time. \n\nBut- the academic settings, the teachers- the education is what it's all about. You can learn and grow and create beyond your wildest dreams- as long as those are your intentions. Otherwise, you can get bogged down in the uncertain social scene.

review.author: Louis C.
review.description: The party was fun and the food was great. Good music and chill vibes

review.author: Molly K.
review.description:
Oh, Sarah Lawrence, how I love thee. I went to school there from September '86 to May '90, and I received a BA in Liberal Arts. I believe my SLC experience has made my life far richer and more interesting.  If you went to a fabulous high school (I didn't), then it might not seem so revolutionary (mine was pretty lame). FYI, I studied creative writing, economics, Italian, and art history. 

SLC tends to be a place that people either love or hate. There are way more of the former or it wouldn't still be around. I'll try to address the issues in a pros and cons format. 

**Pros:** 
--SLC has an extremely low (= great) student-to-faculty ratio (it was 6:1 when I was there). The vast majority of classes are seminars, which have a maximum of 15 students sitting around the table with their professor. Most of my classes had 6-10 students and I only had one lecture class my entire undergraduate education (that's typical, by the way). A student pretty much can't be invisible at SLC--there's no where to hide (in class anyhow!). 

--The conference system is completely amazing.Students get to meet with each of their professors one-on-one every other week and in those meeting they design their own class that they pursue by themselves with the professor's guidance. Those bi-weekly conferences with my professors were simultaneously terrifying and completely (eventually) ego-boosting. Sometimes I didn't think I'd have anything intelligent to say (especially first year), but I gained confidence in myself over time. An example of a conference topic that came out of a seminar was my study of how England held back Ireland's economic development in the 1800s. I did that topic with Professor Mieke Meurs my freshman year, while I took her class, "Political Economy of Developing Nations." 

--Amazing professors. From Grace Paley to Alan Gurganus to Joseph Campbell, SLC has incredible people teaching in the classrooms. And folks don't go to SLC to publish, they have to want to teach. 

--The don system: Patterned on Oxford College's don system, SLC puts first-year students into small classes taught by a professor who will be their guide/mentor/don for all their years at SLC. It's a special relationship. 

--Great study-abroad programs: I spent my junior year in Florence, Italy. Wow--what an experience. I highly recommend the program. There are also great programs in Paris and Oxford (and probably some new ones--check out the SLC web site). I studied studio art, Italian language, Italian theater history, and Italian literature that year.

--Creative freaks can get their freak on here: For folks who didn't hit their peak in high school (non-Homecoming Queen types, etc.) and have a strong creative/independent streak, this is a great place to go. (There are tons of writers, dancers, artists, musicians, etc., here.) This could obviously be a Pro or a Con--for me it was great. I dressed in black, shaved my head, and fantasized about being the next Sylvia Plath. It was a safe space for me to be weird-ish during my early adulthood and has made me so much more comfortable with all sides of myself and all kinds of people. Why be normal?--especially during college! 

**Cons:** 
--It's a very expensive school (it was second most-expensive when I went there, after Bennington). Unfortunately, SLC doesn't have a large endowment (I do my part--I give every year--really!) Also, because it has a low ( = great) student-to-faculty ratio (I think it was 6:1 when I was there), it spends a fortune on faculty salaries. I put myself through school, which was pretty brutal--I worked very hard in the summers and P/T during the school year and took out loans and got grants. I managed to pay off the loans in good time. It was well worth it for me.

--There are no fraternities or sororities at SLC. (That's actually a pro for me, but I sneak it in here!)

--It's not a big "team sports" school. When I was there the crew team was doing really well, but there's no football or basketball team or any "big" sports teams. There is a kick-ass sports facility there now--that's new since I went to SLC (I am so jealous!).  

--People spend a lot of time in NYC (it's 20 minutes away) and many upperclassmen live in the city and commute so there can be a pull for students between the campus and the city. I don't think that's much of a con, though.

review.author: L K.
review.description:
Sarah Lawrence College =  some of the best money I've ever spent. 

I received my M.F.A. here, and while some people may argue that you don't need an M.F.A. to be the next Sylvia Plath (which you don't), I still found SLC to be a safe haven for me. It was challenging yet nurturing, and I left it an entirely different person than I was when I first walked onto its leafy, lofty, black-squirrel infested campus. I started my time at SLC at the tail end of a very difficult period in my life, and although I didn't quite realize it at the time, this place was a soothing balm.  When I graduated two years later, I was more sure of myself, my writing and my place in the world than I'd ever been before, and I was exposed to all kinds of literature that my traditionalist self had never read before. I was a book snob, and not in a good way. 

The faculty are absolutely wonderful, the classrooms are safe havens of constructive criticism, and the conference system is great. I rarely had the opportunity to actually talk to my professors in college - I always got the sense that I was somehow annoying them, at least the upper echelon ones - but that's not the case at SLC. Your teachers want to talk to you about your work, your life and the way your view of the world influences both. It's so nice to feel as though you matter as a student. 

My outlook on the campus is kind of bittersweet, and that's mainly bound up in my internal host of regrets that I didn't get to go here for undergrad - I begged my parents but they wouldn't let me apply because they told me that they couldn't afford it (which was probably true - SLC is one of the most expensive schools in the country). I guess that they didn't want me to be disappointed if I got in and they couldn't send me. 

But all that really matters is that I got to SLC eventually. When I graduated with my M.F.A., my parents couldn't stop praising the campus, the warmth of the graduation ceremony and the quality of the speakers. My mom told me that if she had to do it all over again, she and my father would have found a way to send me to SLC for college. If that isn't a testament to the quality of SLC, then nothing is, my friend. You know when you belong someplace. If you have the opportunity to go to SLC, take it. It will change and brighten your life.

review.author: Claudia S.
review.description:
Someone else:  YOU went to Sarah Lawrence?
Me:  Yes.
SE: ....but you don't look like a Sarah Lawrence student.
Me: ...is that a compliment, or an insult?
SE:  You just, it's just, you don't look like a feminist!
Me:  I wasn't aware you had to be a "feminist" to go there.

Sarah Lawrence is not an all girls college, not everyone is a feminist and contrary to popular belief, not everyone who goes there is "very liberal", but I'll let you jump to whatever conclusion(s) you want.  This was my dream school and even though few people supported me, I got in.

As of Friday, I can officially say goodbye....


I had many ups and downs with SLC in the 2.5 years I went there, but right now as I write this review I'm getting teary-eyed remembering all of the great moments I had there.  Even though I don't have my degree from SLC, I know I'm not going to regret any of my student loans.  

I'm currently finishing up my degree back home and all I can say is, THANK YOU SARAH LAWRENCE!  I'm in a program similar to SLC, but it's just not the same.  The donning system...well it's one of the best things about this school.  I remember when I thought I'd take computer programming as a freshman and 3 weeks later realized I was going to crumble and needed to get out.  I'm freaking out in my don's office and say something to the extent of "I don't care what I take as long as it's not religion" and he replies with, "wait, now let's talk about that."  What do ya know, I end up in a religion class that I absolutely loved.  

Here are some of the reasons I fell in love with SLC:

Komozi Woodard - I met him when I visited the campus as he was my host's don and I knew at that moment that I needed to come here and take one of his classes.  His class is the only one I've ever kept all of the books I had to buy.  Our conference time was the last of the day and we almost always went over by at least a half an hour.  I always looked forward to the stories he'd tell in relation to the class discussion and I'm so happy that I was able to take one of his classes.  

SLC's ECC - Whenever I would send out my resume, this is frequently the first thing interviewers ask about.
