I remember finding out I was going to be with the 2-year-olds and thinking "but I work better with 4 and 5 year olds".  This "job" is what really solidified that I was pursuing the right career path.  

The psychology department - Look at how many faculty members are in this department.  I bet it's a lot more than you would have thought.  Most people focus on taking writing classes, theater or dance (and with good reason), but not me.  My don (a member of this department) had to sit me down and tell me to start taking classes in other departments before I ended up not being able to take any psychology class.

The campus - It's gorgeous and small.



I finally requested my official transcripts be sent to my new school and it was a bittersweet moment for me.  I am so close to graduating and I finally realized the extent of what I gained from coming here.  I remember sitting in a class freshman year when I piped up with, "I feel like I haven't learned anything.  When am I ever going to get to put this information to use?"  Moments later, everyone else said the same thing, but before I knew it I was bringing in material from previous classes to back up what I said in another one.  If there's one thing I should have done, it was those worksheets.  It would have made backing up my points a LOT easier.  Oh well, lesson learned.  

Thank you Sarah Lawrence, for everything.  Even the 9:30am classes that were at the bottom of the hill.

review.author: Dina C.
review.description:
I took a class at the Writing Institute so this review is for that.  I had a several classes one with Sara Saffian and one with a professor who was absent for moth of the semester because  of family issues.
First and foremost the Writing Institute pulls people from the surrounding areas who have been out of the classroom for many years and it often results in, at least in Saffian's class, little to no classroom control.  It was not like any college class I had ever experienced.

Beyond students in the classroom stating that they did not agree with something and discussing the logistics of homework in class, I found Saffian to be lacking in ability to be helpful and insightful of student work and somewhat rude.

The other instructor was great, although absent most of the semester.

I think it may be hit or miss and if your interested before you sign up for a class read the reviews in rate my prof on each instructor.

review.author: Adeel S.
review.description: This school is simply brilliant... you know when i come to think of it this school is so awesome that i dont even mind the food at the pub...\nIf you are someone who wants to get to know yourself... and want to experience the freedom to think and then practice it... this is the place for you....

review.author: Karen K.
review.description:
totally AWESOME yo!!!

100% absolutely worth the 120+K.  now i have the value and respect with which i can demand to work at excellent, reputable and well established companies such as mcdonalds or even, just imagine it... walmart... for the rest of my worthless and trivial life.

sarah lawrence... where our school colors are black and black... a place where one uses bic lighters to open bottles of rolling rock purchased illegally from the mobil gas station down the road to enhance the mystical and ever enlightening experience of making out with gay boys and performing cunning linguistics on straight girls high on yellowjackets, adderal and ritalin while simultaneously learning about the horrors of how we came to be in our current hell state here in this life.  

seriously tho, it was pretty dope, and not just in that heroin kind of way...  when you have been privileged enough to have great teachers who exemplify passion and honesty, and who care enough to share their tremendous wealth of knowledge with you, anything in life is possible.* things you once thought concrete begin to breakdown and deconstruct, and become slowly rebuilt in a painfully harsh light.  a new, more precise and elevated logic is formed and you are forever changed.



*exceptions may include the prevention of genocide, hate crimes, the ruining of our earth, karen k. getting published and making bank, a future with no clean water, homelessness, domestic violence, idiots being elected into office, etc.

review.author: Dian L.
review.description:
Dear young 18-whatever age year olds considering (or not considering) Sarah Lawrence,

I wrote a no holds barred, name naming review/guide to Sarah Lawrence on Epinions and I would like you to read it.  http://www.epinions.com/review/educ-Colleges_and_Universities-All-Sarah_Lawrence_College/content_497328098948?sb=1

During my time at Sarah Lawrence, I amassed a lot of knowledge about the school.  To start, Sarah Lawrence is not a (creative) writing school, neither is it a school for the "creative arts," poetry, theater, music, or dance.  Other untrue ideas: It is not all girls, but rather has a 70:30 female to male ratio which is even harder for women than all girls schools, believe it.  Neither is it particularly dark and gothic (despite the "even the squirrels wear black" t shirts, that died in the 90s along with the heroin era)... Hipster is the new stereotype visible around campus, neither was it as activist/feminist as portrayed, unfortunately (It was a more lax/apathetic time in 2004-2008, I hope that is changing now.)

It is a liberal arts school, academic in nature, for those who want to have the freedom to study different subjects in great depth without a required core curriculum or a major, i.e. delve into Literature, Urban Development, and Biology at the same time.  Its strongest subjects and professors are all informational and academic in nature, regardless of whether it is in social sciences, humanities, or even physics.  
It is also for those who want small (15 person) seminars and need a discussion in class/personal contact with an eccentric and phenomenal professor.  

If you are a self motivated person who likes to steer their own learning and challenge their own self, you will derive maximum benefit if you can also integrate what a professor tells you into your thought process, if you are a rabidly interested, but somewhat unsure person, you will still reap value from Sarah Lawrence.

Do you know why the 15 person seminars, conference work with professors (meeting with your professor every two weeks and developing a written or non-written thesis) are its strongest sell?  Because the PROFESSORS are why you will stay.  After the lonely lack of available men, love/hate attitudes of "one foot in and one foot out" negativity on campus toward the school, hard social life, inept administration, clunky academic structure, doubtful application to the professional world, the elite level squad of Sarah Lawrence professors (hopefully supplemented by your own motivation to steer your education's course) will give you the mind expanding education you never dreamed of and protect you from the various problems and inequities.  

Sarah Lawrence has a cadre of many great, most good, few mediocre, and even fewer bad professors that you will want to get close to.  They will enthrall you, change your understanding, infuriate you, rearrange your mind, and impress you with their brilliance, craziness, prickliness, and caring.  Most people can count on their fingers the amount of great teachers they've had in their life.  I overstep 15.  

(Incidentally, the Oxford program study abroad is also a selling point for the rigorous academic training the PROFESSORS give one on one.  It is a valuable experience and a crucible.)

In my epinions guide, I wrote my thoughts on what professors I particularly recommend.  Those that are feted all stars with years of reputation who understand the system and love to teach students.  Put your ear to the ground.  I think that the humanities, particularly the literature department, are the strongest because they have the best great to good professor ratio and most variety of subjects.  (Addendum: Sara Rudner for dance.)  

One thing I will tell you is that if you are not careful, SLC will IN NO WAY teach you the creative problem solving, logic, and entrepreneurial ideation skills you need to synthesize, create, or learn something completely new at work.  Every work environment presents new problems.  No one can teach that.  Problem solving and analytical skills not related to those in writing are just as creative (i.e. the tech boom).  Neither will you have the resources to learn professional writing like cover letters.  But, life eventually teaches people who leave the nest the skills they need to get by or perish and college isn't leaving the nest.  Self starting, flexibility to change, leading and managing people, etc.  Some schools teach the bare minimum to survive in a job and this is a disservice to the 18-25 year old growing brain, but here a student can pitch a no-hitter in terms of education (wow, baseball metaphors.) 

Few people know what they want to do at 18, (why people change majors) but, with a strategic course load, professor guidance, and meaningful internships, you can carve out a path of a career that also appeals to your passions.  SLC experience is valued in the workplace, whose values are even more unexpected than you think.

review.author: Pam R.
review.description: Sarah Lawrence-\n\nBest ten zillion dollars my family ever spent :D

review.author: Maddy S.
review.description:
Sarah Lawrence is not at all what it seems to be. I transferred after my first year because it was so bad; it's really going downhill. Here are my reasons why I think anyone should steer clear of such a school:
1. The administration sucks. They do not care about any student, or situation. If you need help, they are not going to make it better. I was in the big party dorm when I first arrived, and my RA was smoking weed and drinking right inside our apartment! I tried to switch rooms to a different dorm, and the administration didn't get around to it until after the first semester was over! I then told them I had to be in a smoke/drink-free room, and the roommate they gave me smoked pot every night with the window closed. 
2. Everyone does every drug. They do pot outside on the lawn and in all dorms. Cocaine and heroine are done in the bathrooms and dorm rooms, ecstasy is taken at all the parties, and in the first semester alone there were over 10 near-deaths of students because of this. You think then that security or administration would try and crack down on it, right? Wrong.
3. Everyone smokes. There is supposed to be rules and limits on smoking, but none of that is followed. People will stand right in the middle of walkways and right outside of doors so there is no escaping the smoke. My biggest problem was they stood up against dorm buildings (when they're supposed to be 50 feet away) and I couldn't leave my windows open (even in the heat) or the disgusting smell of cigarette smoke would get in. Students roll their cigarettes in class and the teachers don't care either. 
4. The parties are horrible. There are no fun dancing parties. A party at Sarah Lawrence consists of depressing music and people sitting around doing drugs together. If you call security to shut it down, they don't care one bit. I've seen a security guard walk into a dorm room where everyone was binge drinking and smoking pot, and just laughed and told them to keep it down.
5. There is no sense of community. Everyone is very cliquish or a complete loner. There are no big campus wide events or sororities/frats, and the school is famous for "Sarah-Lawrencing," which means ignoring someone when they say hi to you. People are rude to you, and if you don't drink or do drugs you get alienated. I felt so alone during my time there, and after speaking with others I've realized that many people get extremely depressed from the isolating environment.
6. There are so many weirdos. I'm sorry, but it's true. A lot of people seem to have personality disorders, and others just seem plain psychotic. It is not a normal, educated environment whatsoever. 
7. Hill House is terrible. It's the main dorm for freshman, but it is about a 20 minutes walk from campus, right on the highway. There are people who live there who do not go to the school, but are residents of Yonkers and are extremely sketchy. This apartment complex is a party house with music and sex 24/7; there is always noise and smoke and filth everywhere. And it's so far from campus it's ridiculous! 
8. The president doesn't care about anything. She turns a blind eye to all the problems with drugs and drinking and smoking and bullying, and pretends that nothing is wrong and that her school is perfect and running just as she wants it to be. When anyone approaches her with problems they have, she acts like we're making it up or just trying to ruin the school's reputation ourselves. 
9. There are very few options to study. Everyone their first year is required to take a First Year Study, but people seldom get their first choice, and end up in a class that they hate. This happens a lot with other classes too; a majority of people get bumped and don't get to study what they want. Also, for creative writing students, there are very few good classes, even though that's for what the school is supposed to be known. For history majors, this school has only classes on modern history; there are no classes dealing with anything pre-1900s. 
10. There's no major, and what's more, there aren't even real concentrations. For your three classes for the first 2 years, you are not allowed to take more than one class in one subject. Which sucks, because if you're interested in English, you can only take one English class, and your other two have to be in, like, history and science, or history and physiology...
11. The teachers are very brilliant, but a lot of them are too out of the box or weird to have any real connection with them. You have a Don, which is like an academic advisor, but they rarely are very helpful and the weekly check ins become monotonous and unproductive. A lot of them don't seem to seriously care about the individual circumstance of the student; you can tell that when talking with you they're just doing their job.
12. The size is so small there is no escaping any of what was previously mentioned. The population makes it so that there is no opportunity for any type of student diversity.

review.author: Jess C.
review.description: Best. College. Ever.  Where else do students actually spend an hour a week with the PhD teaching their class?  Where else do you never have a TA?  It's all real teaching, real discussions, being inspired by your teachers and your peers.

review.author: Joyce S.
review.description: I graduated in 1988 (JJ Abrams was in my writing class and we graduated the same year...) and I absolutely loved it there. I'm reading the rest of the reviews and realizing that here it is 25 years (!) later and evidently nothing has changed. I had this French don from Paris who helped me get ready to participate in the Paris program. Even though a lot of the students found her difficult to deal with I thought she was really awesome. I have to say, I don't know if it's because SLC or not, but I am definitely an independent thinker. I don't have to wait for people's permission to do what I need to do. I will always have really fond memories of my time there, and I will always miss it.

name: Westchester Community College Extension Center Mount Vernon

review.author: Bhumi Z.
review.description: I highly recommend Liberty Montessori for its nurturing environment and excellent academic curriculum. I have sent both my children to Liberty for 3 years each. They were both exceptionally well prepared to enter Kindergarten in a competitive school district. I was particularly impressed by their ability to transition to an online format during the pandemic, as well as the numerous measures they have taken to keep the school operating safely once children were allowed back in. My children always loved their teachers and progressed academically as a direct result of the tailored curriculum. They have been taught reading, writing, math, languages, science, art, and yoga all in a loving environment. We could not have asked for more.

review.author: Dara L.
review.description:
The decision to send my pre-school aged son here was thus far the worse decision that I have made as a parent thus far.  I wish I could give zero stars.  The school is tiny, antiquated, dingy and smells like mold. As an example of their antiquated viewpoints, the literature used to describe their school actually says "retarded children".  When I spoke to Dr. Jagoda about how this language might be construed as offensive, she replied that the literature was old, and that if I had a problem with it, I should not have signed my child up for their school. Mr. Jagoda, whom I was told I needed to contact to discuss partial refund of my nearly $4,000 paid for two weeks of school, told me that they didn't write it, but copied it from a book (not cited, btw), so it's not their fault.

Liberty Montessori made my bright-eyed, enthusiastic little boy sad to go to school each day.  The school fed my husband and I a bunch of lines before we signed up, none of which turned out to be true. After only two weeks, I pulled my son out of their school and sent him elsewhere. I am happy to say that he has now returned to his normal, cheerful self. I am STILL waiting for Dr. and Mr. Jagoda to return my calls regarding partial refund of the $4,000 we paid their school and it is three months later.

Buyer beware!!  Stay away at all costs.

review.author: Amanda B.
review.description: Wonderful Montessori school! My son has been enrolled for 2 years going on 3!!!  This is a very special school it creates a sense of community as a home away from home for our children! He is beyond happy to go to school each day and loves all his friends (he talks about school and his friends all the time). This is very loving environment by no means are children pulled or dragged around. Additionally I've done drop off many times and children are not sitting around crying. In terms of choices for children of what they want to focus on---there are plenty Bc I can tell you my son isn't interested in his writing skills and this is not being pushed on him, he chooses to focus on other tasks!

review.author: Jenna O.
review.description:
In response to Dara L's completely inaccurate review.
I have two children in Liberty Montessori. My 3.5 yr old son and my 2 yr old daughter. One morning it was snowing and we were driving by and saw Mr. Jagoda and a staff member clearing out the driveway when we stopped in there. Mr. Jagoda was one of the nicest men and set me up for an interview the next day (if there was no more snow!). We went Tuesday and we fell in love with Dr. Jagoda and staff that we started him Thursday!! He was 2 when he started but when our daughter turned 18 months we couldn't wait to start her! 
The school has given my children the best education that kids their age can get! The staff is the absolutely BEST staff any Montessori can have! Dr. Jagoda is one of the most accomplished and educated women I have ever come in contact with and she hand picked each teacher in the school! 
The atmosphere is clean in all aspects and my kids feel at home when they go each day. Both kids skip their way in to school (this speaks volumes to me!!)  to be greeted by the happiest teachers! 
Every day my kids are coming home singing a new song or reciting a new story! My husband and I made one of the best choices as parents sending them to Liberty! We are so excited to send our month old son their when he's 18 months! Anyone looking here for reviews for Liberty Montessori do not let Dara L's review taint your decision as its a big decision of where to send your kids and you will NOT be making any mistake by sending them to Liberty Montessori!

review.author: Rosalinda M.
review.description: I enrolled my 3 year old son with this school when he was 2 and he can be quite a handful sometimes with fussing and resistance to change. Also, my son tends to be very particular with who he is comfortable with and who he will engage with. The teachers in this school were able to match their approach with my son's style. The lead teacher devoted herself to guiding my son in properly expressing his needs/wishes, managing his emotions more effectively and behaving well while collaborating with me to continue the same at home. This was all done by his teachers in a nurturing, loving and influential manner.  In a short period, I have seen remarkable growth, maturity and calmness in my son. He speaks admirably of his teachers daily and is a very happy little boy when I pick him up. I've visited my son's classroom on several occasions and the atmosphere is positive and supportive. The teachers tactfully direct the children with kindness and affection. They are taught different languages, they are read to, they sing and dance, they have playtime, arts and crafts and they seem to always find a reason to have a party. I am grateful we found this school and the teachers there. I recommend this school without reservation.

review.author: Lexie D.
review.description:
I don't post often, but I really wanted to give a shout out to the TLE in New Rochelle. 
We absolutely love it. The teachers are fantastic and the directors super-friendly and available whenever needed. The environment is clean and stimulating for children, and they are great about sending updates via the app. 
You know it's a great place when the kids are running excited in the morning to go to their class. 
We are so happy to have found the TLE and I absolutely recommend it to anyone looking for a great daycare.

review.author: Ben S.
review.description: Best in lower Westchester for child care. Affordable, great care to the kids and great staff. Love it

review.author: Kara B.
review.description: Both of our girls attend TLE in New Rochelle and we are always impressed with the cleanliness, creativity and support. Jailene and Melissa are the best- always going above and beyond the call of duty to support the little learners! They both truly love and care for the kiddos as if they were their own!

review.author: Annie C.
review.description: Not ASD friendly!! \nMy daughter was diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder when she was 18 months old. I was devastated. She is 2, 1/2 years old now and thriving. She is a sweet little girl, fun loving and a pure joy to be around. The manager was very hard to get a hold of, I left several voicemails that weren't returned. I waited over three weeks for a call back! I finally got through to the manager.  I asked about availability for a 2 year old and she said they did in fact have space. I'm always upfront with my daughter's diagnosis for transparency reasons, but I didn't expect to get a taste of how hard this world was going to be for my daughter at 2 years old starting with my experience with this place. The manager told me she could not accept my daughter because they do not have staffing trained to deal with an autistic child. With the CDC estimating 1 in every 44 children being diagnosed with autism you don't have one staff member trained to handle an autistic child! A major company like "The Learning Experience"? I didn't expect a major company like this not being ADA compliant. It's shameful! I was even willing to pay the highly exorbitant tuition fee because of how close this center was to my home.  I will be contacting the headquarters about this. I'm writing this so that hopefully this place will get their stuff together and other parents of special needs children don't have to deal with the disappointment and heartbreak of doors being closed in your child's face over a condition they have no control over like how I did.

review.author: Shalini V.
review.description: My both kids went to this school for approx 9 months and during these 9 months there were so many changes in their teachers, teachers leave every 2-3 months, most of the time our kids were with one teacher only (though they sent that to our face but when doing pick up and drop off we noticed that there was one teacher and our preschooler talks so he would tell us how many teachers were there in the class). Due to lack of teachers and insufficient qualifications of the teachers, the kids were not kept well in the school. Most important thing, the front desk staff lied to my face multiple times and when I pointed to them of all the issues, they again lied to my face that they will take actions and nothing changed. Some of the front desk staff is very rude and others liers. They don't take the kids out. Every time I asked them, they said they have stroller issues, or other reasons. But their main problem is they don't have teachers to manage kids in the school forget about taking them out. My kids have been going to another school now and I have seen so many changes in the way they are kept in school. I will really really not recommend this school to anyone. Stay away from them. You can't trust whatever they say on anything.

review.author: Dushane R.
review.description:
I'm going to cut to the chase and say that The Learning Experience has given my daughter the best care and community I could ask for. If you're looking for a responsible, responsive, proactive, open, clean and educational place to send your kids, this is it. Highly recommended. Worth every penny. 

Now, a little more detail: 

I toured TLE New Rochelle before my daughter was of age to attend, and before my family had moved into the neighborhood, but our considerations, thoughts and needs were prioritized right away. Ms.Jade stayed late to accommodate my family's schedule, and showed me around the sparkling facility. Months later, that warmth is still present, and as a parent it means the world because I know that's the environment my child is in. I'm pretty sure my daughter thinks her teachers are her family.  And that's cool by me!

I love that there is a curriculum, even for the infants, but what I appreciate the most of the way TLE goes about social and emotional development. My child comes home happy, and goes to school excited to see her friends and teachers. She's always been a fairly social kid, but her environment at school has definitely encouraged her to blossom even more. 

My family is like any other working family. Things don't always go to plan. But between updates on the school's app, or being able to send a quick text, we're able to be flexible with accommodations in a way that I honestly wasn't expecting. And that sense of flexibility is true on their end as well. Whether it was setting up safe procedures during covid, or reacting quickly to things out of their control (snow storms, etc), TLE has always been quick and SUPER CREATIVE in finding solutions and communicating the plan to parents. There hasn't been a situation where my family was left with our hands in the air- we've always benefitted from their partnership. 

And I should also mention that one morning my daughter and I showed up and there was a table of bagels and coffee for the parents. That didn't hurt, either!! :)

review.author: Hannah D.
review.description: We love TLE-New Rochelle! My son has been going there since he was 10mos old and their infant program is wonderful! He is 20mo now and is thriving. We can't wait to see how he does in their toddler classes as he is one happy kid! The teachers are kind and the entire staff is accommodating, responsive, caring and truly cares for the well being of the children. Ms. Melissa and Ms. Jade (and Ms. Angela no longer at the New Rochelle location) are ALL wonderful and amazing people!! Thank you TLE-New Rochelle! You ROCK!

review.author: Aya A.
review.description:
TLE was my son's first daycare and I think it will be his last because from what I can see now, I don't see us going anywhere else before he goes to school. 

My son started at TLE in July of 2019. He was 1.5 years then. By September, I was looking for other daycares and I was looking to move somewhere else where I can find better options. Why is that? Well, because the management, back then, had some communication problems. And there was a lot of turnover in the teachers and there was not much stability. The higher management though were so communicating and good at addressing my concerns. They hired a new manager. Also, almost most of the teachers who didn't meet the required level of expertise were changed. 

Now, I'm changing homes. One of my major requirements for the new home is to be close to TLE so my LO can go there until he goes to school. This is how much everything changed since few months ago. 

To be honest, since the first few weeks. I could see huge improvement and change in my LO behavior and skills. Because I was so lucky to have one the great teachers from the beginning. Ms Aly, who is one of the teachers who was there since the daycare opened, is very responsible, informative and attentive. she tries her best to make the kids and  the family happy. My LO calls the daycare "Aly" because of how much he loves her. 

My son now moved up to a different class, and this was scary for me at the beginning but actually the teachers there are so great too. 

I hope TLE would continue on their high standards as I can see it now. Yes, sometimes small things still happen because nothing is flawless or perfect. But now you can see immediate actions and things keep getting better.

review.author: Dayne S.
review.description: My son has been at the learning experience for almost a year now and I regret he wasn't in there sooner. Great establishment, great staff and great parents. Very helpful and responsive to any issues or concerns that may occur. Would highly recommend for any parents looking for day care for their child.

review.author: Dean G.
review.description:
Being a first time parent is never easy. It is one of the most difficult journeys we have had to face because when it came to the "who will help us" phase we were a little lost. At first we didn't look for a day care, but when it came time to look for one we had certain criteria. Was it the right thing? Do they teach as well as have fun? Is the setting safe? Do they provide food/nourishment? This along with many other questions dreaded my mind, but in the process of all this, we discovered The Learning Experience (TLE). When my wife and sisters-in-law showed me TLE for the first time, honestly I was a little skeptical. I couldn't believe that such a place existed especially one as established as this. As I was doing research into TLE, we decided to go for a visit and fell in love. All my criteria and my wife's criteria for a day care was met. We found a cozy nest for our son to enjoy, learn, play with other children and then some. We are in love with TLC and all I can say is that if you have the opportunity to go see and have your child attend, do it. It's a chance of a life time and the faculty has been nothing but God sent. 

Albert Einstein said "You can never solve a problem on the level in which it was created." As working parents with constant changing schedules, it was no doubt we were having intense child care issues. Traveling and having inconsistent child care providers proved difficult while we waited. Darlene and her staff have always been available since we first found out about the location of this TLE. My wife and I did have an opportunity to go to other locations while we waited, but we decided to wait it out because of how wonderful and marvelous Darlene is. Believe me, I cannot stress it enough. You cannot have good things without waiting and the wait is over. Not everyone will agree but that's why opinions and advise are warranted by different people.

If you wish to contact us, feel free to contact me by replying. Trust me. We waited a while, but it was worth all the wait. We were kept updated all the time we called while it was in the process of opening. Sometimes patience and a little waiting goes a long way. I hope this helps everyone that reads into this a little bit. Thank you and God bless.

review.author: Anna R.
review.description: My kid is 2.2 yrs old. He definitely had trouble in the beginning to adjust, but picked up quickly as he was taken care of. The teachers and the management staff is very good and they hear you. I could simply talk to Ms. Angela or Ms. Darlene whenever I wanted to. And they always assured me. I like how Ms. Andrea pitches in whenever there's a short of teacher or help needed in my kid's room. And my baby loves her. Kids want to see happy and smiling teachers, it is VERY IMPORTANT. And I hope they always stick to this feature. The facility is well managed. As parents, we really like and recommend TLE. My husband was keen on TLE and kept waiting for the center to open. He was so excited and happy to enroll here. My only reason for 1 star less is that my kid isn't a great self eater yet. He's moody. And initially the teachers tried a couple of times to feed him or sit with him while eating, but they stopped that soon. Having said that he dsnt eat anything except for sipping water. I wish they had put some more effort on him than just quitting if he nodded a NO. \nOverall, a great and happy place for kids with good teachers around.

review.author: U A.
review.description:
This school is very pretty looking, but the communication of the staff, blatant deception, and neglect of laws and care for children is outrageous. I enrolled my children ( first time in daycare, normally very happy kids). They cried the entire day everytime. I was ok with the fact that they were transitioning so it would be hard. I never got any pictures for one of my children for 1 week. The other child that was adapting well, I got pictures on the 3rd day. I called many times during the day to ask for pictures and updates. They reassured me all was fine and he was " transitioning". When I picked them up after 9hrs, my son had only had some crackers 1 barely wet diaper and cried most of the day per one teacher, but another said he was fine! They told me pictures were coming, but never came. What are you hiding? The excuse tht the internet didn't work doesnt cut it. The pictures should be saved on the iPad, but there were none. They never got my paperwork or read the packet they made me complete of like 10 pages on how to manage my kids. It was given back to me to sign portions (children section unread). I made every attempt to accomadate the new situation, even told them I can leave work, but no feedback given. So what do I do and how can I help?? I leave a long message, professionally. Guess what, they ignored it. I had to call them and ask if they got it. They had the audacity to give me attitude then tell me my kids should not be enrolled because they didn't have a medical form for them that they lost! Long story short they told me I can leave NO CHARGE...smh. So let's make a list.
1) understaffed from 6a to9a and 3p to 6p. So many kids in a room with just one teacher on 2 occasions I picked up my child.
2) They are not ready to manage children that are not already daycare seasoned.
3) They lie. Tell you what you want to hear about your kids so they can keep numbers up and protect their bottom line.
4) Children are not their top priority, the business is
5) Teachers are not showing up and coming in extremely late per a conversation I overheard in management meeting
My kid is traumatized and the next school I took him to he was scared to death for me to leave his site. Communication and honesty could have redirected and resolved this mess. No one sounded like they genuinely cared until I threatened legal action and wanted to leave.

***update, first day of school at new daycare was great! No problems both children happy...transitioning doesnt equate to trauma after all

review.author: Colleen L.
review.description: We've had our son at TLE New Rochelle since he was about 4-months-old. He's now 1.5-years-old and runs -- literally runs -- into "school" every single morning with a big smile on his face. He adores his teachers (shoutout to Miss Laura, Miss Namiah, Miss Jailene, Miss Grace, Miss Victoria, and Miss Kat!) and we've been impressed with how quickly his verbal and fine motor skills have developed in such a short period. He's also never been sick, minus the occasional runny nose -- a testament to TLE's sanitation practices, which are especially appreciated right now. Most notable to our great experience at TLE is Miss Jade, who started as the lead infant teacher and is now director of operations. She keeps the wheels running at the center and helps us feel our son is in great hands every single day (and he loves all the stickers she gives him). Also, the center's proximity to the New Rochelle train station is unbeatable... There is a parking garage just across the street and then it's a quick walk to the train. The only downside: no windows or outdoor playground, but the kids still go for regular walks and play outside pending weather. For those in the area (and especially those commuting into NYC), we highly recommend!

review.author: Sahoori S.
review.description: A wonderful place for little ones. We couldn't ask for a better daycare. Very friendly staff and teachers. Clean and full of fun activities for kids.

review.author: Palo M.
review.description: My son is currently enrolled and I couldn't be happier! I have been researching and visiting day cares for about a year and I was not pleased with any. I did a tour of TLE in Riverdale and I was very pleased with the concept but didn't really like the location and thought it was too expensive. When I heard of this location opening up I was very excited and hopeful. Did a tour and reviewed prices and I knew this would be the one. I was told it would take a while due to it being a new construction and liscences have to be obtained. I was willing to wait because I completely fell in love with everything about this day care. The staff is great and very friendly, the location secure and clean, the curriculum is amazing, hours are great (not many day cares open early and close late). Last but not least I love the fact that there is an application where I can see pictures of my son, everything he eats, all of his activities and diaper changes. I can finally go to work in peace and know that he is in great hands. I recommend this place to everyone! Definitely best decision ever.

review.author: Shaureena B.
review.description:
The communication was atrocious and we had to go through our bank to get our money back. Our child never actually started daycare with this center.

We were very much looking forward to starting our son at this center. It is very close to our home and the company overall has a good reputation. We were told by Darlene in December that the center would open in early January but did not get an exact date because it was still under construction. We went to a tour of the facility in January where we were then told the daycare would be opening in early February. (Change #1) We officially enrolled our son after the tour. We gave a start date and had it confirmed by Darlene.

Toward the end of January we hadn't gotten any updates so we contacted Darlene who said they were expecting to open end of February. We expressed concern for the ever changing opening dates and with mom going back to work we needed to make sure our son was settled before she returned. We requested a refund and were told they needed to speak to the owner about it. After this conversation we NEVER heard back from Darlene. We left messages where people made apologies for the lack of communication and said they'd forward our message for a callback. Again, we were NEVER contacted, not even to inquire why our start date had come and gone and our son had not shown up. We finally enrolled our son in another TLE location about 20 minutes from home and about $400 more expensive. Finally, after weeks of no one returning calls or emails we contacted our bank to initiate a dispute. Only after receiving notification from our bank did someone from the center call us back.

This is the place that is supposed to care for our children. Communication is key to proper care and safety. If they ignored us and didnt care enough to inquire about the child they were to care for, where else will they lack in communication?

review.author: Nea J.
review.description: I've been working here so far for about two weeks now and I am totally in LOVE with the center, its bright and welcoming colors, the bright children and my supportive co-workers. The parents have been great also and I am enjoying all of the big personalities that the children have. The trainings have been pretty easy and adjusting within the center has been a breeze with Darlene and Ang! No need to purchase my own supplies, the classrooms are fully stocked and Darlene is always prepared and willing to provide any materials that are needed. Very appreciative of that! I also highly appreciate being able to take the children on daily walks as its refreshing and needed. Definitely feels like a family here and I couldn't ask for anything more!

review.author: Erin C.
review.description: My husband, son and I couldn't be happier with TLE! We had a very difficult and horrible experience at another local daycare so we were very particular with the next daycare our son would attend.  Angela, the assistant director, put our minds at ease with all of our concerns and our son is now thriving. The staff is an amazing group of warmhearted, patient, knowledgeable and experienced professional care givers. What stands out to us the most is our first week at drop-off our son was naturally scared. We didn't know how the transition would go and, as any parent would feel, we were nervous. The staff gave him such a warm welcome and made him feel comfortable right away. This spoke volumes to us and solidified that we made the right choice in daycare provider.   Our 3.5 son is learning so much through their curriculum and the services that they offer are exceptional.  We get pictures and information throughout the day which is always a delight as well as reassuring to see. We love to see our son smiling, laughing and having fun all while learning.  I have told all of my friends about TLE and would highly recommend the center to anyone.

review.author: Lefter G.
review.description: The staff is amazing . Very helpful . They made me feel very welcomed I felt like I was part of the family there. Will recommend this place to anyone. Thank you for everything.

review.author: Leah O.
review.description: My daughter graduated from here. I can't review the college experience although she seemed to\nLove it. It's a small school with about 7000 students. Which she loved. My review is about the look of the campus and the graduation. The campus was very clean and green. They had it whole graduation planned out really well. There were police officers directing you where to go. And then they had a shuttle that would pick you up and drop you off at the graduation building. They only had a few schools graduating at our daughters 3:30 pm graduation.  They evidently had a later graduation and a Saturday graduation for other schools of study. It really cuts down on the length of the event and the traffic getting in and out of the college. I thought this was very smart. It was quick and efficient. The graduation was less than an hour long.

review.author: Kenya M.
review.description: My daughter is a freshman this year! Move-in day ran really smoothly and there was a lot of help. The students really had everything all planned out and helped a lot. There were also free snowcones! She will be on both campuses for classes; her dorm's on   the downtown campus which is right in the heart of Columbus and seems super fun. There were a number of student organizations that had a lot of activities for the first week so she's already met some new people. \n\nGo Cougars!

review.author: Chris L.
review.description:
In response to the post made by Sean T about Columbus State and Columbus.  He typed:

"Columbus is a pretty dull, backwards, cliquish small town so off campus entertainment is almost non-existant unless you have the time and money to visit Atlanta and social life/on campus events are almost nonexistant unless you're either in Greek life or a Christian fundie. The few lame "events" on campus would be a ghost town if it weren't for free food and t-shirts. Local job market is horrendous. Food is rather expensive and leaves a lot to be desired. The surrounding town is extremely backwards and rural and is pretty much the armpit of America. Most administrators who are native Columbusites can be very corrupt, so Atlanta students, North Georgia students, do not be fooled by CSU's "First Choice" PR campaign."

The college is as good as most I have seen.  I attended a top-tier university with several world-renowned departments. They are specialty departments heavily involved in astronomy and space exploration, closely linked to NASA and the Jet propulsion Laboratory. Columbus State may not have those programs, but the academic departments are all good.  On the comment by Sean T: "...unless you have the time and money to visit Atlanta and social life/on campus events are almost nonexistant ...".  First, the work is nonexistent, not "nonexistant".  Columbus is the sort of place you come to GET AWAY from the Atlanta mega-mess.  Get it ?

The local job market features many large and respected companies, especially in manufacturing.  I don't know where Sean T gets his information. Columbus is a nice city, with its share of blight and problems, but the urban waterfront is probably the nicest in the country for a city this size.  Local dining is not expensive that I have ever seen after 19 years.  Good specialty restaurants, especially along the historic waterfront. 

It would be nice to know the surrounding circumstances that provoked that rant about CSU and Columbus...

review.author: Alan P.
review.description:
As a MIS business major, this University provides many opportunities that make it very competitive with other Universities in Ga.  Examples are: Certification for one of the Business World's most used programs by that company,  fair tuition costs, very good support for veterans, internships with large company's like TSYS and Aflac, great student recreational facilities (the gym, pools, climbing wall are great), and a great faculty that go out of their way to help students that show effort and ask for that help.

   Parking can be challenging at times but I am sure that is common at other Universities.  I really enjoy it here and for a business major it really is a pretty great place.

   Just for clarification,  Shawn T in a previous review says "This "university" has a 30% graduation rate thanks to a combination of mediocre local high schools and harsh grading from professors."  He is skewing numbers, which many people who are not educated enough to understand them often do.  So for he and other Yelp readers I will clarify. 
  
   He is referring to the "on-time" graduation rate, which does not consider  transfer students, persons taking more than 4 years to graduate, or several other factors.  To fairly compare, consider that Auburn University's "on time" 4 year graduation rate is 38.2% and the national average is 34.4%.  Also consider CSU has many active military and veterans that are "non-traditional" students like myself that also count against that number.

   As you can see CSU is actually very close to the average, but I guarantee you that the professor to student ratio is much better here than at Auburn.  Plus, let's get real, only the people who could not get into Alabama end up going to Auburn anyway:)

review.author: Sean T.
review.description: This fourth-tier community college masquerading as a state university is not worth it unless you're a non-traditional student or a native who plans on transferring to a different school after a year or two to save money. This "university" has a 30% 6 year graduation rate (in response to Alan P. the ontime rate is actually 12% according to the state's own data). thanks to a combination of mediocre local high schools and harsh grading from professors. Columbus is a pretty dull, backwards, cliquish small town so off campus entertainment is almost non-existant unless you have the time and money to visit Atlanta and social life/on campus events are almost nonexistant unless you're either in Greek life or a Christian fundie. The few lame "events" on campus would be a ghost town if it weren't for free food and t-shirts. Local job market is horrendous. Food is rather expensive and leaves a lot to be desired. The surrounding town is extremely backwards and rural and is pretty much the armpit of America. Most administrators who are native Columbusites can be very corrupt, so Atlanta students, North Georgia students, do not be fooled by CSU's "First Choice" PR campaign.

review.author: Sarah P.
review.description: Service Members get a great deal with this airline! Five free trips!! It's crazy. Now my flights did get delayed often but I mean it's free ya know, still got to where I was goin'. If you're looking to take a bunch of flights in 3-4 days I would definitely recommend this one. Overall 10/10 would recommend to a fellow service member.\n\n*DISCLAIMER* You do not get to choose where you fly to or when you fly there. Plane DOES NOT LAND you must jump out.

review.author: Isaac Y.
review.description:
Probably the best Army school I've yet to been in. 

You get there on a friday, and after you've been checked in at the BN building across the street and submitted your DA1610 and received your meal card, you are told to report to your company area at around lunch time. There they get your information, orders, and assign you your roster number and STX (squads) and platoons. Then they issue you our helmets and canteens that you will be carrying around every day at Airborne School. After that, off-base and Abrams Hall personnel are released, and those that are staying in the barracks are released to the barracks for the weekend. Each Platoon rotates fri-fri pulling CQ duty (1 officer or NCO with 2 joes).

Ground Week begins that Monday, with your standard PT test at the gravel pit near the 250ft towers plus a 10second hang from the pull up bars. You only need to pass a minimum number of pushups and situps (45, 56 something like that) in proper form (all the way down, all the way up) in order to pass it. Noone's going for a 300, there's just no time for that.

After the pt test you are immediately moved into training. You will run everywhere (do the airborne shuffle) so get ready for that. 

Ground is consisted of the mock doors, the 35ft tower with ziplines, and PLFs (Parachute Landing Falls, or how to properly land and fall) in the gravel pits. 

The next week is Tower week, and here you will continue to train on the 35ft tower, if weather and time permits, the 250ft towers, and then the swing trainer for your PLFs, and the suspended harnesses where you will train for malfunctions.

Final week, Jump Week, you will conduct 5 Jumps, usually 1-2 jumps a day from an US Airforce C130 high-performance aircraft. The standard is 2 hollywood (chute and reserve chute) jumps, 2 combat equipment jumps (medium molly ruck and weapons case with the chute and reserve chute), and 1 night jump. This is on the cadre's discretion depending on time and weather conditions. Might do 3 hollywood, 1 combat, no night, etc etc. But you will do 5 jumps total. You will be pulling 18hr days. You will be in the harnesses all day. You will wait for hours. You will be sore and tired. Get used to it.

Friday morning you will conduct your graduation, and after the barracks are cleaned you will receive your paperwork and leave Benning. 

The quality of training is excellent, best in the world. The cadre know their stuff inside and out. This will be the most rewarding, some of the best training in the Army you've ever received. Get psyched for it Airborne, you'll have the time of your life. Just remember, feet and knees together, and eyes on the horizon. 

Hooah Airborne!

review.author: Sue C.
review.description:
Here at Airborne School, ground week separates the boys and girls from the men and women, and tower week separates the men and women from the fools...because only fools would jump out of planes. 

Day one of jump school we learned a very valuable lesson: Airborne is an equal opportunity school because everyone is gonna hit the ground, one way or the other.  How's that for incentive to pay attention and learn to keep your feet and knees together?

This is by far the best Army course I have been to in my career as a TRADOC Ranger.  I have the utmost respect for the Black Hats memorizing their blocks of instruction rather than going off PowerPoint or notes, and for being able to apply the material to actual jumps and real airborne units.  Plus nothing beats jumping out of a C-130 and floating through the air.  Truly a course not to miss.

JUMPERS, HIT IT!

review.author: Stan C.
review.description:
How do you get over your fear of heights?  Go to Jump School of course.  Why didn't I think of this sooner?  Cuz...uhhh...I'm still afraid of heights.  But I have to say, this was one of the best times of my life.  Thinking about the training (3-5 mile runs in combat boots rocks my socks), the camaraderie (Privates with 3 months service are treated the same as Majors with over 10 years service), and the gauntlet (when you get your Airborne wings pinned to your shirt without the anchors and a hard smack from everyone as you walk down the line) brings a tear to my eye...sniff sniff.  

Brief overview straight from the all knowing Wikipedia
Ground Week:
During Ground Week, students begin an intensive program of instruction to build individual airborne skills, which prepare them to make a parachute jump, and land safely. They train on the mock door, practice parachute landing falls (PLF), exit the 34 foot tower, and train on the lateral drift apparatus (LDA). To go forward to Tower Training Week, students must individually qualify on the 34 foot tower, the LDA, and pass all PT requirements.

Tower Week:
A team effort is added to the training with the "mass exit" concept. The apparati used this week are the 34-foot towers, the swing landing trainer (SLT), the mock door for mass exit training, the suspended harness, and potentially the 250-foot free tower. Tower Week completes student individual skill training and builds team effort skills. To go forward to Jump Training Week students must qualify on the SLT, master the mass exit procedures from the 34-foot tower, and pass all PT requirements.

Jump Week:
During Jump Week students make five parachute jumps into Fryar Drop Zone (DZ) located in Alabama on the Fort Benning Military Reservation. Trainees must run to the air field, conduct pre-jump training, and then get into their harnesses and await their turn to jump. Generally, two of the jumps are "combat jumps", in which the jumper carries a ruck sack and a dummy weapon. The other three jumps are "hollywood", in that the jumper only wears the parachute and reserve. At least one jump is at night, although, during training cycles where Jump Week falls on a three day week (due to a Federal holiday), a night jump is not mandatory to graduate.

review.author: Jim S.
review.description: It is 20+ years since airborne school and still one of the best things I have done. \n\n20 years later and my knees sound like rice Krispies, but I would not trade this experience for anything.

review.author: David S.
review.description: Don't believe the hype. Theres no "separating the men from the boys/ girls from women". Its a coed school with weekends off, so, obviously its going to be pretty easy. When I went through in '08, they made you stop doing pushups and situps as soon as you hit your minimum because they're usually at max student capacity if not overbooked so they don't have time for the "hooah hooah fake motivation" BS. They're there to teach you how to jump without being babysat. If you're 11 or 19 series, you probably did more running at a faster pace then you'll do here. Keep your mouth shut and learn what you can, don't act stupid on the weekends and get into trouble, and you'll have a great time. There are so many weak soldiers that show up to and graduate from this school that the chances of you not falling into the middle or excelling is very slim.

review.author: Heather W.
review.description: Black hats are overall great, very professional. Just so everyone is aware you now have to do a chin up. You must hang all the way down from a bar, pull up to your name tape, hold for 20 secs. This is a task I would have completed had I known it was a requirement. So I was not prepared. I do plan on coming back and completing once I train for this event. This event disqualified every female in my class other than 2. So ladies this is no joke. Train.  What little I did get from the course it seems like great training. They just need to get info out there sooner.

review.author: Kim K.
review.description: One of the most fun times of my life. Loved this school! Kinda jealous to hear they are using the 250' towers again (if that's true). I wish I could go do it again! Minus the running everywhere in boots part, of course.

review.author: Susan C.
review.description:
Excellent instruction with Rhonda Kite and Susette from Living Herbs.  Enjoyed Rhonda's pace of instruction and extra tips for subbing other ingredients to make your dishes you own.

Delicious entrees, app, salad and dessert.  Rhonda used a pressure cooker to cook the short ribs.  So juicy and moist.  The flavors were amazing!  The fresh herbs from Living Farms were so flavorful.

I highly recommend any of her classes!

review.author: C E.
review.description: Love, love , love this cooking school! I've taken a wide assortment of classes here. I especially recommend the Cooking with Trader Joe's classes with Rhonda Kite. She has yummy recipes made with Trader Joe!s products but more importantly are the great tips she always shares!\n  If you have a spouse who likes the kitchen too try one of the evening couples classes- happy cooking!

review.author: Maureen G.
review.description: my friend booked two slots for my birthday.  She came down with the flu and was unable to attend.  I sent an email to see if we could reschedule.  I received a copy of the policy and a very curt reply that the policy states a 72-hour cancellation.  Since I did not make the reservation I knew nothing about the policy.  Kitchen/Kitchen has  always been open to any changes so I assumed that this school would have the class to reschedule.\n\nin reviews on google it was stated that they overbook anyway.

review.author: Robert M.
review.description: they cancel classes - with no notification - drove 40 minutes to get here for a class i registered and paid for 6 weeks ago only to be told "there was a conflict" with the instructor. I had to put in a request to get a refund !!

review.author: Cynthia R.
review.description: Our class was with Janet and the class felt very disorganized. She had people participate in the cooking but never really showed an example of what was expected. Lots of time was spent looking for things and we had to ask that the fan be turned on because of the smoke and fumes. \nIt was easy to follow if you know how to cook but if you are truly a beginner you would not feel comfortable trying to recreate the dishes.\nThey do offer some really good  wine to purchase while you are in class.

review.author: Dana B.
review.description: I have taken numerous classes here!  Each Chef instructor brings so much information to each class!  I glean little gems at each lesson!   This week was Cooking with Fresh Herbs with Chef Rhonda Kite!   I learned so much about clams (which I was always afraid of attempting) how to choose them, what I'm looking for, what questions to ask...    tasted different fresh herbs.  Wow!!  Didn't expect some of those flavors!  Each recipe was excellent and something that I not only COULD make at home.. I actually WILL make!!!    Signing up for more classes today!!   I'm addicted!!!!

review.author: Denise K.
review.description: My husband and I attended a "Couples In the Kitchen"  class this evening at "Cooking with Class" in La Quinta, CA.  What a delightful evening!  Chef Billie, our instructor was fabulous.  We loved the selection of dishes, from from the appetizer to the soup, the salmon and orzo salad to the Creme Brûlée...not only were the recipes easy to make, the food was delicious!  Thank you Chef Billie for a wonderful fun filled evening.

review.author: Holly G.
review.description: Went to wine dinner tonight. Food was very good wine was tasty but very short pour. Price of $85++   Not a great deal. Some friends with us compared to Ruth Cris. Portions and wine fell short of expetati

review.author: Rebecca R.
review.description: The staff is amazing. The selection of classes that are available are awesome. They even have classes for couples, kids and teens. Love this place.

review.author: Donna H.
review.description: Andie,\n\nWe had such great food and fun with Chef K.K, Stephanie, Doug and Cameron at our recent corporate cooking class in La Quinta. I must say better than expected and better than advertised.  The food and wine were a fabulous treat. The menus will be used and abused.  Everything was planned out and presented brilliantly we had a great time! Thank for a great interactive experience!

review.author: RvrWld Q.
review.description: My husband and i had an amazing time at the thai class tonight. There were only 6 of us and Kayla had many great tips for thai ingredients. Everything was so delicious. She and Jake (i hope i got his name right!) were both very friendly and welcoming. It was a great night!

review.author: Darrell M.
review.description: My daughter purchased gift certificates for my wife and I for our anniversary. When my wife and I went there for dinner we were told the certificates where for the classes only. My daughter specifically said it was for dinner. We were told they had changed their policy and could not accept the certificate for dinner. Wow!! How bad is this! My daughter spent $100 and we can't use it. This is unbelievable! Do not go!!!

review.author: Wendy B.
review.description:
Want to learn to cook?  Cooking With Class can help!

This is a beautiful teaching kitchen that would make Food TV proud.  We have enrolled our daughter in cooking camps twice now and have been thrilled with the experience.  Not only did she learn to make some great recipes, she also learned about kitchen safety, nutrition and staying organized.

Aside from the camps, Cooking with Class offers adult classes, wine tasting dinners, and party options.  Check out their cookbook too.

The only downside to Cooking With Class is that their kid's camps are expensive compared to other camps in the area.  You do get quality for the money though.

review.author: Alice A.
review.description: The idea of this place is great, but the execution, not so much. The class I went to was clearly over-booked and I ended up being crammed in a corner in which I could not see anything going on as far as cooking. It was nice that they had mirrors on the ceiling to watch the cooking, which is what I had to do, but that's not that much different than watching a cooking show on TV. I wasn't able to truly see what was going on and every meal tasted the same due to the addition of the same 2-3 unique ingredients in each dish served, even the dessert. The class I went to was a wine paired one, but we received less than half a glass of mediocre sparkling wine. I specifically took a taxi to the event because I figured we would be trying a bit more than that. It was not really a true wine tasting/pairing as advertised. The class wasn't cheap either at nearly $100 dollars. To top it all off, the elderly lady that owns the place was not very pleasant and she was extremely rude in her correspondence that my jaw actually dropped. I really wanted to like this place and learn some new techniques, but sadly I learned absolutely nothing from this class and the food was very average. I found myself scrambling to take notes the whole time to try and absorb all I could from the chef, but I didn't get much from it. Hopefully others had an appropriately booked class and actually learned something.

review.author: Christine H.
review.description: A great experience every time!\n\nI've been to Cooking with Class three times now and have been equally impressed every time.  The food has been consistently exceptional, and the staff is so friendly & helpful, with many generous cooking & product tips.  I also really like the space and being able to see well from any seat. I've taken many guests, and even the non-cooks have loved it.

review.author: Jessica W.
review.description: Just did the "Girls Night Out: sushi and sake" with my mom and sister. Just a fun experience! Andie was so knowledgeable and kept the mood light and fun. Would definitely attend again.  The food was amazing and the company was even better! Go check it out. (:

review.author: Jen H.
review.description:
I took the Trader Joe's cooking class with a group of ladies and we were all underwhelmed to say the least.  $75 per person got us each one glass of wine, a carrot dipped in kale pesto, and a main course that consisted of spinach tossed with a few shrimp. The flavors and dessert were great, but my husband would have eaten his arm off if he had come.  My friend that booked the class said she was told there would be wine and appetizers for coming early - not.
We would have been able to look past the small and SIMPLE bites if we had filled up on invaluable tips on Trader Joe's products or were introduced to some chef-secrets, but that wasn't the case.  Instead the owner spent the time that could have been used by the chef telling us about corporate history and philosophy that anyone could (and she did) pull off Google.
The counter stools were painful to sit in, and the clanking of the dishes from their restaurant kitchen next door was distracting.  
We had been wanting to do this for years so it was a big disappointment - we regretted not saving the $$ and buying one the many Trader Joe's cookbooks that are out and experimenting ourselves.

review.author: Lori S.
review.description: Chef Andie is inspiring. Can't wait to hit TJ's and start cooking up some great food.

review.author: Karen T.
review.description: Awesome atmosphere , great food and wines. Our favorite "dinner spot" to take out of town guests!

review.author: Janet B.
review.description: I have taken the 26-wk culinary program and 12-wk baking programs and gained a lot of knowledge and confidence in my cooking.  I have taken many other classes and always learn from the knowledgeable instructors as well as building my recipe repertoire. \n\n The variety of classes offered from Trader Joe's, Healthy Eating, couples in the kitchen, wine pairings, pasta making, kids camps, and even sipping and painting offers something for everyone.  The staff is very friendly and the kitchen is well laid out and offers easy viewing from any seat.

review.author: Sandy F.
review.description: This was the most comprehensive CPR class I've ever taken. I loved the fact that you can do it at your own pace,  at the comfort of your own home or wherever there's internet access. I felt very prepared the day of the practical test, which was very fast and easy to do! I highly recommend this method of learning to acquire those necessary life saving skills.

name: College of the Desert - Intensive English Academy

review.author: MiYong E.
review.description:
My cousin went to this program, and I have so many complaints. I don't think there is enough time or space for it all...

1. Do NOT get with their host program. They charge $500/month and make no guarantees about your living arrangements. One kid was given a garage as a room and no AC. Most are told that they have to stay in their bedrooms and are not free to use the house. Some are not allowed to cook, so they have to microwave or eat out. Some hosts take multiple students so they can make a lot of money and cram the kids in. They also limit utilities and all that. Yes, I've heard horror stories. Ew, and one old couple only gets young Asian girls, and the old man is super friendly with them and likes to sit out with them while they are in the pool.

2. They got super nosy and refused to give my dad a letter stating that my cousin was a full-time student at the school on letterhead. Simple, right? nope. They didn't want to give the letter, and my dad had to raise hell for t he simple letter. 

3. They give each student a handbook. I went in the day after they gave them to the students and asked for an extra copy for my parents. The lady hands me the book and starts explaining away excuse after excuse about errors and mistakes and misinformation and contradictions contained within. Did she bother to do the same for the students? Nope. Only told me because I speak English fluently. 

4. One teacher was super strict. Which is fine. But she was also MEAN. The teacher told one girl that she was stupid and shouldn't even bother to learn English.....and she did so in the middle of class in front of everyone.

5. Another teacher isn't qualified to teach. Why? Because she was marking certain things incorrect. But they were correct. And I helped my cousin find the rules in a grammar book I bought for him since their textbooks don't cover grammar at all (kinda odd for an English academy?). He took the papers in with the rules marked in the book and asked her why she marked them wrong. The teacher just said ok and left. Eh? Did she bother telling the other students that she was teaching them to write run-on sentences instead of proper compound sentences? Nope.

Should I go on? Nah, just know that the list continues on and on and on....

review.author: Steven S.
review.description: The superb staff at iCreative has come to my aid twice, solving my Mac issues with swiftness, professionalism, and friendliness. I recommend them highly.

review.author: Nancy D.
review.description:
After I had  migrated my data from my old Mac to my new Mac, I had lost interest in the older MacBook Air.  My new Apple watch was distracting me as was my to do list for my road trip.  

Apple was only going to give me a minimal credit for my old computer so I took it to icreative to take a look at it. 

My intention was to give it to my son, so they wiped it clean, checked the battery, and texted me later that afternoon when everything was complete.  I was expecting that they would replace the battery, yet I was surprised to learn that they said I didn't need to.  I am so glad I was referred to this location.

Most of the work I could have done myself but sometimes when there is a time constraint, it's easier to pay for the experts to get it done right. You can feel confident when you come here that they are extremely knowledgeable and you will get the best service on all your Apple products.

On Eclectic near the Post office off Hovley.  Eclectic runs parallel to Cook Street. It's immediately on your right after you turn from Hovley and takes up several Suites.

review.author: Nicholas A.
review.description: They really know their apple products. A good option if you are having trouble at the Apple store.

review.author: jf h.
review.description:
Amazing service and super fast turn around.  The customer sercice is outstanding and they called a few times to keep me updated on what they found on my 7 year old I Mac that the Apple store could not fix.

Easy to find and much better service I think than the Apple Store in Palm Desert!!!  

Very veyr vey happy and glad to be able to write this review.

review.author: Perry C.
review.description: Without doubt, this is really a top notch and information. Jonathan did a superb job... making sure the new products replacing old routers are in working order. He was able to give time to communicate the technical things and advised when necessary concerning the speed of our internet. He certainly knows his stuff. I am very pleased with excellent servicel\n\nPerry C.

review.author: Chrissy J.
review.description: I wouldn't recommend coming here! They are trying to make money any way that they can. Apple sent me to this location and they were trying to charge me $265 when Apple said it was going to be free. Icreative even said it would take 5hours-48 hours to fix but I called support while in the parking lot and they had my computer fixed in 45 mins and the female's attitude changed, no way I'm paying $65 just for them to talk to me, $70 for them to do what Apple already did remote and then $70+ for them to download the MACOS that Apple said should be the only thing they needed to do. \n\nAs I was there 2 other older customers were complaining about the prices. They won't even talk to you unless you pay for consultations $65 minimal. A joke!!!! There were other issues while here but whatever I'll never come back! Try to contact Apple tech support via phone before coming to Icreative. You may save a lot of money!!!!!

review.author: Preston F.
review.description:
Have been a Customer for years. Excellent Service. Know their STUFF and now sell much of what you need !!!


Preston Fischer

review.author: Gary W.
review.description:
I live in cathedral city, ca---for many years and have always used any help with Apple products i have gone to the Apple Store in El Paso. Well for some reason--i looking up apple tech and found Icreative today, and took my iPhone problem to them.
When i would have taken this to Apple Store, either makes appt with Genius--would be few days--or turn in iphone to get problem fixed and have it there for couple days.
Today at Icreative--the iphone special tech too my phone and solved the voice mail problem--right there--and then to pay--was no charge at all!!
So i have new place to go with any apple product problems

review.author: Sabrina D.
review.description: ICreative had many open appointments while the Apple Store was booked out to the next day, and everyone there was super sweet. When trying to take my iMac to run diagnostics on it the cost would have been $200 but they ran my diagnostics and gave me the issue with a quote on how much it would take to fix. My issue was a bigger fix so I only paid $35 for the diagnostic run, but they were super thorough! Will definitely only be coming here to take care of my Macs. \n\nThank you!

review.author: Sean M.
review.description: This team would make Apple very proud, from the professionalism of the team, look/feel of the store, and the ease of communication and use of technology. I will absolutely come back the next time I need service to an Apple product. \n\nShout out to Rafael - he was kind, attentive, and really thought outside the box to help me. I can't say enough good things about this team.

review.author: Jesse F.
review.description: I had liquid damage on my computer and worked with Matthew. He was fast, diligent, professional, courteous, and funny. He informed me in detail the work he was doing, how it would impact the computer, and the risks in a very digestible way. Liquid damage is weird and we'll see how salvageable the computer is over time, but he repaired it really quickly and got it working as best we could.\n\nWe run a business and deal with electronics repairs frequently. This is by far the best repair experience I have ever had. It's unfortunate I don't live locally because I'd love to be able to regularly rely on Matthew.

review.author: Berneil M.
review.description: If businesses could get Emmys iCreative would win hands down!!!!  It is such a delight to go there for whatever tech support you need. Staff is genuine and smart and supportive.

review.author: Bob M.
review.description: The Internal Speakers in my Macbook Pro suddenly became unavailabe. I knew they worked because they "gonged" at startup. I spent time on the phone with Apple Support, which was terrific, but no solution. I even did a reinstall of my OS. Still no cure. Casel helped me at the counter. He quickly figured out that the Digital Output jack switch was stuck in the ON position. (I had mistakenly plugged my analog headphones into that jack recently.) He had a special tool to turn the switch off. Problem solved. When I asked, "How much?" He replied, "No charge." iCreative is a terrific repair service for all your Apple needs. I highly recommend them. Thanks, Casel!

review.author: Jayar F.
review.description:
Right now it's more important than ever to support our local businesses in the Coachella Valley.

Thank you, Rich, and the team from iCreative for your 5 Star  Repair Service.

I am glad that you were able to diagnose, repair and replace my MacBook Pro in a timely manner. My keyboard is working flawlessly, and I am enjoying the new battery on my device.

If you are looking to fix, update your Apple Devices, look no further, I highly recommend that book an appointment with the team online. 

Thank you, Rich, and the iCreative Team!

review.author: Sam S.
review.description: Mathew helped me repair my shattered iPhone screen the same day I went in even when supplies were short during the coronavirus pandemic. He was very helpful and got me in and out quickly.

review.author: Rafael P.
review.description:
The best place to bring Apple products! 
Amazing and kind team.
As an Apple Authorized Service Provider they are doing a wonderful job.
Now that I know iCreative, I will always bring my iPhone, iPad and Mac there when needing something for sure!
You should go to!

review.author: John C.
review.description: Top notch service and information.  I had my iphone screen replaced and its as if I never turned off my phone.  I was late for my  pickup at 5pm closing, but they stayed for me and let me in at 5:20.  Saving me 24 additional hours.  It's great to know during these times of store closures, one being Apple, that I can go to an Apple certified (allows for repairs not voiding warranty) and get something fixed at Apple prices.  I had $29 screen repair per mu insurance agreement and that's what I paid.  \n\nThanks again guys for letting me in!!  I'll be back...

review.author: Georgeanne Y.
review.description: Jonathan Gorman is brilliant. He has selflessly helped me out on countless occasions. Everything from designing and installing a whole house system, to advice on buying devices, to procuring and setting up devices, to helping untangle tech nightmares created by others. He's one of a kind - knowledgeable, careful, thorough, methodical, fair and trustworthy!

review.author: Justin David C.
review.description: Incredibly fast & awesome service all around! I was visiting Palm Springs on vacation and my MacBook Pro keyboard stopped working which was horrible because I needed it for work and all the other things I use it for every day. Thankfully, I was able to quickly & easily schedule a service drop-off at iCreative and Rafael the Apple Certified Technician at iCreative was able to get everything fixed with superb customer service & in lightning-fast time! Couldn't be happier with my service experience with Rafael & iCreative! Highly recommend!

review.author: Julia C.
review.description:
