The bus is set in a room that looks like a small movie set with buildings, a faux street and streetlights. Here is a link to a Youtube video of this exhibit: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=h82ajl69iy0

OVERALL it is a great experience, especially when coupled with the other Civil Rights museums in the downtown area. Not far away from the RP Library the City of Montgomery is working to construct a park and monument @ the site of the famous bus stop where Rosa boarded. Not sure when it will be ready as digging was underway during our May 2019 visit. The Library is actually the location of the arrest. Both the Time Machine exhibit in the Children's Annex and the Bus Arrest exhibit in the main building are must see's when visiting Montgomery Alabama and the Freedom Trail. Come see the quiet unspoken life's work of a Civil Rights pioneer.


2019/82

review.author: Ben E.
review.description: This place is really good. It was engaging, emotional, and it left me feeling so optimistic about our ability to make a positive impact. I recommend it for everyone. Another thing I liked, it's much more immersive than most museums. Def recommend.

review.author: Pumpkin C.
review.description: Another great museum to visit while you're in Montgomery. I decided to take my family, luckily it wasn't packed during that time, which gave us the freedom to take our time to reflect while reading and listening to the host. They do not allow you to sit on the bus, however just to be there was an experience.

review.author: Julio H.
review.description:
Such a historical figure... 

This museum is a very fun museum. Your visit starts with a brief video, only to be followed by an interactive exhibit. It is one of the coolest things I remember at a museum. It really charges you emotionally and creates an interest. After the initial exposition, you follow into another room where you free flow and explore at will. If you are not familiar at all with the Civil Rights movement, well, there are lots of reading to do on these displays.

This is one of the better exhibits I have been to, and I truly think they should make it a traveling exhibit.

review.author: Paisley T.
review.description:
Well, 2 out of 2 exhibits were 'out of order' and so I didn't get to see the museum like normal. But still. 

I guess the bus time machine would be cool for grade school kiddos. I mean, the video was informative and all but the shaky bus was just a goofy distraction for me as an adult. And since the Rosa Parks hologram wasn't working I cannot comment on the most critical piece of the museum: The actual part about Rosa and the boycott. Oh well. 

On the other side, the room opened up but they had to turn the lights on in order to see the graphics and pictures. I basically just walked through and read the placards. Towards the back, when you walk through the larger exhibit pieces and follow the boycott timeline that's where it gets cool. They did a good job with the last section of your visit. 

Customer service was great at the front desk. But in the gift shop where you buy your tickets I felt like the lady was irritated that I bothered her with a question.

review.author: Katherine C.
review.description: The introduction is excellent.  The initial film to the actual bus and the interactive film of her arrest is a treat to watch.  Its $7.50 for this half of history.  The artwork and artifacts are excellent.  There was free parking in the lot opposite corner of the museum.   Although the metered parking was plentiful and cheap.  Coins only though.  The museum took about an hour at a leisurely pace.

review.author: Alexis B.
review.description: Great little museum on the site where Rosa parks was arrested for refusing to give her seat up to a white man on a city bus in 1955. There's a short video about segregation in busing in Montgomery and then a short video which depicts the way the arrest occurred. And then there are a couple of small rooms containing artifacts relating to her arrest and the subsequent successful Montgomery Bus Boycott, including the original fingerprint arrest record of Mrs. Park as well as other court documents and police records. (There is also a small gallery which, when I visited in April 2018, had some very powerful art by V. L. Cox.) The museum is a little on the small side, but well worth a visit if you want to learn more about Rosa Parks and the Montgomery Bus Boycott in the place where that history occurred!

review.author: Loren M.
review.description:
As an educator I jump at the chance to learn about historical events so while in town visiting family I knew I had to stop at the museum. 
My first impression was that the staff was not very warm or welcoming. The tone of the 4 people that I encountered was not very helpful or patient. 
Once we got our tickets we went to the Children's Museum which consisted of a big noisy "bus ride" that played a video that took the rider through history up until the Rosa Parks incident. I found this part very overwhelming even as an adult. 
Back at the museum we watched another short film and then went into a room to watch a video reenactment of the night Rosa Parks was arrested. 
The museum has other paintings, photos, memorabilia, and artifacts that take you through the civil rights movement. 
I would say this is a "must do" while in town.

review.author: Michelle J.
review.description: Beautiful museum that honors a civil rights pioneer. The staff is amazing. I didn't have a lot of time but they have a gallery, in case you don't have time for the museum. There are two parts to the museum so you should leave about two hours. When I return I will probably take the time to really take it in. I didn't count on there being so much to see in Montgomery.

review.author: Iman S.
review.description:
Had a wonderful visit to the Rosa Parks Museum. I didn't realize that the children's wing and main museum were two separate things. This is probably why the first time we tried going, we thought it was closed but it said it was open. But it's because we were at the children's wing entrance. So be mindful of that. Just walk up the sidewalk and the Museum and Library entrance are right there. 

Decided to take my 7yr old, because it was the day of the midterm elections and she's doing a report on Rosa Parks for school. 

She said it Mae her feel a little creeped out. I asked her "why?", because we had also gone to the EJI's Lynching Memorial and she didn't find that disturbing at all. Apparently for her the photos and videos at the Museum make it more real for her. But she did retain a lot of the information about Rosa and the boycott. 

I'm going to ask if her school will take the kids to the children's wing next year. 

The staff is friendly and very helpful. Enjoyed ourselves

review.author: Jon C.
review.description:
"This is so creepy. Hurry up" is the text that I got from my friend while making a slight detour and hitting the restroom instead of walking into the "time machine" immediately after paying $28 for two adults do to both the Children's Time Machine piece as well as the museum.  

When I walked through the doors, I saw what he was talking about. Inside a big room sat an over-sized replica of a bus surrounded by used computer parts and lights that were intended to make the place look like you were traveling back in time. I don't know if I would have called it creepy - but with him being the only person in the room, I can see why he wanted me to hurry up and get there so they could start. That's right.. it was just the two of us along for the trip through time.

The feature started and Mr. Rivetts, our "bus driver" (which looked like the robot from the movie Short Circuit) took us on a trip through time starting in Cincinnati meeting a young boy named Jim Crow and ended up in the 1950's after being introduced to Mrs Parks. While definitely geared towards children, it was worthwhile to go through. There were TV's throughout the entire room and the walls became projection screens, so even if the room was packed with students on a field trip, everyone would be able to see.

After going through the Children's part, our admission also got us into the 1955 and beyond part of the exhibit. A much smaller room was waiting on us with very few seats, but we sat down and watched interviews on three projectors and learned more about Rosa Parks specifically. After about 15 minutes of watching this, the automatic doors opened and we were outside on a street corner in 1955 watching and listening on the city bus when Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat. 

The rest of the tour was a self-guided walking tour of the bus boycott, church meetings, police reports and historic memorabilia. As I walked through the museum, I thought to myself many times "I can't believe this happened only 50 years ago!" 

Learning about this in the history books is one thing.. walking the streets of Montgomery and seeing it unfold on a likelike tour is something completely different. I'll always remember this trip and be thankful that I was able to do it.

review.author: Dee H.
review.description:
Troy University oversees the Rosa Parks Library and Museum.  After a trip to the Civil Rights Museum, we stopped by here.  Without a doubt, the Rosa Parks tour features the most interactive and engaging setup that I have ever seen.  After passing the ticket gate, visitors are invited to watch an opening video on a three-panel television display mounted high above.  Given that we were a large group, seating was insufficient, but we didn't seem to take issue with plopping down on the floor.  In retrospect, it gave the video a drive-in sort of feel.

The next stop was an audiovisual tour of the Montgomery bus boycott.  A facsimile of the bus appeared against a wall.  Audio recordings simulated Ms. Park's refusal to vacate her seat; though Rosa's voice actor's speech was a bit slow, I appreciated the accompanying voices' authenticity until the moment of her arrest.  This part of the museum was very dark, so I would urge visitors to be careful navigating this space.  The doors opened to reveal a walking exhibit of the planning and aftermath of the bus boycott.  The guide continued to walk among the exhibits and ushered us through them.  When we got to the end of the walk, double doors featured an audio recording of a MLK sermon; at its end, visitors were invited to walk through them, simulating a church revival service.  The tour ended shortly thereafter.

I think the only thing I have to recommend is being told what else is in this building.  I suppose it worked out well since we had additional stops planned.  Nevertheless, I urge visitors to view other exhibits in the museum.  Of interest is a room showcasing the tattered clothing of enslaved Africans, their names tagged on the sleeves.

review.author: Shara W.
review.description: Loved it he is interactive tours. Felt like i was there back in time. Very educational!

review.author: Shannon J.
review.description: A beautifully crafted edifice in honor of our beloved she-roe-- Mrs. Parks that has a children's location right next to it!!!  Simply Lovely!!\n\nDonaldsonville. La

review.author: Robert W.
review.description:
My wife and I have been so pleased and felt blessed to be part of the Saint James family. 

Our Journey began in January 2021 when we made the decision to move to another public school. We traveled to  Birmingham and Auburn researching schools and neighborhoods. After a number of area visits, meetings with real estate agents and tours of homes, nothing seemed to fit.  So at one point  we looked upward and ask God, "this isn't working out, do you have other plans"?

He then began to unveil His plan. That was to look at private schools in the Montgomery area. The cost would be significant, however, after running the numbers, we realized the cost of moving coupled with the premium for housing, we would actually save money over five years. 

We began to reach out to private schools and narrowed our search to two. One a Christian school and the other, Saint James, a secular school. We then began communications with the admission office. 
They were amazing. Their processing of new applicants was as well orchestrated and professional as one could have imagined. 
Next came the course selection process. Once again, this team was very engaged in guiding us along as we chose the academic course levels and electives. 
 
During the open house event, we heard from the head of school, Dr. McLemore, and the middle school principal Dr. Taylor. They deftly handled the power outage that evening and carried on without the use of lights or PowerPoint. They didn't miss a beat. The handout materials they provided during that meeting were well thought out and very useful. 

Finally, after meeting with each of the teachers, we gained so much confidence that God had led us to the right school. We had scoured Birmingham and Auburn in our quest to find the right culture and environment best suited to prepare our son for college and life. As it turned out, that school was Saint James. 

Everyone we have met has been so helpful, communicative, responsive, and professional. Even the parking lot attendant is a great guy! 
The consistency, professionalism, courtesy, communications and passion to the education, emotional and psychological well being of our children has been such a constant theme throughout our Saint James experience. 

While we initially had some reservations over choosing a secular college preparatory school over a Christian school, as it turned out, Saint James is staffed with teachers and administrators who lives are marked by Christ. While Saint James doesn't have required Bible study or verses displayed on their marketing materials or on the school walls, it's clear the presence of the Holy Spirit is in this place.

review.author: Will L.
review.description:
Flat out...this is a top notch flight training facility.  From the moment I contacted trainer Woody Sellers, the experience has been fantastic.

Located on the north side of the airport, the hanger is easy to get to.  The lobby, study rooms, and hanger are clean and inviting.  As you head down the main hallway, you can see most of their immaculate aircraft parked out of the windows below you.  Before walking down the stairs to the hanger floor, you are greeted by their state of the art simulator.  Not only is it cool, it will save you money on your quest for certification.

If you're in Alabama and wanting to learn how to fly, this is your place.  Not ready to commit? Just go by for an introductory flight.  I promise, you won't regret it.

review.author: Vic B.
review.description: Tried to show up twice a year ago around 10 am and 2 pm. No one was there but the lights were on and door was locked. Left my name and number on the door and no one ever called back. Called again random times this year and left messages but still never got a call back. Save yourself the hassle and fly at Shelby County. Over the mountain aviation is WONDERFUL.

review.author: Norma R.
review.description: My son is in the nursery at this location and we have loved it. He is always happy and well taken care of. Oh and the teachers in the nursery are fantastic and really connect with and care about each of the children

name: The American Academy for Young Professionals Gr. 6 12

review.author: Nyla F.
review.description: This gym has my heart. I love all the people here. The coaches are all loving and help you reach your goals and objectives of the most important things to do in the future. The all-stars are great and the girls are so sweet and supportive of each other. The coach Karlie Knight is awesome and hardworking with us girls and we're so lucky to have her she's the best.

review.author: Robert T.
review.description: I do not recommend this school, it was a completely waste of money. Parents save your money. Kids love this school because instead of learning they are playing, but not just any playing a complex playing.

review.author: sandra S.
review.description: Our experience at Wheeler has been consistently excellent over the past twelve years with our two kids now in middle and high school. We highly recommend Wheeler for any family looking for amazing education that teaches kids how to think and learn. Wheeler's teachers and administrators are best in class. They are dynamic, creative, and work hard to provide the most engaging curriculum.

review.author: Connor C.
review.description:
This school is really a great school.

Their Arts and Theater departments are amazing! I have visited and all I saw was amazing things. From the outside the school looks like a fortress. That's how it was built. Buildings surrounding a Main Courtyard that connects the whole school.

They also have a "Farm" in Seekonk, MA that really adds something different about the school. It is 128 acres. They also have a School Radio that adds a different thing to the school.

review.author: Cathy Z.
review.description: Dew Claw Studios is truly a Rhode Island gem! John and Kris are such kind, welcoming people that make ceramics accessible to all skill levels! The classes are relatively affordable and generally filled with diverse groups of people. Whether you're looking to hand build or throw pots on a wheel, Dew Claw Studios is a great pottery studio!

review.author: Beth C.
review.description:
A bad place for beginners. The owner is extremely nice and affable, but his inability to actually instruct (particularly for the price of these classes!) is absurd. I initially signed up for a hand-building class and noted that the instructor seemed to enjoy socializing with studio "regulars" more than spending a lot of time truly instructing. Indeed, one day the entire class (instructor included) spent the ENTIRE class talking and no lesson was provided at all. This was of course bothersome, but something that I could work through since hand-building can be fairly intuitive/self-taught. Also, I was motivated to learn and this is practically the only studio in the area that offers these courses. 

However, I then signed up for a pottery wheel course, at which point the cracks began to truly show in terms of the instructor's limitations in the teaching arena. Certainly, the pottery wheel definitely requires a LOT of practice in order to become proficient. But if the majority of your class can't even CENTER a pot--the foundation of pottery wheel work-- by the 4th or 5th lesson (and are being taught by a few of the other class members who have somehow caught on), that truly indicates there's a problem. 

I attended several open studio sessions in an attempt to hone my skills prior to additional lessons, but again, the instructor would spend the entire time socializing with others working in the studio. You felt as though you were dragging him away from his chit-chat with studio regulars in order to get instruction that you were paying him for. Two studio regulars sitting beside me at my first open studio session finally took pity on me and taught me how to center, which is certainly not their job. But there you are. 

I stuck out the wheel course for perhaps 5 sessions, in the meanwhile the majority of other students in my section stopped attending. I finally joined them, as I could certainly think of better things to do on my day off than try to wrangle a pottery wheel with little-to-no instruction.

I imagine Dew Claw is a fantastic place for those with a background in pottery who are looking to build on their skill-set. But whether they realize it or not, this studio is truly taking advantage of new students who pay a reasonable amount of money and spend a large amount of their time for little return.

review.author: Kimberlee D.
review.description: Last night should have been my last pottery class of the seven week Beginner Wheel session that I signed up for, however I quit after three classes and here is why:  When I arrived to the first class I was greeted by Kris who informed me that I needed to purchase clay and tools = $65. Somehow I missed that memo when signing up.  John, the instructor,  came out after eating his grilled cheese sandwich, to begin class. We met the dog Cheesy and then class began. The first class was fun - as we learned the basics and it was exciting to "throw" clay and feel it on the wheel. The second class started 25 minutes late because John was throwing the ball to Cheesy. I felt very frustrated when I left that night because there were lots of details about prior students that really didn't add much to my pottery lesson.  My third and final class thankfully started on time (3pm) however he demonstrated how to make a bowl and how to trim until 4:40 which  leaves 20 minutes for me to try and do the same. No way is that happening, as I am a total pottery virgin! At one point John fell asleep at his wheel in mid sentence.  I guess this is common. And then, after his demo that lasted almost the entire time (could be all the random stories) he went into the garage to find a tool and did not return. I was STRUGGLING big time. Another student with more experience stopped what he was doing and tried to help me. I felt like this should have been John helping me because that who is getting paid to teach this class. I was so frustrated that I cleaned up my wheel station and left. John was still in the garage. I told him I felt frustrated and was leaving - he did not seem concerned at all and simply said "bye".  I realized that this may not be a good fit for me. I called the studio in hopes to talk to John and explain how I was feeling. I left a voice mail and did not get a return call. I emailed also. Kris responded and said John was out of town and would get back to me by Tuesday ( the day before our next class). I never heard from him. I decided that this class is not a good fit for me. I asked for a partial refund. It was denied. I saved up for this class all summer so I am pretty disappointed I ended up throwing my money way instead of learning how to throw pots. I did ask that they donate my clay and tools to the nice guy and his family that were in class with me so hopefully they were able to use it.  I think John and Kris are nice people but this studio experience is not recommended for a beginner. I wish I had taken the time to read all of the previous reviews because it seems someone else had a similar experience.  I am planning to save up and try another studio that is more structured.

review.author: Kristopher G.
review.description: I love this place! Everyone is so helpful and I have fun and made new friends of all ages and experience levels. If you don't know something just ask anyone.  If you see something awesome and you want to try it just ask. I find its great stress relief and with our pot luck today I really got to know some people.  I'm only eight or ten weeks in now and haven't looked back. If you're an artist with laser focus or someone that wants to be social this is the place! We also have two awesome dogs that add to the atmosphere. Cheesy and butter ( I guess they like dairy products ) which is great for a dog lover like me. They are not around all the time but really helpful and supportive people are. I am the LEAST artistic person but they helped me make cool stuff. I am happy this place is within walking distance to my house! Give it a try. You won't regret it.

review.author: Alma C.
review.description: helpful encouraging instruction for the beginning wheel throwing class i took. it does take some time to get your work glazed since they try to be economical about firing up the kilns, but they also won't slam the door in your face either after your session's classes are done, giving a clumsy potter such as me time time to finish up half worked on pots. i'll probably book some time for privates in the future.

review.author: Loretta F.
review.description: I really enjoyed my classes last year at Dew Claw. John was very encouraging and it was a very laid back atmosphere. My only issue was a big one - it took forever to get anything the class members made bisqued and glazed. If you set something up to be put in the kiln one week it sometimes took 3 weeks or more to get back, then it took weeks more to get back after it was glazed. One woman I took the class with went back week after week once the class was over and was told "it will be back as soon as possible". Not great considering these classes run over $200! I'll try another studio next time.

review.author: Steven S.
review.description: Terrific school. Great principal and staff. They keep the younger children separated from the older ones.

review.author: Mary H.
review.description: This place is a beauty bargain for anyone who wants esthetics services at very affordable prices. The students are eager to perfect their technique and skills. The teacher was right there watching the entire time. I made an appointment for an Anti-Aging Firming Facial and was pleasantly greeted by Ariana. She performed the multi step treatment with precision. The only difference between this school and my former beauticians salon was the price. I am pleasantly surprised at the quality of service I received and can't wait to make my next appointment.

review.author: Lisa N.
review.description: I called for appointment and was able to get one same day! Sophia cut and styled my hair to perfection! Very reasonable prices excellent service. I highly recommend.

review.author: Ann M.
review.description: I recently had a facial at Empire Beauty School with Dani. For 25$ I wasn't expecting much but was pleasantly surprised!  It was a very relaxing and thorough facial ( lasted just over an hour).  Dani had a very soothing sense of touch and I loved the facial massage and pleasant fragrance of the products Dani used.  I would definitely recommend Dani and will return for future facials.

review.author: Tannie C.
review.description: I love empire beauty school.  the teacher's are the best everyone there is down to earth. \nI'm so happy to be a student at empire love it XOXO

review.author: Maria R.
review.description:
Listen to this. As this is the most sneaky, embarrassing  pathetic attempt at hiding all the terrible traits, habits, behavior/lack of professionalism from the educators at this school. When you come here for a service the "educator" (black lady with short hair) practically tries to force clients into reviewing the school and the service WHILE you are in there in order to try to make you feel bad into writing a good review. How unprofessional is that? I was appalled.  She basically told me I had to write a review NOW while I was getting a pedicure. Why? What if I didn't want to? What if I didn't want to leave my bad yet honest review right there and then while all the salon was looking at me and still performing a service? 

I originally wanted to go to school here but after my visit with them a week ago I changed my mind. One of the educators here (I didn't catch her name but she is black and has short hair) was giving a student completely inaccurate information on how to apply a product to a clients hair. I was so shocked. She walked around the students saying stupid things that were incorrect. Outdated lady needs to go back to school herself. 

She was also very rude and whined a lot instead of teaching with a polite assertive manner she would whine and complain. Real classless lady. She really rubbed me the wrong way as being very mean, catty, almost evil natured. She gives me the creeps. 

If I owned this school I would fire her and replace her with literally ANYONE else as I'm sure a random stranger plucked from a group of people would know more about hair dressing than she does. I really never write reviews. But this has been eating at me for an entire week. Lady, if you're reading this... seek help.

review.author: Kayla M.
review.description: I am currently attending  school and it has been an amazing adventure.. along with covid making thing difficult.... they have \n made everything  work out great!!!!

review.author: Cesarina S.
review.description: I enjoy my education at Empire so Much. Highly recommend going to this school. I learned so much during my time at Empire. It inspired me to pursue a passion in nails and become a nail tech. I am so happy that I came to this school.

review.author: Seleny M.
review.description: Ms. Maureen is the best teacher ever! She is so nice. She's the type of teacher that will be honest with you about everything no matter what it is. I am a visual learner and Ms. Maureen has helped me with that. She always makes sure her students learn the Mods correctly. There's no better teacher than Ms. Maureen!

review.author: Rose M.
review.description: It is unprofessional to use your educators position as a power trip and to put others down because you yourself believe to be above everyone else around you. Its sad to say they cant give the students a chance let alone tell them that they dont have one. Its unfortunate that people who are  asumed to be looked upon as role models have disgraced not only themselves but the place in which they are licensed to work. Empire Beauty School should reevaluate the individuals they put in place to be "licensed educators" to these young adults who will be the future of this field for as long as it lasts. Judging by the attrition rate due to uncalled for degrading disagreements and disputes they wont last long. Any teacher who doubts their pupils are the true failures.\n\nEmpire Beauty School Wariwck RI

review.author: Kat R.
review.description: I hate leaving negative reviews, but these guys can really use the feedback.  I booked an appointment for a perm.  The girl on the phone seemed distracted, but managed to confirm my appointment date and time.  I showed up only to find out I'm nowhere on the schedule and the girl I booked the appointment with is already booked for that time.  The person I was talking to was rude and didn't even offer an apology.  They did offer to take me and just have the student work on both of us (which is very possible when there's a perm and a hair coloring going at the same time).  Plenty of downtime to focus on the other client.  After waiting for half an hour, nobody came to get me or to ask me whether I'm all set.  I just left. The sad thing is they probably didn't even notice.\n\nThey need to really work on customer service and logistics; clearly, not all know how to book appointments.  Would not recommend coming here.

review.author: Sheila M.
review.description:
Before they moved to Providence from Warwick I'd have given them a 5.
Had been going here for over 15 years. Never a bad experience. 
The last 3 appointments have been a disaster. 
First week they moved I had an appointment. Waited over an hour because students didn't show up. Couldn't get everything done in time left.
Two weeks ago I called before I made the drive. Again short handed. They rescheduled for tonight at 5:30.
I have a wedding out of town this weekend. 
I have been sitting here for 45 minutes. No  student to take my appointment. 
There seems to be no accountability.
As a courtesy they could give you a call to let you know no one is here. 
I drove an hour to get here and now have to find someone to color my hair tomorrow before my flight.
There is also NO PARKING despite them saying there is.
I won't be back.
Management needs to be on top of this.
I was just told "it is a school".
If you are training students to be professionals they need to be accountable for showing up.

review.author: Heather D.
review.description: No matter when you the Glen Burnie Md location, they are never taking any additional clients for the day. Tgen you hear students complaining they can never get hours WTH!

review.author: Annamarie T.
review.description:
So I can not rate the school itself, but did stop in for a hair cut the other day and they did an awesome job!

I always pass Empire and finally stopped in and was not disappointed. For $5 I was able to get a great haircut including washing, cutting, a blowout and flat iron straight! If that is not a deal I don't know what is. The service was great too the girls at the front desk were nice and so was the person that gave me a haircut.

This isn't only a womans saloon, they also do men and children too. They also have other services such as manicures and waxing. Def someplace worth checking out.

review.author: Miranda M.
review.description:
Definitely a great place to go if you want your hair and nails done for super cheap! Just a warning... you do get what you pay for. The service is good, but it's not great. But these are students, and that's to be expected. 

One problem I did have that I wasn't happy about was that the pedicure description online and in the store says "foot and leg massage," yet I didn't receive that or even lotion. I didn't get lotion/a hand massage during my pedicure either. 

Also, you should be prepared to be turned away during the walk-in hours. You can make appointments for 10am and 2pm and walk-ins are between 11am-1pm. I went in today for a walk-in at noon and I was turned away and told to come back another day. 

In the end, it's still worth it though because the prices are DIRT CHEAP.

review.author: Ashlee S.
review.description:
If you're a potential student, please run. 
My mother talked me into going here, due to it being cheapest and close by.
Personally, my education was TERRIBLE. 
I graduated feeling like I knew nothing. 
If you failed a test (I failed one) you could retake the SAME EXACT test over and over till you passed.
They also told you every question on the test a few days in advance, you looked up the answers and that was your study guide. Are you kidding me? 
We learned 3 weeks of cutting, a new cut every day, you don't learn the angles and their results. 
So if someone wants something that goes against "the norm" good luck creating it. 
By the time I left I only knew a straight "blunt" cut, long and short layers. 
Want a bob? Nope, sorry.
Want something edgy? Maybe even Miley-ish? Nope, sorry. 
Want a fringed angle to you face? Oh sorry that's also out of the question too.

We had students who wouldn't do projects and passed right along side the hard workers.
The only thing they cared about was you were there for them to get your money. 
Show up, you'll pass. 
Go nap in the lunch room, as long as you're there and they are getting money, they don't care how well you do.

We never did real relaxers because they didn't want to waste product. 
They taught us Keratin but didn't give us a certificate, which is required to purchase the products. 
The best scumbag mover, they don't let students formulate color. You're not even allowed to measure it. 
Apparently, this is a Warwick Campus thing, it's been a few years since I've graduated so hopefully this has changed. 
The director when I went said "students are wasteful and disrespectful" 
So for color, we would get our teacher, they would consult and then bring us a bowl of color. Leaving me wondering what and why those were picked for this particular client. 

Wanna hear about our kits? 
Hahaha. All my butterfly clips they charged $9 for broke in week one. 
My blow dryer, caught on fire. 
They don't give you a flat iron because you need to learn how to create styles using a blow dryer and not rely on the iron. 
Their curling iron, I must say was really good. 
The scissors they charge $300 for, are probably at best $50 quality.
5 mannequins is also pretty good, but they along with everything else is grossly overpriced.

When you sign up they tell you "other than things like pens and paper you won't need a thing, your kit includes it all." Yeah, lies we were forced to spend money most of us part time workers didn't have, pretty regularly for projects, or new clips, new brushes 'cause theirs are a joke, extensions for lessons, supplies for nail art that they don't even teach.

You're supposed to be able to get state board preparation, but because they overbook students my senior class got stuck in the Junior class for about 2-3 months over due. 
By the time we got to move up to the class where they teach state board practice, it was almost time to graduate. 
They also forced students in the classroom out on to the floor, and they came for seniors first because you have more education and according to them can miss more. We would be in the middle of learning something (which probably wouldn't do much for us anyways) and the receptionist would come in and say "I need 5 girls" and we would be forced to miss instructional hours to work on clients probably doing things unbenificial to us like a nifty roller set. 
They had a asinine policy where clients cannot wait over 10 minutes. Uhm? Have you never walked into a Salon to be told "sorry there isn't an opening for a half hour." If you don't want to wait, be smart and make an appointment. 
I think this rule was less about customer service, and more about making money.

As for a state boards, the teachers are the ones who grade you, again they pass anyone and everyone. It keeps the schools statistics up. I will tell you first hand, I probably should of failed 75% of it. I didn't meet the times on anything other than nails, cut and make up. I passed with a grade in the high 80's. 
I'm grateful that even with my horrible education I did obtain a license, because it can open doors and is a great benefit. I can also continue my education at my own pace at professional classes, however I'd trade my easily obtained license, for a solid education any day, even if it meant struggling. Because as of now I have so many holes in my education, it's going to take a while to become useful.
I am going to check out Tony And Guy. I went for services and was amazed. I think I may go for half the time, relearn basics like cutting and coloring, and continue on to do what I love. 
Please don't fall victim to this school. Look at your options, read read and read reviews. I rushed into my decision blindly, out of excitement. 
Twenty thousand dollars, is a lot of money to waste for nothing, so is 1,500 hours of your life. 
Good luck to future stylists I truly wish you all the best!

review.author: Dora P.
review.description:
I'm currently a cosmetology student at Arthur Angelo an EMPIRE SCHOOL in Rhode Island.  I'm am discouraged and shocked at the what they call an education.
First there is no a structured curriculum . One day we are doing hair cutting, the next braids, the next pin curls and in the next breath we are having a test on waxing which we've never done. When I first started, we were told we weren't allowed to use any salon product on our mannequin because it was a waste for students and cost the company money, so we used water for everything. 
The school is open enrollment. They accept everyone that comes through the door. Majority of the girls  there don't take this seriously and are only there because their welfare counselor told them "this" was a good idea. They're always late if they show up at all and disrupt the "class" any chance they can get.
Once (while teaching pedicures) the school refused to allow us to wear the pedicure slippers and told us to tape paper towels on the bottom of our feet. I refused and took a pictures of this horror. The teachers don't want to be there and talk down to the students.
We were never taught how to properly curl or blow dry hair. We still burn the hair(I've been there 10 weeks)
The theory is a joke. I get good grades. When we have test, The girls that fail are allowed to retake the test right after they've failed it and the new grade which is higher than mine is kept while their failing grade is dis guarded. I'm not allowed to retake the test because I passed the first time.
This is a reminder you get exactly what you pay for. This school is the cheapest in the state. They said everything I wanted to hear in order to get me to enroll. I'm currently working on attending a school that takes education seriously. I can no longer attended a school that has no interest in producing hair stylists, partakes in unethical practices and could care less if we learn anything at all .
GO TO TONI AND GUY better education.

review.author: Melissa R.
review.description: This school is an embarrassment, they treat their students poorly. I graduated feeling I knew nothing. The esthetics program is a joke! No makeup was taught to us and everytime we would complain their excuse was, "they are only there to teach the basics" (which we didn't even get that) we would complain to corporate as a group which just made all the teachers including the director hate us and treat us even more poorly. Total waste of money, we learned nothing and hardly did any hands-on because they were to cheap and said it was a waste of product. Majority was learning through a book. They would over lap classes, which means before your program is done they are starting another program, they move you to another room where you sit and do nothing all day. They tell you to study for your stare exam, but it was just busy work so they could teach the new class. We had so many substitutes and half of them wouldn't know any answers to our questions. Iv had to take so much continuing education after this, Total rip off!

review.author: Potato Sala D.
review.description:
If you are serious about cosmetology AVOID THIS SCHOOL AT ALL COSTS. This is what corporate education is all about. PROFIT. This school, (not just prov but all Empire schools), only care about profit. Their curriculum makes NO SENSE. Why on earth would you spend one week on hair cutting but FIVE WEEKS on relaxer?..they would have us doing hair cutting and the next week we would do hair dye so your maniquinn had no hair left on it to dye cuz you cut it all...on the week we did makeup, they didn't teach us anything, they had us partner up and do our partners makeup with really cheap horrible make up that they let everyone use which is unsanitary. when we did facials, they had us laying on two chairs, which is unsafe and uncomfortable....when we did hair dyeing (one week which is not enough time to learn a skill like that) they had a plastic bin full of expired hair dyes, mostly empty, all one blonde shade and weird copper shades no one wanted to use. It's very hard to be creative with hair color when you only have 11ash and 7 copper red to work with. The students there are mostly ignorant welfare scum...they interrupt the class so that the teacher runs out of time and you never accomplish anything.  there are really only a handful of serious students who will go somewhere some day, but mostly that school is churning out employees for Best Cuts or Fantastic Sam;s....

Basically their curriculum is ...teach the students JUST ENOUGH to pass state boards and then send them packing....30,000 dollars and a year later...you're working at Best cuts making 9.50 an hour. Not worth it...I quit, and if I go back to beauty school I'm going to Tony and Guy or Paul Mitchell.

i was enrolled in 2009, my tuition was 16,000 dollars, every month they tuition rate goes up. There are girls who enrolled after me who's tuition cost them nearly 30,000 dollars!! I can only imagine what it is now, 4 years later....geez....

review.author: Angel M.
review.description: i love going here do how cheap is to got a hair cut if you don't mind Lerners  working on your hair and good location

review.author: Natasha C.
review.description: where to begin. I actually looked into going to this school, but there customer service is a turn off. The first time I went i went pretty short and was so scared because I dont like letting ppl cute my hair short. The girl cutting my hair didnt do to bad until i straightened it and realized how horrible it looked, i went back and the teacher said she will have another student fix it while straight. the student was sweet and taking her time to fix it and was going over it with the straightner since she sprayed my head with a water bottle. A teacher came by and asked her "what are you doing, you need to hurry up and finish and take more customers." then looks at me and says " i wasnt going to charge you and now i have to" which i do not believe her whatsoever. and then just walked away. both the student and I felt very awkward and i told her to just stop, ill finish at home. I decided to give it another chance to go get my hair blow dried. my sister gave me a name of a student that was really good, so i made an appt with her in the am. when i called to let them know i was 5 min late, they tell me she left for the day!  so i cancelled and went to Paul Mitchell (and the girl did a great job at my hair) just yesterday my other sister needed a blowout and manicure so she goes, find out the girl scheduled to do her hair never showed up, she waited forever to be seen, a random girl who was being guided the whole time just to trim her hair and the blow out was horrible, she ended up having to fix her hair when she got home and had to rush out to get to work because she ran out of time for the mani. i know its a school but customer service is so important

review.author: Jolene R.
review.description: My son is currently a student here. It is one of the only locations that is close to our house and work on the west side. This makes it convent for all members of our family me, dad and grandma to pick up/drop off. The teachers are amazing however they seem a bit over worked and seems under staffed. I can't tell you the numerous times my child has been bitten by other students. I am sure you are thinking "why don't they pull him out?" Easier said than done currently on several waiting lists for other schools and to be honest my son seems to love it here and his teacher are amazing. I would say it is a little overprice for the toddler programs as there are other facility's inside private schools cheaper than this place.  They do however provide all meals and snacks.  They do go by their stand at giving quality care to their kids however it seems to be at a cost to other children, those who don't fight back. Not to mention my child is now picking up bad habits of biting, kicking and not listening due to other students. But as always a trade off for daycare.

review.author: Kim C.
review.description:
I transferred here to work on my bachelors degree. I was a commuter like most of the study body here. It's a big campus on top of a hill with multiple buildings. I decided to go here because it's affordable; parents aren't rich enough to pay for my tuition and I wasn't the smartest to get a scholarship lol.  

I enjoyed my experience here except like most people mentioned, there wasn't much of a college life. I worked full time and went to school full time so my time was limited to hang around anyway. Although, I didn't get the college experience, I still felt like I got a good education. I switched majors a couple of times but ended up with one I loved and my advisor, professor, and head of the department was awesome. He guided me in the right direction and was an easy going person. 

I took night classes for the most part; I've had classes until 10 pm. The scheduling was decent for working students. The website was outdated but it got the job done. I was able to pay my bills, schedule courses, and access my grades/transcript.

Downfalls, parking was always a nightmare; I would park what felt like miles from the building. Imagine walking alone at night and in the winter! I always felt safe but just be aware of your surroundings and bundle up in the winter. The buildings were old but it got the job done. Classes averaged about 25-30 students. Professors were helpful, friendly, and smart; I've had some really strict ones.

Overall, if you're on a budget and want a good education, I recommend going here. Now I'm going back to graduate school and look forward to doing everything online! Those days of going to campus are over. I would definitely send my future children here. (If I still lived in RI).

review.author: Gail A.
review.description: This is a very supportive environment. Happy to be learning and sharing about moving STEAM education forward at Rhode Island College STEAM Conference. Mr. Khurram Hassan, of Advantage Consulting speaking.

review.author: Mandy D.
review.description:
Hey look, I'm still here! I will finally be graduating in May after 2 years full-time and 5 years part-time. I've seen a lot since I've been here so long.

My previous review still stands, but I've also uncovered a lot more awful things about this place, hence the demotion to two stars.

The food is horrendous. Awful. Inedible. They force every student to pay a fee for the dining center every semester. On top of that, you either have to buy a meal plan or pay for the food. Both options are severely overpriced. The dining center has way too many administrators and state employees to pay, so they seriously cut corners with the food.

Buildings are falling apart. They did just get some state money to do renovations, but because this is a state institution it's going to take years before anything actually happens. Yeah, and you look down the road at PC and watch an entire building go up in less than 6 months...

The state unions here do nothing but protect the people who suck at their jobs. If you're ever trying to get anything important done with your academic records, expect it to be a huge project because nobody cares about you and nobody wants to do any work. 

SO MANY professors here need to retire, especially in computer science. They're teaching outdated software and skills that you will never ever use. 

This college gears toward working-class families, yet offers hardly any night classes. Balancing work and school is a major struggle as it is, and this place makes it harder. That ONE class you NEED will always be offered in one section at 2pm on Monday and Wednesday so you'll never be able to have a normal 9-5 day job and get a degree from here. If you can manage to get a decent job on campus, you may have better luck with the work/school balance, but they're not easy to come across since everybody wants one. 

New Hall is beautiful, but the rest of the dorms are gross. The two years that I lived on campus were awful and I was sick all the time from the mold and dust buildup. 

Nice things: BEAUTIFUL, awesome new rec center with free aerobics classes and a pool. Active, involved student media orgs that put out a great newspaper, radio broadcast, and TV station. Student Government that tries really hard to fix stuff, even though they are small in numbers. Lots of free help on campus such as tutoring, counseling, and career advisement. Some really awesome professors that go out of their way to see you succeed.

review.author: Barry N.
review.description:
I had a great time at this school. It took me a while and some going part-time to finish up, but I have to say I was satisfied overall.

My major was HR and there were only two faculty. This can sound like a setup for disaster, but these two faculty members deserve every accolade they receive. Dr. Shani Carter and Dr. Randy DeSimone are two professors I remember fondly, even all these years later.

I minored in Mathematics and the faculty there were hit-or-miss. I specifically recall Dr. Humphreys being adept at illustrating complicated math problems graphically, which was very helpful.

I was a highly involved student and in general, my experience with being involved with student organizations was a positive one.

The food was mediocre, but I don't care. It was college. I didn't expect gourmet meals from a school with no culinary program.

My on-campus job was great.

Scheduling of classes always worked out favorably, because even in the few times they didn't fit, the school made accommodations to help my class graduate. It was just a matter of asking!

It's a little too easy for students to ascend to power in the student organization scene, which leads to a lot of in-fighting and politicking. It's about what you'd expect, but it's sitcom-levels of anxiety just to run a club. Very little actually gets done in this regard. You'd expect a high turnover in student leaders, but financial incentives are attached to managing some clubs. If you're popular and conniving enough, you can leverage enough positions to squat in college while financially accruing enough money to justify it.

review.author: Nicholas S.
review.description: I'm giving this college one star just because of how rude they allow some of there staff to be to the college students. In particular the over weight lady that works at the financial aid office. It's just not a comfortable or welcoming place for me. I'm a respectable adult who makes much more than there office staff already, yet when you go in there they treat you like a third world citizen,  applying for a visa. I literally will not be going there because of this, and the fact that they pretty much only have parking for faculty. #Students lives matter. We're your only customers.

review.author: Allison R.
review.description: For it's price, RIC does what it needs to do. I transferred in after 2 years of design school and decided to jump into the management program. I demanded an adviser before they were mandatory and relied on her to help me pick out some courses. \n\nTook 3 years of my nose to the grindstone but I got out with my BS on the Dean's list and Magna Cum Laude. I now work at a fantastic company who didn't blink an eye that I went to the cheapest option available. Many co workers look down on me for not having a name brand education, but hey, I have the same job/career as them, so why does it matter?

review.author: Samantha R.
review.description: The programs available at RIC are great. However, the staff working for the school are extremely unprofessional and rude. As a student we  are paying thousands of dollars to better ourselves and I don't think it's right to be the talked to the way I have by multiple departments. Very disappointing and by talking to other people I know I'm not the only one who deals with these issues.

review.author: Kimberly A.
review.description: Both my sons attend this school and although it's not fancy the education is top notch. It's local. Clean and the staff is caring of all their students. I have a senior and a freshman and I like the dorms they are welcoming . Both sons have no complaints. One of my sons does a sport and he enjoys it. My other son does Intermural's and fully enjoys his experiences at RIC.

review.author: Wendy B.
review.description: Excellent place with small class sizes, supportive faculty and a great learning environment!

review.author: Sarah M.
review.description: I attended this college from 2005-my graduation in 2009. Since then, I went on to Curry College for my Paralegal certificate, and will be continuing on for my MBA in 2018. RIC is a nice school for your "foundation." Low cost, close to home, and I had mostly great professors. They earned a massive grant a few years after I graduated, which was used for beautification/revitalization of the school's buildings, grounds, and parking lots. It looks like a whole new place now! I gave 4 stars instead of 5 because the dining hall (Donovan) is disgusting. The food is barely edible and many of the items are expired. Look far enough into The Anchor's (student run newspaper) archives and you'll see the article I wrote on that very topic. When I attended RIC, most of the buildings were in disrepair, but I was raised in a poor MA city so I was used to it. I found it easy to make friends, both inside and outside the classroom. There's not much to do on campus if you're looking for structured events- but you're only a stones throw from Providence Place Mall, PPAC, Trinity Rep, and some of Providence's waterfront clubs/pubs. It's a decent deal for the good quality education. I was able to graduate in 4 years while holding an on campus job. I lived in the dorm the first 3 years and rented an apartment my senior year. I never had a car on campus and - if you land an on-campus job in one of the offices like I did -- you really don't need one. There's a RIPTA shuttle with a RIC stop, so you can still get around the city. It's not perfect, but it's not terrible, either. I made some lifelong friends, a boyfriend, and some essential progress from childhood to adulthood there. If you're contemplating attending RIC, do it. I highly recommend it, as you'll get exposure to many great people while learning quite a bit (from textbooks and life). Did I mention how RIC is also close to India Point?!

review.author: Yeri M.
review.description: RIC is a good school. Like others have mentioned, it's nothing fancy, but the teachers seem to be great so far and I feel like I am actually learning, not just memorizing. The campus is practical. The whole admissions thing can be a nightmare, specially since they use 'the common app'. You might end up having to hi to the admissions department a few times, but they are helpful. Once all of that us taken care of, it's smooth sailing. The tuition is a bargain for instate. They also have regional tuition for folks living in neighboring states. They have a very solid film department, so it's definitely worth a check out!

review.author: Sushi X.
review.description:
Wow, where do I start? This is the worst university I've ever attended. (Because I've moved around the country a lot I've been through five colleges). 

There is no life on campus whatsoever. The place feels completely dead. Very closed off feeling. The professors are hit or miss. I've encountered amazing professors here right along complete shitheads who need to retire. 

The school is falling apart building wise. I've been in class and sections of ceiling tile have fallen onto desks leaking roof water everywhere. 

Rhode Island College is also fairly homophobic as it goes. Inside the restrooms hate writings can be seen in the stalls, walls, etc. The pride flag was ripped down. A lot of RI trash can be heard spouting off hate. Administration does little to stop these problems. 

The food here? Oh boy don't even get me started. If you're a vegetarian you better bring your own food here. Or you'll fatten up on cheese pizza (nasty cheese pizza BTW). 

A lot of petty academic work, even in the higher level classes. So many professors are just not engaging enough.

The student population is here because they have to. Or have nothing else to do. That feeling oozes from just about everyone who attends this school.

review.author: Monika N.
review.description:
Well, it's RIC. What else can I say. I studied Psychology and Mental Health Counseling here and I can't complain about the program or the education I received. The professors were all experienced and knowledgable, the classroom sizes were reasonable and varied from 11 to lecture halls, and I felt I was able to balance work, personal, and school life. The admin kinda has their head up their ass when it comes to tracking credits, managing your finances, etc, so just keep a copy of everything in case they misplace credits you've already taken or drop you from all your classes because somewhere it didn't record your payment.
Parking is absolutely ridiculous. For a commuter school it's a battle every single day to find a spot even remotely near your class, and I've had to walk across campus in snow and rain to get to a class, run in some cases in order to not be late. 
I never lived here so I'm not sure about student life on campus, but friends of mine lived here and the dorms are standard issue and there does seem to be activities to keep students occupied. 
The food is pretty decent at the cafeteria, with vegan and gluten-free options which is very cool. 
There's a cafe with decent coffee and pastries, good pizza, so-so sandwiches. 
Can't think of much else to say. For the money (tuition is amazingly inexpensive compared to URI or other colleges) you get a hell of an education. Headaches and hassles with systems and parking.

review.author: A B.
review.description:
RIC is decent state school. Nothing fancy or outstanding (well, many instructors are) but does its job. It is known for its teaching and social work programs. It is also good way to get BS/BA for low tuition and move on to graduate studies.
        Campus is ok, some buildings are ugly but others are new and cute. It is also not very social or party school and if those features are really important to you don't go here. This school has more cozy and quite environment and yes, many people like it. People are in general friendly. Student body is very diverse- have seen adults in their 50s, weird students, cool students, some are motivated and smart and some are behaving like they are in high school. 
      The reason I gave four stars is instructors in this school. I have had many great and even outstanding professors here. With such faculty, RIC in my opinion has great potential to become much more than your average school. 
      Unfortunately, here is no social life. It is very important for school to have parties, social events etc, it brings students together, builds community and rises student spirit. RIC is lacking that and administration does very little to make situation better. RIC would be great school if it had more social involvement.
       School in general is evolving and progressing and depending on what to study here it can be good or not so good experience.

review.author: Gordon B.
review.description: Great concert by Frederic Chiu. The selected Chopin Etudes demonstrated "groundbreaking" (for Chopin's time) uses of the piano, and the Liszt arrangement of Beethoven's Symphony no. 5 was breathtaking.\n\nCan't wait for him to appear at the Newport Music Festival this July

review.author: Lorin K.
review.description:
When you have been here as long as I have, you feel like you might need to write a review. I am finishing up after first arriving in 2007. I am leaving after one more summer course with my Master of Arts in psychology. 

People have criticized the leaking roof, terrible food and lack of "campus life" due to it being a commuter school. I would agree with all of those things, and I would include I failed to ever get my club idea off the ground because anybody who was interested worked too much or couldn't sign up in conscience knowing they would miss all of the meetings. So with all of these problems, why I am not giving it one star? I am giving it a solid +1 for good people, and another for academic quality. I have met some truly wonderful people here, and due to being a regular fixture in the psych department for more than half a decade, I have become quite friendly with all of the professors. I was a teaching assistant as a graduate student, and my lab students were truly great. 
In terms of what I learned, I couldn't have asked for more. When applying for PhD programs, I have had a lot of difficulty. I think it is because the people judging apps haven't heard of RIC, or probably think we graduate a bunch of dunces. This elitist mindset is troubling to me. I have come out of RIC prepared to deal with the rigor and intensity of any graduate program. I know this because I have friends in doctoral programs at Brown and Yale that would validate my claim. I'm not just gloating here, I am saying that Rhode Island College, on a purely academic level, has some of the best professors that actually care about you, that any other school could boast. Just stay away from the cafeteria.

name: Rhode Island School Of Design Library

review.author: Honore F.
review.description:
I feel so blessed to be kissin' on someone who works for RISD and it kind enough to max out his card with me. I mean, I don't know what the limit is actually. I just know that each time I enter the building I hold my breath and touch those amazing ornate doors that are just background to the hallway where students eat cafeteria food. 
     As one would guess, this library is amazingly curated. I am a huge Maurice Sendak fan and I found  copies of works by him that I didn't know existed. Like the first translated version of a famous Czechoslovakian fairy tale that he illustrated. 
   I always grab a comic too. They have two sections, one for typically sized comics and one for over sized comic books.  
    Also, the student work they showcase is always interesting. 

As a bibliophile I feel genuinely lucky to have this library in my home state. And I'll totally marry someone who has tenure there so I can sneakily read their books till they die.

review.author: Jess P.
review.description: If you're not a lucky RISD or Brown student (or friends with one), you can get in before 5 PM with a student ID for another MA or RI academic institution.\n\nPlenty of spaces to work in this beautiful building, good WiFi, and decently quiet. Be sure to check out the mini gallery at the front entrance for some cool student work!

review.author: Rachael J.
review.description: This library has a beautiful interior and study layout. If you are a fan of comics and graphic novels, the RISD library has a particularly large collection. \n\nAlso, in this building is the RISD archive, that holds both school and museum archival records and objects. Don't forget to check out the design materials library as well! Both are located on the second floor of the building.

review.author: Sohini R.
review.description: The Fleet Library is a gorgeous place to sit and read; visitors can sign in with public safety for entrance.  The library has a range of study spaces (carrels, small tables, open reading areas) and furniture types, plus views of the city and banking hall interior.  Our only complaint: needs more outlets.  There are enough but they are grouped together, and sometimes in non-central spots.\n\nThe clock is a piece worth seeing if you're walking by!

review.author: Susie G.
review.description: Such an inviting, functional and interesting space. Great collection, great reading areas, meeting areas, research nooks... One of my favorite spots on the RISD campus, and not just because I'm a bookworm.

review.author: Mckenzie G.
review.description: The RISD library is an interesting pairing of old and new, and it seems to work. The large spacious room is filled with decadent columns, archways and an ornate ceiling. The modern touches include new mac computers flanking either side of the check out desk and a raised study space in the center of the room with space like cubicles underneath.  Depending on whether you're in the mood for a cafe, cave, birds eye, or window view, there is a study space in this library for you. While I'm not a RISD student, thus don't check out any books, this library draws me in to browse, study, or write yelp reviews

review.author: Maddy M.
review.description:
My husband and I stumbled upon it while we were looking for a playschool for my son. We were looking for a shorter program, that would just allow for some socialization. The more we read about it though, the more it seemed like a wonderful place for our son. The calming atmosphere, and wonderful routine are things that our son took to immediately. He is a cautious little boy, and very wary of people and spaces, Angel Care has brought out the absolute best in him, and in turn, helped us learn as parents, as we can see first hand how he responds to the slightest changes made. The directness, Catherine Valenti has a remarkable understanding of children and their needs. He has developed so much confidence and his language skills are incredible. He sets his place every day, he shakes hands, he puts things away (within reason- he is a toddler after all!) and although he still will act out sometimes (toddler) he is able to vocalize his frustrations and we, as parents have learned to validate them and work through them alongside our son. You can see him being proud of himself and the work he has done, and it continues on at home.

One of my favorite aspects of Angel Care is that they go outside all year round, and spend lots of time outdoors having messy, muddy, glorious outdoor free time. Inside there is calm, order and routine, and outside lessons continue in a way that seems to be lost in many other places. There is a strawberry patch where my son picks and eats berries. This simple act is so meaningful, as he learns where they come from, how they form from flowers, and that he must wait until they are ripe to pick and eat them. Small life lessons in the fresh air lead to rosy cheeks and long afternoon naps! 

I simply cannot imagine a better place for my children's early education.

review.author: Ned D.
review.description: I'd heard about the challenges that Providence Schools are facing and looked for additional opportunities to help (in addition to our workplace options). Inspiring Minds had flexible programming that fit well with my work schedule and volunteer interests. Great program experience so far!

review.author: Anita N.
review.description: The opportunities afforded by Inspiring Minds is unmatched. The staff (shout-out to Melissa!) make it *so* easy to get out into the community and make a difference! If you've ever (even remotely) considered volunteering, Inspiring Minds will support you. The students and faculty in our local schools need (and sincerely appreciate!) volunteers. Even if you have only one hour per week to donate, I encourage you to reach out to IM. It will be the most rewarding thing you've ever done.

review.author: Alexander V.
review.description: Signed up to volunteer as an after school tutor and attended the afternoon workshop. The workshop went over time and was poorly planned. Most people were in transition and unemployed but I work full time and was inconvenienced. However I stayed the entire length of the training and then some after to get "registered". That was not included in the description they sent out which was a one on one basis and only two staffers going around between 15-20 people. I gave them my interests and time availability and was told they'd call up two references I put down. One of my references has to call back multiple times and was never successful in reaching them. Four weeks went on by and I never heard nor saw anything. Then I get an email asking if I was interested in the summer program. I was more annoyed that after four plus weeks I was contacted for a program I didn't even signed up for and nothing about what I signed up for. I was told that I'd be contacted next academic year since school was out already at this time. Now it is October and I have not heard anything from this group. I have wasted time attending a training workshop for something I clearly I will never be a part of. Furthermore, a personal reference has wasted his time trying to get a hold of the group. Clearly this group lacks respect for people's time and is poorly managed.

review.author: Owen R.
review.description:
Just passed thru some major universities..
Syracuse 
Yale 
And Brown.
Beautiful campuses 
Be so great to be rich, have a scholarship or be really smart!!!  I'm 0 for 3

review.author: Mollie W.
review.description: When traveling, I love to tour college/university campuses.  Brown is a beautiful university located in Providence.  The historic buildings are incredibly gorgeous.  The grounds are easy to get around and are full of trees and green spaces.

review.author: Chuck K.
review.description: I took a campus tour on a beautiful Saturday in November 2016 and enjoyed learning about the history of Brown University.  I like visiting Ivy League campuses but I felt there wasn't that much to see, although the big blue thingy is pretty impressive!

review.author: Sue D.
review.description:
Move-in Day
Simmons Quad was full of incoming students and staff. Very happening!

Beautiful campus. Close to many restaurant. If you are into Thai food, highly recommend Heng Thai, 2 min walk from Brown Bookstore.

Dorm Amenities: 4/5
See pics: microwave, refrigerator, bed, desk, chair and walk in closet.

My family and I enjoyed our experience of being here. My husband especially, he just loved the quaint feel of the campus. Lots of shaded areas to shield from the sun. That was a plus for him!

review.author: Dude K.
review.description:
In A Nutshell:

-Brown University located in Providence has an awesome campus/neighborhood.
-I really enjoyed walking around being surrounded by all the nature & historical buildings.
-The atmosphere was lively w/ plenty of students walking around w/ smiles.
-The location is close to the Brown Bookstore along w/ a plethora of shops, restaurants (some fine dining ones too like Persimmon & some ethnic ones like Aleppo Sweets).

Overall, if you have a chance to attend college here, I suggest you pay a visit & you'll fall in love w/ Brown.

review.author: Eric D.
review.description: This review is based purely on a visit to the city and walk through of the campus. I don't know enough about the school or politics of the school to make judgements one way or another. That said, what a beautiful campus with some seriously pretty buildings and an awesome and very quiet and peaceful quad. I love visiting colleges and especially Ivy league schools (Doing pretty well on my visit them all list) and Brown fits the bill. The main gate was super cool and from what I've seen the campus is pretty big but well laid out and beautiful throughout. Cool place loved the visit!

review.author: Vincent L.
review.description:
If I hadn't gone to a certain Ivy League school in New Hampshire, I'd have gone to Brown, if it weren't for the fact that it's only 35 minutes from my parents' home, while the school in New Hampshire is 2.5 hours away. Easy choice for the only kid of smothering Chinese-American parents.

Nevertheless, I retain a soft spot for Brown, and it's got many endearing qualities that are similar to those of the school I went to. First and foremost is its focus on undergraduate education. It's one of the smaller Ivies, with the lack of a large graduate student population being one of the differentiating factors. This means that professors must be able to teach - and teach well. As a result, the classroom atmosphere is often dynamic and intimate. Moreover, because there aren't that many graduate students helping professors with research, this provides undergraduates with tremendous opportunities to step up, pick up the slack, and partake in world-class research that they might not otherwise be able to tackle until the graduate level at other schools. Furthermore, the curriculum is quite flexible, with students doing whatever they wish.

Although the campus is quite compact, it blends in well with its historic Providence surroundings. Classrooms, study and research spaces, professors' offices, key amenities like convenience stores, and the entire city of Providence are all just a short walk away. 

These days, with Ivy admissions rates plunging into the single digits, I'd have a much harder time getting in here than I did twenty years ago. If I were a student offered admission here today, I'd definitely give Brown much consideration. Overall, a great occasion for my 1750th review!

review.author: Alexis B.
review.description: A friend and were visiting Providence and Newport for a weekend, and we decided we needed to at least briefly explore Brown's campus before we left Providence. It is a beautiful campus and exploring it is a reminder of the age of the university as well as the city! While it wasn't the highlight of our trip by any means, exploring Brown briefly was an interesting part of our trip, and I recommend it to anyone visiting Providence for the first time!

review.author: Megan C.
review.description:
Historical Institution // World Class
Beautiful Buildings // Arts Community

Came to visit a friend here. Had been to campus once before and to the RISD museum which was fantastic. Stopped by the gigantic sculpture of a blue teddy bear (must have been a nice tax credit) and watched a couple of kids who wanted nothing more than to be able to climb all over this untouchable toy. 

Had lunch down the street at a Korean restaurant.  The train is close to campus, easy to get around using uber as well.

The Scene: Historic, Smartie
Destination Rating: 8
Date Rating: N/A
Hob Nob Potential: 8

Strong Suggestion: Charge your battery, you'll want to take photos.

review.author: Shelley D.
review.description: And for my 500th review, one of my favorite places on this planet, my alma mater Brown University. What can I say except this is probably the best school that ever existed. You may think your school is cool but does your school have a class in hieroglyphics? Does it have a book bound in human skin? Does it not make you take gen ed classes because it values learning for the sake of learning? Or does your school let you take classes pass fail because you shouldn't feel the pressure of a grade when you're learning something new? My alma mater has that and more. It has over 100,000 beautiful memories for me during my four years and I've never been to a place which had more amazing people in my life. I was so lucky to call that university home and it will always hold a special place in my heart.

review.author: Michael L.
review.description:
This is a review for the campus environment only. We had some spare time between our work meetings and our flight home so we decided to stop by Brown and explore the campus/dining options. The campus is well manicured and has that old, New England charm to it. Brown sits across the river from downtown Providence, and is home to numerous independent coffeehouses and shops. I would come back again to explore the area around the campus. 

Metered parking is all around, so finding a spot to park is just a matter of luck and timing. While we were driving away we spotted a Kung Fu Tea that we wanted to grab a drink at, but it didn't seem convenient to find a parking space (all the street parking was taken) and the neighboring bank parking had restriction signs posted. 

Will definitely come back again to explore should we be in Providence.

review.author: May A.
review.description:
Nice campus

I am a tourist here in the East Coast and just wanted to see one of the Ivy League campuses and the 7th oldest college in the U.S... and where the Brunonians went to school... small and intimate compared to the others we visited. Beautiful surroundings in historic Providence :)

Review #0058

review.author: Gerald N.
review.description: We walked around the campus for the first time and it was pretty nice some parts and others were just average. I'm comparing it to the likes of Princeton FYI. Brown's campus was more integrated into a small city feel. The students were a mixed bag of nerdy, preppy, dazed, and snotty. For example, I held a door open for a girl and she just stared at me with no "thank you" as she walked by. There are plenty of restaurants nearby mixed from rich to ordinary like chipotle.

review.author: Eric C.
review.description:
This will be my new home for the next 4 years. Starting residency at Brown University is by far one of the proudest moments of my career thus far. Of course, Rhode Island hospital is off campus on the other side of town (I make it sound far but really it's only like 5 minutes away). The school sits next to RISD so in addition to the world class departments that they have on campus, they share some of the great art community that RISD has to offer. 

Campus is probably smallest of the Ivies, but it's nestled in one of the best college towns I have seen. As you walk through the school, you have to walk down Thayer street and see the great restaurants and tiny stores that the area has to offer.
