We found parking at the large garage just off campus. It's definitely much more compact after touring UC Davis. It feels a bit sketchy near the outer edge of campus and surrounding area just off campus. Keep in mind that it is a small square campus plopped in the middle of a city, near the downtown area. It might not feel safe walking alone through campus at night. Perhaps it's for these reasons that most of the campus buildings require a key card for access/entry (unlike UC Davis where all buildings were unlocked and accessible to visitors).  And perhaps the university may also wish to discourage non-students and transient people from surreptitiously auditing classes. You should schedule a guided tour with if you want to see more of the campus that is not easily accessible to someone without a key card.

Open/accessible areas include the Wellness Center, which has unlocked doors and access to restrooms. The library and the Student Union are also open to the public. You'll find a large food court, plus restrooms, at the Student Union. There are also restaurants (and coffee) a short walk from campus if you don't like any of the food offerings at the Student Union. It is very easy to walk from building to building because the campus is small and not so spread out. The residence halls (dorms) are at one corner of campus. From the outside, some of these dorms are large, tall, modern looking buildings that you might mistake for a hotel. 

SJSU had the "Send Silence Packing" exhibit on suicide awareness & prevention, on the day I visited. It consisted of a bunch of backpacks placed on the large lawn area. Each backpack represented someone's suicide story; many backpacks had a photograph of the person who lost their life to suicide. There was also a tent with counselors. 
https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=i6k9Qfem1079786UNipjqA&userid=isQotFiKU_S_TI4Qt4MtMQ

Boyce Gate
https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=WpYT33KGKC1IgCPrXMzXpw&userid=isQotFiKU_S_TI4Qt4MtMQ

.

review.author: Erika G.
review.description:
As a current student I couldn't be more disappointed in the overall organization of the student services center! Very poorly ran so be aware. 

The student services center staff is there to help students, period point blank!. The bursars office/registrar are a nightmare to get ahold of, and when you do they have little to NO answers for you. They will loop you to other people, have you coming down in person more than you need to be. 

There's no way these people should be working in education. They have no passion, no love to help students. Instead they tell you they have no answers. I don't remember a time where I have been HELPED by a staff member. I always have to find a way around, talk to a dean or higher up. It's really sad and makes things hard for those enrolled.

Thankfully I won't be coming here anymore and I can let this go! But new students be aware, be prepared to self advocate a lot!

review.author: Daniel C.
review.description:
I've been coming to SJSU for the past five years as a volunteer for the Chemical Engineering department, and one of my favorite activities is the annual GRASP (Graduate Research, Alumni and Senior Project) day.  I get to meet with faculty, attend special lectures, chat with students, and review and provide feedback to the senior design projects.  I also provide feedback on the curricula and provide an industrial perspective on skills and behaviors we'd like to see in new graduates.

In chemical engineering undergrad, the final class is a team project to design a chemical process using all the engineering knowledge you've picked up in the past 3 years plus being able to calculate the economics.  You must also be able to clearly articulate the project with a poster, oral presentation and/or written report.  Its not necessarily the most difficult class in the major, but its the most comprehensive and most realistic in terms of what to expect in the workplace.  SJSU deserves credit for giving a wide variety of projects to choose from, from traditional chemicals to semiconductors, biofuels, carbon capture and minerals.  Best of all, many of these projects have diverse industry advisors and sponsors which adds realism and a sense of credibility to the project.  

The Student Union is a pretty nice one, way better than both my alma maters!  The SJSU has a Starbucks, pool hall, bowling alley, and a full food court similar to shopping malls.  Yes, a Panda Express, Jamba Juice, a Halal place, etc.  There seems to be plenty of seating everywhere and flatscreen TVs running the latest news and sports.

Definitely reminds me of the trials and tribulations of getting an undergrad engineering degree.  SJSU is well positioned in Silicon Valley with lots of opportunities, not just high tech but also exciting startups that need chemical engineering skills.  Glad their engineering departments forge ties with industry to best prepare their graduates!

review.author: Alexandra B.
review.description: My review is specific to the freshman orientation for fall 2022. My twins attended the freshman orientation for fall 22. We were very impressed with the level of organization and detail that were provided on the email sent one week prior. We had been surprised to realize that the orientation included a one night stay at the dorms for all students, even if your student was not going to be staying at the dorms during the school year. The food was good and plentiful. The activities during the day were well organized and it was a good experience overall. It was also possible for parents to attend orientation as well for an additional cost. I did not do that so I cannot offer an opinion. We also had to request some special accommodations due to a medical condition and the staff was very empathetic and kind. They were also flexible and made My daughters experience an excellent one during the orientation. Go Spartans!

review.author: Daphne H.
review.description: the location is alright, and the campus is friendly for people who have classes in different buildings. Walking through campus at night is safer than on the street, because of the campus police department, however, walking "inside" only. \nAnd the offices are terrible, during the pandemic, they are all nowhere to be found (which is now better), and it's hard to find parking.

review.author: Kathy N.
review.description:
I went here from 2014 to 2016 and thought it was worth it! I knew this was a commuter school and wasn't there to make friends or anything, so that was not an issue for me. The campus is extremely diverse and had wonderful professors. 

I received my degree in health science (now changed to public health as of 2017). I really felt that my professors were supportive and were always there for me. I was active in a few organizations and also was president of one as well. I was a shy person before starting here and wanted to improve myself, so I really believe that SJSU really unleashed my full potential. During convocation, I received a excellence in leadership award which I am still proud of today. 

After SJSU, I went into a graduate program at another school and I found that SJSU provided a very solid learning foundation for me to succeed. I'm forever grateful for my time here. The only reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars is because I had random homeless dudes approach me at the library asking for my number and it was kind of tough finding parking during certain times.

review.author: Angela G.
review.description: I'm a new student and trying to get IT issues resolved is an absolute nightmare. All I want is to be able to register for online classes, but it's taken 5 days to get in touch with IT.\n\nIn that time I could have applied and been accepted to another university that offers the same online degree with the same admission standards and a functioning IT department.

review.author: Wilma I.
review.description:
Unbelievable that they NOW won't allow any adding of classes within the first 2 weeks before the first day of class.  This just shows how successful they want their students. Then you e-mail an instructor and they won't respond even if you teach our several times.  Being a professor nowadays must be the best relaxing remote job in the world!

Additionally, they force students to do things they aren't comfortable with and that's not the way you should treat college students in America. 

I'm so glad I don't have to deal with them anymore and if I were you I wouldn't go here in person but if you do online schooling you won't ever have any instruction from your professors because they're in Hawaii vacationing while you read books and take test after test and quizzes meanwhile charging the same tuition as you did when you went into classes. 
They're was one class per semester that actually had students appear on zoom and prove that it was you other than that no accountability on the student or instructor. 

It's really sickening what the colleges have come to because they aren't providing in-person instruction or any type of responses through e-mail anymore either.  Sent several emails within 3-2 weeks of the start of the semester- nothing no response.

You might benefit from watching videos on y o u tub e or watching Jordan Peterson's videos for free. 

You've been warned.

review.author: Jacqueline F.
review.description: I walk through the campus when I visit my sister because she lives across the street. She's also an alumnus and lived about four blocks south of it when she was in college. I like the walk through the campus and have taken some pics. There are some old buildings and new ones. One day, we ran into a professor who was a friend of my dad's and he helped my sister with her entry. She had a couple of good years before transferring to another school to continue her education. I think that she was lucky to go there and we are both l lucky to visit.

review.author: Ivan S.
review.description:
This review is on a slight scale of bias, but I love this campus and what I think it means for everyone that visit's this place. I haven't attended college before and am not a student here. With that said I am a life long learner and I show my friends who have graduated here love and respect through spirit and context of being somewhere firsthand. NOT vicariously. I usually come here for face time sessions, online classes and just about finding a place to stretch during this c19. A nice campus to bury oneself and come out a refreshed person. I am mindful and I throw away my trash and clean up after. It's a nice campus and maybe one day I'll attend here as I work in Human services/ Social services. Who knows.

_Enso

+-

 Parking is tight. Again come here as early as possible and don't wing and think yourself a king and then find no parking. YOU WILL GET FINED AND OR TOWED if you try and park in one of the near by lots neighborhoods. The city has absolutely no shame, ie Grocery outlet. 

Benches, stairs, nooks and crannies.

Grass.

Shade. 

_See I never really knew life could be so hard
I never really knew pain til I got scared
I never knew people could be so cold
I never knew wrong til I was ten years old
I never knew fighten til I got my ass kicked
I never knew gettin' got til I got tricked
I never knew healthy til I got sick
And I never knew people killed people so quick
Yo, I never knew mind power could be so deep

Never say never because it never comes true

_ Artist: Aceyalone
Album: Accepted Eclectic
Released: 2001
Genre: Hip-Hop/Rap

review.author: H J.
review.description:
*I started this review in 2019 and finally decided to post after I graduated lol

Their bursars office is terrible. They act like debt collectors and hunt you down, call you ALL the time, and email. 

Amanda Johnson from the Bursar's office called me and left a voicemail saying my e-Check payment of $500 for a study abroad deposit bounced and, her words, I "didn't do anything about it." I literally paid the day I found out the check bounced and she would've known that if she looked around a little more instead of calling me immediately. But she didn't and
just went ahead and blocked my online payments, so I'd be forced to go to the office and pay in person AND she'd contact the study abroad office to tell them I didn't pay and that I can't attend the program... 

I called back, no answer, so I left a voicemail saying I paid for it, I had the transaction listed on my bank account, so I know you took the money, so why are you calling me?  She called me back, and we spoke, she made excuses about how I "selected the wrong term" when paying, when I KNOW I chose the right one because I triple checked with the professors in charge of the FLP Study Abroad program and they checked with the study abroad office, who told them to choose the term the study abroad program will be. In this case, it was Summer 2019, so that's what I chose. Yet they couldn't keep track of it? Whatever she 'fixed it' and I'm just glad I didn't have to pay all over again. 

BUT the annoyance continues. They CHARGED $35 FOR RETURNED E-CHECKS. As if the school isn't already sponging me of almost $4,000 a SEMESTER. The fine had no due date, so I was planning on doing it later in the semester, yet Amanda calls me again, says I didn't pay, THEN PLACES A HOLD ON MY ACCOUNT.  They literally waited until the 2nd week of the semester to place a hold on my account, when it's peak time for people to be adding and dropping classes....F*** this, honestly, the whole system sucks. I also don't appreciate being harassed over a $35 fine that had no due date. Be better, thanks.

My older sister went here a few years before me. A few weeks before graduation, they said they didn't have any record of her so we wouldn't be able to graduate. She ran around all the offices like crazy trying to figure out what was going on. No one knew, so they'd point her to a different office. Come to find out, they were looking at the wrong list. All that panic over nothing.

review.author: Clayton M.
review.description: The campus changes by the new buildings. With the new buildings, comes new ideas to come for writing in English courses.

review.author: Steve F.
review.description: As a graduate of SJSU, I must say, it's not just the professors that makes a different here, it's entire ecosystem which exists here at SJSU.

review.author: Jason G.
review.description: This state school has once been a good school to get education. A loooong time ago. Now this University is in the worst area possible with shootings, homeless, a stench that never leaves and bad neighborhoods surrounding the campus that do not look appealing. Furthermore, the classes all have a policy that enables instructors to chastise students for looking away, not making it to a class quiz that was scheduled to overlap another class you have, giving extra points to student who report other students and the list goes on. What is worse is that the advisors will more than likely deny any credit transfers because they want you to graduate from their university specifically (attempted and this was what was said and the result). They take no consideration for students and for a "university" with instructor that have degrees and is regarded as a "good business school". It is poorly managed and upper and lower staff frequently makes irrational decisions that are non negotiable. Do not make a mistake in believing that this is a college pick based on old reviews or assumptions. They have changed policies, culture, and there are better options at the time of this writing.

review.author: Krista B.
review.description: I received my Master's in Industrial Organizational Psychology at SJSU (class of 2020). I had an amazing experience while attending school. I received my Bachelor's degree in Ohio, and I feel that SJSU did a better job at getting their students involved in activities outside of class and held many events. I really enjoyed the "outdoor adventures" where I met a few friends I am still friends with and I also enjoyed the "chew", which is a cooking class. Between these two activities, I learned how to kayak, surf, and cook many diverse and delicious dishes. I highly recommend participating in these fantastic activities for students!

review.author: Don P.
review.description:
After enrolling in three classes here, during covid pandemic. There has been countless amounts of hackers on the server. San Jose State dean have not responded to this issue professionally.

Each student is given a different exam base from a tests bank.

I am highly disappointed my first semester at San Jose State University..

review.author: Shannon H.
review.description: Just visited the University as I was in the neighborhood. Very beautiful campus, located conveniently in the heart of San Jose downtown area. Although a public University, I'm sure it must still be very expensive to study here as I figured. However, close proximity to Silicon valley means lots of jobs, which ensures student placement. Overall, should be a great school to go if you're looking to major in Computer Science or related disciplines! Go SJSU Spartans!

review.author: Jessamine A.
review.description:
08.07.2018

Home to Sammy the Spartan!

Came on a campus tour for H today....it's getting closer to being reality! ‍

Nice campus in the midst of downtown San Jose.  The MLK library is also open to the public daily from 8a-5p.

review.author: Sonia N.
review.description:
Let me start by saying, what an experience I had at this university. I graduated community in Spring 2015 and then graduated here in Fall 2018.  Throughout my time here I fell in love with the staff and the school. Originally back in high school I did not want to "play it safe" and attend here. What a fool I was! I wish I applied earlier to save me the heart ache and headaches of not being able to attend school in SoCal and problems I faced at EVC. I was accepted into EOP, Educational Opportunities Program, a wonderful program that helped me through my time at SJSU. 
 Although heavily impacted, I loved my time in the psychology department. The professors all have experience in the field and really impart their wisdom. I felt like I realistically could go to any of them for advice, which is incredible because I am very shy. I also feel prepared for attempting to apply to grad school thanks to my professors. 
The university itself is quite inspiring. There is so much rich history, and architecture here. I always loved exploring the campus grounds because of how beautiful it is. Also because it has loads of Poke Stops!!! One of my favorite things here is sitting under the trees listening to the bell ring at Tower Hall. 
Although this school is amazing in its resources, I have to knock one star off. The reason for this is due to student safety. Although there are various "blue lights" (campus police system) the campus is still unsafe. There are always robberies at various times in the day (primarily in the garages). There has been gun scares, suicides in the library, and recent racial incidents. Also, there are homeless that wander the grounds, especially the library. Yes they send a bulletin about these incidents to students, but it doesn't help stop this from happening. 
All in all I would recommend this school to incoming freshmen and transfer students. You will receive an excellent education here, but make sure you put in the effort. My grades from EVC (also paper screw ups) haunted me here. Instead of graduating Magna Cum Laude I graduated Cum Laude with Honors in the Major. I worked my ass off and was off only by a little bit. Grades matter, so take your time here seriously. Also keep in mind your experience here is what you make of it. There are loads of clubs, frat/sor, and organizations. I joined Psi Chi, and it was a great decision. The chapter here at SJSU is great. I made friends from my psych classes and we powered through together. Advice: only take on the work load you can realistically handle. Enjoy your time here, because like me you will miss it!  Also look into SJSU Cares! They have wonderful resources for students such as the Mobile Pantry. As a struggling college student they were a life saver to help feed my family, and provide me assistance during the most difficult time in my life. I am forever thankful to them.

So join the Spartan Familia and Spartan Up!

review.author: Eliza J.
review.description:
SJSU is an AWESOME college campus and has a AMAZING education system. The university was built in the 1850's and is one of the oldest in the West Coast college systems!

SJSU is VERY WELL CONTAINED I.e. Campus housing; academic, social and athletic activities; campus police/policing; MANY food choices. There is definitely not a need or reason for  FROSH (freshmen) to leave campus. 

We love the university is DIVERSE ethnically, academically and socially.  SJSU is centrally located in the heart of San Jose. It's surrounded by a lot of great culture and beautiful old architecture. 
 
Our son will be a FROSH very soon :))

Go SPARTANS!!! Go Graduating Class of 2021!!!

review.author: Maurica H.
review.description:
We couldn't have picked a better option for our son. He has been attending Stratford since Pre-K and the experience has been wonderful. We were truly worried starting school in the middle of a pandemic, though those worries were quickly put to rest. We appreciate the smaller class sizes, social distancing and the fun lessons of how to stay clean. 

Our son's love for school has doubled over in size in the past 2 years. The amazing connections he has created with staff and students is something we truly cherish. 
 
His teachers so far - 
Pre-K: Ms.Dottie 
Summer T-K: Mrs.Hayes
T-K: Ms. Ayala (current teacher) 

They have all been absolutely amazing. HIGHLY RECOMMEND

review.author: Michael S.
review.description:
Our child just finished 5th grade at Stratford on San Anselmo, after being there since Pre-K and thru Spring 2022. We used to recommend Stratford to everyone, but now, cannot recommend the school, especially for 5th grade.  Stratford has a serious teacher-accountability issue and is woefully behind the times with their online portal, compared to any other private school in the area. Once we started having issues, I asked the latest principal "why should our child go to Stratford instead of a public school?". His answer was "we have a 15-1 student/teacher ratio, so no child should get left behind or feel like they are not getting individual attention, like they might-- in public school-- with larger class sizes." 

If you know your child to be outgoing, requires no supervision, is unafraid to ask questions, always motivated to study, and confident in speaking up in class, your kid could thrive anywhere. They are the 5-star reviewers here. They should be reviewing their kid. Many kids at this campus were that way before the pandemic. Stratford literally had no policy regarding getting kids re-acclimated after distance learning.  Coming back to school was sink-or-swim. A group of 5-6 parents and I shared our bad experiences and encouraged each other to talk to the teachers first and then, the principal. It was the worst customer experience of my life, not only because of the money involved, but the "time"..... I write a lot of positive reviews, but if you read any of my negative ones, please know this is the hardest and worst of all of them. My motto is "the fish stinks from the head down...". 

Stratford is the only private school here, owned by a Private Equity Group from another country that is currently undergoing a severe debt and financial crisis with capital flight, political upheaval, you name it. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_Education_Group. PEGs, in general, are not known for keeping customers first, they support shareholders. They are known for ruining many an industry. 

We were warned about 5th grade at this location by a few parents who each had a few kids go there, and pulled the youngest out in time for 5th. Especially warned of a male math teacher, who had a reputation for being--not mean, but--too gruff and inflexible with any student--especially boys, who were not super motivated, outgoing and studious. He had a way of calling kids out who asked a question about what he just lectured on, blaming them for "not paying attention" or "not taking notes". Any student who was shy or needed extra help would not get help unless they asked. Kids who needed help, after the way he treated them, "learned how to not ask dumb questions" as my son put it. We asked him many times to please help our shy kid, but he just ghosted us. He somehow chose 2022 summer to quit. His 5th grade co-teacher, a woman who is still there, was kinder the kids, however, she was very disorganized. She changed the lesson plans from what was on the Schoology online schedule almost daily. Constant feedback accomplished nothing. Her habit of "changing of plans on the fly" caused 15 kids,+ 30 parents (45 people), hours of stress almost each night because we would email or text each other to try to figure out what the lesson was (she took to long to respond). Same thing on the weekend for big projects that were due, then not due, because she cancelled at the last minute. 

Most of us were shocked when we had the first parent teacher conference, which was months into the school year. At that time, they announced to us that not only were our kids struggling, but the two teachers knew about it all those months. None of us were notified by a concerned teacher before that announcement, or any time after that conference. They could see the child needed help and never reached out. We asked why. They said they were waiting for the kids to ask them for help. So much for good student/teacher ratios where the child gets individual attention.

The new principal, who came during lockdown, was a breath of fresh air. The previous principal had years of feedback about 5th grade. Never got better. He tried and tried. Eventually, he quit this summer after 1.5 years at this campus and years at Stratford. Their loss. 

Most parents I talked to, who had kids who did not do well in math in 5th, said their kids did well in all the previous years. The math was not that much harder, I know, I helped my kid study...Same student, different teachers, seems obvious to me. Instead of giving feedback to the school, they opted to send their kids to expensive and time-consuming tutors. If I bought a car, I would expect the dealer to fix it under warranty, not for me to have to pay out of pocket. Makes no sense to me. 

Since this has happened, our child applied at 2 local secular private schools. Both have online portals that make Stratford look like the 80s. Better customer support, as well. Your money is spent better elsewhere.

review.author: Deepika A.
review.description:
This is our daughters second year at Stratford and we are very happy with our decision to choose Stratford as her first school. She is currently enrolled in Ms. Naila and Ms. Shumin's Pre-K class. Both the teachers are exceptionally well with the kids. Teachers engage the kids in activities right from the time you drop off till the time you pick them up. I have seen teachers read stories or sit with the kids n engage them in conversations while I pick my daughter up. They make learning fun for our daughter. I have seen a tremendous growth in our daughters social n writing skills. She is more confident n Independent. Thanks to the teachers working with her closely on these areas. Our daughter wants to be the last one to be picked up. This shows how much she loves being in the class. 

We like the curriculum offered at Stratford. Our daughter enjoys Mr. Max's music class and recites all the songs at home. I am amazed with her Spanish vocabulary, thanks to Ms. Victoria and she can't stop talking about all the cool science experiments she learned from Ms. Sandy. 

We are looking forward for yet another amazing year at Stratford.

review.author: J Y.
review.description: Where do I even begin? This year (2022) has been nothing but an absolute disappointment! School has been in session for a month and the teacher has yet to show up. What kind of private school functions like this? For $20,000/year you would expect them to have their act together! \nMy child refuses to drink any water because their restrooms are worse than a gas station. Feces and urine on toilet seats and on the floor! If you try to file a complaint, the leadership team does absolutely nothing but brush you off. Is it not a basic necessity to have a janitorial staff at an elementary school? What exactly does my tuition cover? Do yourself a favor and PASS on this one. There are way better schools out there.

review.author: Darren I.
review.description: Best choice and investment I made for my son.  He has been with Stratford since preschool, before the pandemic.  The school went to distance learning when the pandemic first struck, and it only took them a few weeks to transitioned. PreK we did entirely online. Ms Ankita was amazing and the curriculum was on par with brick-&-mortar. My son read at 4 years old and did basic addition and subtraction.  He is currently back in class in Kindergarten with Mrs Cumbo and Mrs Nair, who are the most patient teachers.  This year has seen amazing growth from my Kinder, writing sentences, reading whole books, proficient with arithmetic and graphs.\n\nWhat I love most beyond the academic is the nurturing and warmth of this schools.  The teachers and even staff knows every student by name.  Academic is balanced with play and socioemotional development.  The principal is out everyday greeting the kids at drop off and pickup.  Kudos to all the safety measures during this pandemic period.

review.author: Vanessa W.
review.description: I thought Stratford had a decent reputation.  I enrolled my rising 5th grader into their summer stem program.  My experience has been that Stratford uses substandard supplies, lacks attention to detail and piece mills its curriculum. Very disappointed.  Last day of week 3 and I kept my child home.  It just was not worth the drive over there.  My child was supposed to be in a stem program not a daycare.  I could not recommend this program to any friends/family.

review.author: Shital M.
review.description:
Stratford has been an amazing stepping stone into my all of Children's introduction to education - most specifically pre-k under the guidance of Ms Naila and Ms Shumin. I have seen a tremendous growth in them socially, emotionally and academically.  I'm always taken aback at how much my children have learned and continue to learn under their kind, gentle and warm guidance. I especially love the variety that is provided in their curriculum from science, arts, Spanish, music to much more. 
The San Jose Campus especially has done an excellent job during this pandemic year in ensuring our children/staff are safe and communication lines kept open on guiding us through covid-19 protocols and changing guidelines. 

It's been a pleasure watching my kids blossom at Stratford and develop a solid start to their educational career.

review.author: Nahal Z.
review.description:
Both of our kids have attended preschool at stratford, one as they was transitioning out of the home daycare and the other as an addition to the home daycare environment just prior to and during the pandemic. We truly came to Stratford because of Miss Saadiya. We met her for a tour and she was so warm and welcoming. While walking us around campus for the tour she literally knew every child's name and the kids would light up when she greeted them. We were floored as this was so different than some other schools. Both our kids immediately clicked with her. Aside from all the fun things at Stratford like the train, the music, the science, I think it was the relational aspect that made us feel so comfortable. Our kids were 2 of 7 kids at their home daycare, so making a transition to a bigger preschool was a concern; however, seeing an admissions director know every single child's name and have a connection with them put us at such ease. She would also check on the kids in their first months, and we would know because the kids would tell us Miss Saadiya visited today! 

Our child's preschool teachers have been wonderful this year. Mrs Amisha and Mrs Mamata are so incredibly loving and kind. They give each parent a quick update during pick ups. And they truly love these kids. Our child loves the hugs they get from them and they talk about them both nonstop. If you are in their classroom you are so lucky as at this age and all the things these kids have been through, getting love and care is so important! Even during snack time where teachers may just use the time to do other things or check out, they are multitasking and interacting with the kids, talking about how juicy and crunchy the apples are and bringing in the 5 senses. We also witnessed something after their spring program where like 6 kids were having a meltdown seeing their parents leave. They remained so incredibly calm and were gently calming each child. This is not an easy task with 23 toddlers to manage. They also know your child, their interests, their quirks and they work with your child. Most importantly our child feels loved at school and our child has the space to develop their voice. Miss Angela, the school principal, is both professional and kind. In the first months of school she would stand close to the departure area and would always be connecting with different parents. 

Our other child is in KG at Stratford and is also very happy!! They still get excited when they see Miss Saadiya around campus and we remember those first apprehensive days of preschool where she would just go sit beside them to increase their comfort. We just have less interaction due to the COVID protocols; however, our child enjoys being with Mrs Cumbo and Mrs Nair. Mr, Bickel is very relatable to the kids and he has a strong presence at the school during morning drive line. It's not often that you see a principal in this role opening car doors and taking temperatures. As a parent, the academics seem demanding as the kids enter elementary school and that is still something that we are evaluating to see if it is the best fit for our kids; however, our child absolutely loves PE with Coach Collins, music with Miss Dena, and Spanish with Seniora Lopez! These are fan favorites! Our child does not love the daily homework and yet that comes with the territory of the school and we will see how that continues into 1st grade. Are there areas for improvement, sure, as there will be with any school. We encountered a few things that we thought could have been handled differently and yet that would probably be the case anywhere these days. Bottom line is both the kids are happy and I don't think they have ever said they didn't want to go to school. Our older child went through so many transitions with COVID and childcare that this year has provided them with a lot of stability and consistency. Also the office staff, specifically Miss Vanessa. She is so wonderful and handles so many things with grace.

review.author: Lisa M.
review.description:
We are in our third year at Stratford and I continue to be impressed by all the staff and teachers, and thankful that my son is able to attend this school.  He is currently in Kindergarten and previously attended both Pre-K and T-K.

Stratford San Jose puts in a lot of effort into making each child feel known, safe, and welcomed.  I have been on campus many times and witnessed interaction between faculty and children in many settings, and without fail the staff and teachers are warm, respectful, and appropriately firm with the children.  Each student is known by name and encouraged to express themselves, while still operating within a structure that teaches core values such as trustworthiness and perseverance.

Stratford has a very well-rounded curriculum, emphasizing solid foundational skills (reading, writing, math) and also incorporating music, PE, Spanish, art, science, history, and social studies into each week's lessons. Older students also participate in additional subjects such as computer science.  They also have fun activities (in-person, in normal years) such as pep-rallies, field trips, and after-school clubs.

Due to Covid during the 2020-21 school year, Statford has been nimble in adjusting their offerings to suit both online or an in-person hybrid school model.   They have quickly adapted to provide a robust curriculum in both formats and used technology to make sure the online option is still providing a great experience for the kids.

I would encourage any parent looking for a school with strong academics, while also truly caring about their child as an individual, to check into Stratford San Jose.

review.author: Surabhi A.
review.description:
Our son is currently enrolled in Pre-K virtual program. We have been very impressed with the curriculum as well as the way the teachers have been able to adapt and deliver it virtually. 

Our teacher, Ms. Ankita has been truly exceptional. It is no small feat to engage kids via zoom. I give all the credit to her for my son thriving academically in remote learning. She is a total rockstar. Her positive vibes uplift the kids and they look forward to the class everyday. She is encouraging and teaches kids to be independent. She is consistent with the behaviors kids are expected to do and she patiently encourages them to make the right choices. You can tell she loves all the kids and the kids adore her!

Our son also enjoys art and science. Ms Sandy makes science class interesting and interactive. I marvel at how simply she explains concepts. 

Special shout out to Ms Angela who has been superb too. She has been very responsive and was especially helpful as we transferred our child from De Anza. She really helped us build confidence in her teachers and school. 

We couldn't have made a better choice.

review.author: Aristomenis C.
review.description: Our son just finished pre-K with Ms. Joly. We find Ms. Joly and the rest of the staff to be so kind, warm and thorough. Our son is doing things we didn't expect he'd be capable of for years. The school is clean, welcoming, and an exciting place for our son to look forward to going to. We've visited other private schools in this area, and this is by far the best.

review.author: Ankita K.
review.description:
I have both my kids here my older one is in 4th grade and the younger one in pre k 
So far it's been a positive experience good administrative staff and positive teachers 
My kids enjoy the school and curriculum and always do pretty well when the reports come out
The stage performances used to be quite good but due to coronavirus everything has changed and switched online 
Last year the staff did well managing the online and hybrid system 
I regularly recommend this school to friends

review.author: Shun Y.
review.description: The school was closed in March this year. At the very beginning, no classes were offered. Then one hour class was provided by the teacher.  We have to pay full tuition fee. \nThe school did not care about anything but money. \nIf you want to withdraw,  then you will be fined with a lot of money.

review.author: Thanh L.
review.description: My daughter was enrolled in Pre-K really late this year due to the pandemic. Had been staying home for over a year, she was a very picky eater and shy. Within 2 months with Ms. Joly's class, we can notice her impressive progress. From being scared of snack time and unsocialized, she has become more open with her peers and been able to try new food. Ms. Joly and Stratford was really accommodating to the student's need and trying to make the children feel at most comfortable. Ms. Joly was very responsive to parents, always let us know how my daughter was doing and if there's any concern. We really appreciate her for everything she has done for my child and how amazing she was as our teacher.

review.author: Gargi C.
review.description: Our kid was at San Jose campus as a transition student in Ms Jyoti's classroom (preschool). Even in those short 2 months he learnt a lot about different life skills, co-existence with Nature and STEAM subjects. Butterfly lifecycle was one of the best projects in my opinion. Students used their imagination to create each form of the lifecycle. Ms Jyoti even demonstrated it using a real caterpillar and its stages. When they let the butterfly into the open air kids' joy had no bounds. This taught them value of freedom for animals and insects as well. She is a very loving and caring teacher, and puts her passion for early childhood education into the curriculum. I saw a big leap in my kid's painting, writing, expression of his thoughts and creativity during those two months. Big thanks to Ms Michelle who is very kind and loving, taught music, arts and painting to kids that help develop their creative side of brain. My kid had eczema flareups and both teachers took lot of effort to keep it under control by applying home provided eczema cream regularly. On his last day at school they had a nice farewell party and all wished him well. Ms Jyothi's loving and encouraging words in her short prose for him on his picture will always be cherished :)\nI am thankful to Stratford San Jose administrative staff for providing excellent support during the toughest times in pandemic. All my concerns and questions about operation in pandemic were very patiently handled. They maintain highest standards of cleanliness and hygiene which made us feel safe and comfortable sending our kid during pandemic. Big shout out to Ms Angela, Ms Saadiya and Jessica. I highly recommend this school and in particular Ms Jyoti's classroom. Stratford SJ family will always be missed.

review.author: Maire L.
review.description: Great school in an amazing safe suburban area. Each staff member here goes above and beyond to prepare your child for the following grade and educates them in a way that leaves them confident. I've sent my children here since pre school and if I could refer any Stratford school it would be this location. 10/10 recommend.

review.author: Maki M.
review.description: We are so grateful to be part of Stratford community at this unprecedented time. My daughter is pre-K with Ms. Desirie and Ms.Madhavi. I have a very super active daughter who requires more challenge and follow up. Before shelter in place they were helping her a lot and after zoom session starts we were amazed how the school scaled up by creating distance learning curriculum. She has a daily zoom class and she look forward to it everyday. Her room teachers are phenomenal, they try to make all zoom session as fun as possible so that the kids can be engaged and do the work. We love the science teacher Ms. Sandy, Spanish teacher Ms. Victoria and Music teacher Ms. Vivian. They all do a fantastic job. \n\nWe highly recommend Stratford for any parent who is looking a very structured curriculum.

review.author: Cyndy S.
review.description: WOW! This is what I use to describe Stratford San Jose. From the teachers to the staff they are amazing!  Besides the well rounded education my kids receive here everyone is so welcoming and you can see how much they care about each child.  \nMy family went through a horrific tragedy in May 2018, we were so touched by the love and support we received from Stratford teachers, staff and parents. I want to give a big shout out to Ms. Angela, Ms. Janet, Ms. Audrey, Ms. Lily, Ms. Madhavi, Ms. Julianne, Ms. Ashlie. Ms. Kelly, Ms. Marisol and everyone else who has helped my kids Olivia & Nathaniel grow. \nTo all the parents searching for schools Stratford San Jose is the place to be!

review.author: Ana C.
review.description:
If could rate them higher I would. They offer an excellent STEM curriculum. The teachers and others staff members are phenomenal. My son is now enrolled in Pre-K with Ms. Naila, she is top notch, every day my son amazes me with how much he learns, she is caring and her passion for teaching is reflected on all that she does.  The class projects are varied and interesting, my son looks forward to going to class.  

The science teacher Ms. Sandy is also amazing, my son talks about all the "cool stuff" he learns and all the experiments (projects) they work on.

I highly recommend Stratford to any parent looking for a solid curriculum.

review.author: NL S.
review.description: Mrs. Manasa and Mrs. Debbie have been so passionate about making sure their students have continued to develop intellectually with the homeschooling program which they have efficiently formulated in these trying times of COVID-19.  They quickly adapted to the challenge by stepping up to provide an entertaining and effective way of learning for their kids.  I'm amazed with the daily classes that they prepare for my daughter and I'm so grateful for their genuine love for teaching.  Their punctuality and consistency they are offering to my daughter has really helped establish a vital routine while we are at home.  I'm fortunate to witness these two teachers' expertise during the last several weeks with their regular zoom classes.  The specialty classes given by Mrs. Sandy, Mrs. Victoria and Mrs. Vivian have been extra fun too!  I'm proud of our decision in confidently trusting Stratford for our daughter's enrichment needs.  Thank you everyone for your stellar performances week after week!

review.author: Aniko N.
review.description: Currently my daughter's goes to Sora three times a week and she's truly enjoyed the Japanese interaction she's gets at school. She's only cried once during her first day of school but since than she's look forward attending school and washing her hands first thing in the morning. Just be aware that before your child goes to preschoolers. They need to know how to drink and eat on their own. Also, there's wont be any straws at school to assist them with their drinking. I understand They are strict, but Japanese are known in their country to well disciples. Anyways, My husband is Japanese and He's very happy with how much his daughter is learning. We both looking forward transitions her into preschool and K in the near future.

review.author: Ken O.
review.description: Small classes (6 max) - nice teachers.  Not your typical instructional type program.  Each student goes at their own pace so levels can be varied in one class.  Only Japanese is spoken - this is a better alternative to the more rigorous program on Sat at Hoshuuko.

review.author: Kayla C.
review.description:
Such a great university!

While the building is nice, I do think the actual library is subpar; it's more of a common area for students to be social than an academic space for quiet studying, research, reading, etc. The second floor of the building is the "library," but it's mostly couches, some tables and chairs, table games, board games, arcade games, TVs... The actual "library" is very small area of the second floor, marking one side of the second floor of the building. There aren't a ton of books, I think there is ONE private study room (on a first-come, first-served basis), and it's very sad compared to South's library: several floors of MANY books, a lot of computers, MANY private study rooms for groups as well as cubicle areas, and it's understood and enforced to be respectful and quiet there. 

As a nursing student, it was a bit disappointing there is no formal library or separate building for the School of Nursing. I love the university, but it would be great to see them do more for the academic settings and rein it back a little on the social ones. The social aspects of the university are great, and while nursing students have privileges to be in certain parts of campus for studying regardless of time of day or semester schedule, I think more students could benefit from a formal library-- away from the relaxed environment of loud socializing-- and private study areas within the library. As far as a building for the SoN, only time will tell how/if the funds could provide that...

review.author: Isaac V.
review.description: Going for the Accelerated Nursing Batchelor's and, while the education is great, the school nickels and dimes you to death with fees. The school is already expensive at $425 / credit, and they still stick you with $260 per term (three terms per semester) and other ridiculous fees. I've seen people taking the normal 24 credits for one spring semester, and getting billed $18,000!!!  UM leadership needs to realize they are not Harvard and tone it down a little.

review.author: David C.
review.description:
A hidden gem.

The University of Mobile stands in the shadows of the University of South Alabama only due to its size.  Springhill College is older.  But the University of Mobile (UM) is a world-class school and has achieved remarkable status in a relatively few number of "university years."
My son has attended the University and has benefitted in so many ways.  He is a music and business major and has received top-of-the-line training in both areas.  As an "All-Steinway" school, UM's dedication to having an ultra high quality music program is apparent.  Christian music legend Dr. Roger Breland is engaged and accessible to the students.
The campus is first-class, and the students are friendly.  My son has made a multitude of great friends. We have attended many different programs there from recitals to the annual "Christmas Spectacular".  If Branson, Missouri closed down, the faculty and students at UM have more than enough talent to do anything they do in Branson or Nashville.  Their new recording studio, 880 is one of the very best in the country.
Dr. Smith, the new president of the University seems focused on taking things to the next level and beyond.  He certainly has the credentials and skills, and I believe you will be hearing more and more about this amazing school in the years to come.

review.author: Serena D.
review.description: GenerateTech has excellent coding classes and hands on technology training for children. They offer after school classes, summer camps, and field trips. The teachers are patient and smart and the classes fun for the kids. For kids that want more than just playing video games, this is a great place to go.

review.author: michael s.
review.description:
From first grade to fith, I attended Robertsdale El-Hi. My adoptive parents went here bacj in the 30's for goodness sake! And it's still there!
My memory us of getting into trouble and having to stand outside in the dark hallway..(the school had wood floors then) and freaking out upon hearing shoes clomping from the distance, fearing it was Virgil Buck, the principal at the time, coming toward me. He actually found me once and was very kind to me. Of course, I had his wife as a teacher in 2nd grade and she kept me in a 'special' desk close to hers so she could keep an eye on me. I actually thrived that year.
The place was so old they still had cloak rooms. I was put in there a lot by teachers. The whole place was OLD! I'm quite surprised I didn't find graffiti from my mom and dad's time!
But I loved the grassy hill outside that sprouted onion grass every spring and the old oaks and pecan trees. One of the old trees is still there but a shadow of its former might.
So glad certain landmarks are still around.

review.author: Aleeta P.
review.description:
It's a beautiful place to live.   The evergreen trees make it beautiful and green all year.  In the spring, the bounty of Azaleas all over the county sprinkle the landscape with vibrant colors.  

Summer/Fall temperatures can sometimes extend into November, so there is not a huge display of fall colors.  Plus, there are more evergreen trees than there are trees whose leaves change color.  

Public transportation is really bad, so a car is absolutely necessary to get around.  

There are a number of institutions of higher education.  Bishop State Community College has 3 campuses that offer different technical specialties.  

Mobile College has become the University of Mobile.  It is a private Baptist -affiliated institution.   

Spring Hill College is another private institution that is affiliated with Roman Catholics, while the University of South Alabama is a public, mostly teaching institution with a phenomenal Medical school, public hospital and level 1 trauma center.  

The State-of-the-Art Convention Center is on the waterfront and hosts all sorts of conferences.  The building was erected around the train tracks such a train goes through the building on a daily schedule.   

The historic (1927) Seanger Theatre in an historic section of downtown Mobile offers numerous live performances and even has a summer movie series.  

Mobile Bay Bears (minor league baseball) are a double A affiliate of the Anaheim Angels and the play their home games at Hank Aaron Stadium.  Hank Aaron, who broke Babe Ruth's  career home run record is from Mobile.  Other teams in existence are (were) the Mobile Bay Tarpons (indoor football), the Mobile Mysticks  (hockey:1995-2002), Mobile Revelers (basketball:2001-2001).  

Downtown Mobile also has the Alabama State Docks (Port of Mobile), which is in the top 12 largest shipping Ports (by tonnage) in the Nation. It is the only deep-water port in the state.  

While this is not all of the glorious offerings of Mobile, Al, you can see that it has many components of a nice place to visit or live.

review.author: Tina B.
review.description: Saraland City Schools all in all is a great school system to send your kids to, I wouldn't be the one to try and turn you in another direction. The school is nice, the eduacation is good, most of the teachers are very help, etc. The only thing I would have to complain about is how focused it is on sports. Mostly football but sports in general. So much time and focus goes in the sports that the arts are rarely given the support that it needs. I understand how good sports are for students but the arts are just as important for a student to be able to grow. Although the Arts are not as loved as they should be Saraland offers many arts to participate in and that I am extremely grateful for. The only thing I and any of the parents and students are asking for is more support and focus.

review.author: C Lyn M.
review.description: Saraland has great schools. All 3 schools have a very good programs for all ages. For children that have behavior issues to children that have very high IQ. The schools have a lot of things to involve parents in. If the parents want to be involved.

review.author: Monique P.
review.description: Saraland Elementary school was the best choice for our family. The community is very family oriented. We feel safe with the Saraland Police Department. My kids love this school system.

name: Amoura Aesthetics Education and Hair Care
Vina High School Gym & Field House

review.author: Tommy P.
review.description:
Let me start off by saying that I feel like I'm the kinda person who lingers between Andy Dwyer and Ron Swanson. So before you take this too seriously, let me remind you that this is a Yelp review. That being said, I'd love to come out of retirement for this review and talk about something that I've cared so deeply about ever since I joined Greek Life, in the time before twitter. Lame ik.. 

First, I highly recommend going Greek no matter what your age is. But before you do, know that there is a standard you must meet. The school will tell you that you need a minimum GPA of 2.5 in college or in High School (if you're an incoming freshman). But lets be real, if you're coming out of HS with a GPA between a 2.5 & 2.8 you need to seriously consider establishing a solid GPA for a semester or two before you join. Now for the part they won't talk about during recruitment.. You need to be a person of solid character and moral judgment. In life you're going to be put in awkward situations that you're not always going to have a good answer for. But you don't have to be a rocket scientist to know the difference between good and bad. You'll learn proper etiquette later and will mold in to the person you were meant to be as you get older. That's life. 

Now who doesn't love sorority rush?? I'll be quick and to the point. As a whole, sororities at ATU need to use more glitter and the Campus Rush video needs a serious overhaul. The music in the video is comparable to Nickelback playing at a Chuck E Cheese venue. (Cringe) Now I understand the school wants to come off as a safe and conservative place for students. But seriously? Ew. My experience with sororities has been excellent. Something about southern ladies helping the community and being leaders on campus is a thing of beauty. (To my knowledge the Panhellenic Council is a secret society of robe wearers who all carry gavels) Idk I've never been to one of their meetings, it's just what I've heard.

For the men in Greek Life, I'll make this super short and hopefully you'll get something out of it:
You're born male, You grow in to a man, and you choose to be a gentleman. You can be cool and interact with everyone on campus without having to act insecure. Do that and you're college experience will be so much more bearable.
 
Now for the PRO'S: 1 Speaking from experience, Greek Life gives you a platform to meet and get out in front of new people.  2 You'll make a ton of new friends and make memories that will last a lifetime. Who knew this was possible in Russellville? 3 Opportunities to get involved are endless. You can literally do incredible things to help the community. 4 Mixers!! Need I say more? 5 Greek Week. This is hard to explain unless you've been through it.

And finally: The CON'S : 1 The Link 2 Mandatory meetings and events 3 No Greek housing. Seriously Tech needs to get on this. It's kind of embarrassing and hard to justify all of the improvements on campus while not have Greek housing. 4 Student Services can be your best friend or worst nightmare. Elect intelligent and hard working leaders!! 5 Fines 6 Living in Russellville. 

I could go on all day. Seriously. (Willing to change my review to 5 stars pending I get my photo hung up and placed in Doc Bryan). @RiffRaffPayne

review.author: Quincy E.
review.description: Great university to attend!  Buildings are updated and new! Instructors are easy to reach and offer good advice! Student life is fun and a lot of opportunities.  It's a beautiful area with lots to do. Hiking, camping, kayaking, and Mt. Nebo down the road. My young adult daughter loves it, although she doesn't like to study so much!

review.author: Randall K P.
review.description: A great university. Has had impressive, quality growth over the years.  Nice facilities on campus. The faculty gives their students personal attention. Students are not just a number here.

review.author: Daniel P.
review.description: Nearly the entire campus needs to be power washed, it's looking very old and dirty.  The physical appearance of the campus is hurting.

review.author: Patrick C.
review.description: Much improved student environment compared to when I was a student there. Seems like they are building constantly but they need to improve their Witherspoon theater; you would have thought the people that designed it were only 4ft 8inches tall because the seats are uncomfortable with not much leg room.

review.author: Joseph M.
review.description: Don't expect much help from the various offices. Financial Aid will be especially annoyed with your presence. Watch out for the woman who looks like someone locked her in a tanning bed for days. She's got a bug up her butt.

review.author: Tim Y.
review.description: Very good school. Teachers that care. Two of our three children have graduated from Pisgah and our third has just started 7th grade.Our principal, Mark Guffey, is a huge asset to this school.

review.author: John L.
review.description: I'm a student at this school and I will say this is a great school out of the several schools I've attended. The teachers and staff are great.

name: Northeast Alabama Comm College Salon Institute

review.author: Kat F.
review.description: hated it here. full of racist/ homophobic/ transphobic staff and students. went to a protest a few weeks ago to support transgender students and saw staff laughing and talking with the homophobic students that started counter protesting. absolutely awful. a couple school shooting threats this year that caused lockdowns. counselors don't care about you. teachers hardly give a shit about their job but there are some that do and made it worth while. don't send your child here unless you want zero support for them UNLESS they can play a sport. then they actually give a shit.

review.author: Nick R.
review.description: garbage food, actually dooky. portion size for a toddler. like bruhhhhh we aee practically adults

review.author: Matthew G.
review.description: We are playing a concert here tonight and the facility is great!  The students we've met so far have been respectful, the place is clean and we are hoping for a full house. Thanks for hosting us!

review.author: Tyler R.
review.description: Worst school to enroll in! You are not treated well! If you're lucky, you'll get at least one good teacher. Otherwise, the teachers will lie about you and your grades and you will FAIL! Their activities are overpriced, their sites don't work so you have a maximum of a 5% chance of getting into your desired sport! They force you to take place in meaningless assemblies that last FIVE SECONDS, and the students absolutely suck when you're disabled like me. You have little to no friends. When you go into an IEP meeting for special needs like me, they set wondrous goals, and never get close to helping you complete them at all! The only students who get to go on field trips are students in choir and other musical activities, but this applies to the previously mentioned little to no chance of being able to join said activity! If you're seen with a seemingly dangerous item coming on campus, they take it away and never give it back. A PAIR OF GLOVES IS NOT A WEAPON! This school sucks overall. If you want to go to cal poly, OSU, or whatever, go to a better high school. *Atascadero high school in california* if you go to this school, good luck trying not to drop out.

review.author: R M.
review.description:
This organization has great outdoor classes that range in location from Lava Caves Nat. Monument to the California/Oregon coasts.

Some classes provide college credit or can be used for various certifications, others are just plain fun. One of the latter is the winter snow ecology course held on Mt. Ashland involving a trek on snow shoes, building a snow cave and looking for the tunnels of voles and other winter-active rodents.. Another fun "class" was the sunset photo hike to the summit of Mr. Elijah starting with a walk through wild flowers and pitcher plants and the drive partly up the mountain then a walk through forest, meadow, past an alpine lake and ending with a magnificent view of the Siskiyou Mountains.  Did we see the ocean on the far horizon? Some said yes, some said no.

Several classes are family oriented and there are also special ones for school groups and for teachers.

For those who need accommodations at Sema, there are yerts and a camping area, or a few miles away, some motels.

review.author: Mark W. G.
review.description: This place is INCREDIBLE. The volunteer staff is so friendly and the animals have wide-open spaces to roam. I took my 2-year-old son and he loved meeting Yak, the brown bear, along with the bald eagle and wolves. We will be revisiting when we next come through the area. Thank you for creating this space to rehabilitate wild animals.

review.author: Matt D.
review.description: A very nice place with knowledgeable and friendly staff.  It provides a unique experience that you are likely not to encounter anywhere else.  It's a short day trip however and not a major attraction, but worth it.

review.author: Jen A.
review.description: Awesome spot to stop if you're driving up or down the 5 in Oregon. There are lots of other "wildlife" attractions that seem very "Tiger King" esque. Not this place! These animals are all rescued and seem well taken care of. This is a perfect stop for all ages. It was one of the highlights of our trip!

review.author: Laura I.
review.description: I've grown up in Grants Pass and this little wildlife sanctuary has taken in multiple animals that were injured including skunks, owls, fawns, and birds that we've helped since childhood. Everyone is kind and friendly and they even work with the Irwin family, which is amazing! A must see. They could really use your business to help feed the animals and continue their work.

review.author: Paul N.
review.description:
I saw a program on TV about Steve Irwin's family and Wildlife  Images Rehabilitation & Education Center.  That prompted me to visit WIREC.  My wife and I really enjoyed the experience. 

The mountain lion came right up to the fence and was less than two feet away.  I could hear it breathing and saw his breath in the cold morning air. You are very close to the birds of prey also.  The bald eagle looked huge.  It was quite an experience for my wife and me.  

It is a little out of the way but worth it.  We were there mid January and they already had 10 new birds/animals they received for the year.  Some of them can be rehabilitated and released back into the wild.  Others must remain at the Center. Your visit will help them continue their great work.

review.author: R F.
review.description: Any wild life "rehabilitation" wildlife center that euthanizes perfectly healthy baby animals is a crap organization!! I will no longer support this organization. They are murderers!! The state and its employees really need to educate themselves when it comes to certain species!! Idiots!!

review.author: Dan D.
review.description:
First, let me state that we have been members of Wildlife images since 2011 and have made additional donations in that same time.
Yesterday, we went to drop off shredded paper and empty TP/paper towel rolls. We've routinely saved these items since they asked for these items a number of years ago. We called ahead to verify the need and were told to bring them over, we said we would and because of Covid, would drop the donation out of the way on the front porch.
We pulled up, and started to unload and "Cheryl" came out and unpleasantly asked us what we thought we were doing. We explained, and said we had called. Then she wanted us to carry them inside. We were masked up, but declined. She became agitated, and rudely told us to just take them home--"we don't want it and we don't need it". We left the items, and reminded her that we were members, she shouted "WELL THANKS FOR NOTHING" as we walked back to our truck and departed.
Prior to yesterday we have never had a bad experience at Wildlife images. We've routinely taken out of town visitors there, and all have loved their visits. Our visit yesterday left a bad taste, and all because "Cheryl" was nothing but mean and nasty to us when we were trying to help and had even called ahead to verify the items were needed.

review.author: Ray F.
review.description:
This non profit organization is dedicated to helping injured and orphaned wild animals make it in today's society. A 90% volunteer staff keeps the facility functioning.

Using a variety of fund raising methods, the guided tour is the most interactive, at a cost of about 10$ per person - this tour takes you as a group, on about an hour and a half leisurely walk or ride (electric carts available for a fee for those with mobility issues) through the park grounds. Where you will have up close and personal interaction with a variety of the facilities permanent residents. 

Several raptors and birds of prey, Gray wolves, bears, cougars, badgers, otters and bobcats are a part of the family here - several have been here for a decade or better. Most of these animals are domesticated, or habitualized  are unable to adapt back into the wild. 

The day of our visit, our tour had about 15-20 in our group and it was a hot summer afternoon so most of the animals were either sleeping or lazing around.

We did have great encounters with the cougar and the grizzle bears - they were right up on the fence in both cases and interacted with the guide and as such the group was a part of the action.

There is a gift shop as well as a membership information desk in the main building, and all funds raised go to help maintain the facility and the animals. So far to date for the year 2015, Wildlife Images had released 206 injured or orphaned animal back into the wild.

A worthwhile organization and well worth the drive out to Merlin.

A solid 4 Stars 

00266

review.author: Debbie B.
review.description: Great place, nice variety of animals.  Just be CAREFUL and check your receipt!  We very exactly told the girl, one adult and one child.  She rang up 2 adults and a child, and she was so busy trying to talk us OUT of going through Sunday because of smoke, my husband didn't catch it on the receipt.  Over and over, she said no employees would be out there, no one to help or explain anything, but there was plenty of employees, and they were 100% much nicer, and more customer friendly than the brunette at the desk.  So.....just ignore her, check your receipt, and have a good time wi5 the help of all the other employees.

review.author: Samara S.
review.description: At Wildlife Images Kiley our tour guide was knowledgeable and cheerful!  We came across a tortoise and his mate "coupling" loudly and she handled it with a sense of humor in front of the young ones in our tour group.  Kiley was also helpful in the gift shop after as well!  \n\nI hope when or if the guides come by our Grizzly and Wolf Discovery center when you are in Yellowstone.

review.author: Heather N.
review.description: Wildlife Images is a amazing nonprofit organization.  They care for all kinds of wild animals.  We saw many different birds hawks, vultures, owls and even a couple bald eagles.  My favorite animal was Clark the Cougar who was gotten as a pet and the owners had his tendons cut when he got big so now he can barely walk.  It was so sad.  He seemed very sweet purring and rubbing against the fence.  We also saw several bears, a couple wolves, a honey badger and many other animals.  Some I had never heard of.  They rehabilitate and release back into the wild the animals they can and those that are unable to be released either because of permanent injury or human imprintation can live at the facility permanently.  Our guide Eric did a great job of teaching us about each animal and how they came to be at the center.  He taught us about the effects of hunting, exotic pet ownership and wildlife legislation in an informative and factual way that didn't offend anyone on either side of the issue.  The facility itself is very nice.  There were several areas that they were building or upgrading.  Make a donation or buy something from the gift shop to show support.  My nephew goes to their summer day camp for kids and loves it.

review.author: Crystal L.
review.description:
An amazing facility-- it was an incredibly heart warming and inspirational experience.  Our tour guide who had only been working for Wildlife Images for a month and a half knew every animal and shared their story with us.  The critters and creatures brought here have been taken in from all over and have been assisted with their rehabilitation (sadly, most of the injuries were at the hands of people).  Wildlife gives a home to an impressive array of cougars, black bears, grizzly bears, birds of prey, and one seriously feisty badger, "Nubs".  

The animals are quite social and were interested in seeing visitors.  It's nice to see animals that live in spaces where trees are actually growing and their keepers are concerned for creating as 'normal' of an environment for them as possible.  The tour guide mentioned a few times that they work with other centers to help the social animals find mates to keep them company...even if that means sending them out.

The gift store itself is clean, well put together, and if you look for the picture of the grizzly bear sitting with a cat, you will find a story that will move you to TEARS.  If not tears, maybe your eyes will well up.  At any rate, this is a place you should absolutely visit, and genuinely feel great about supporting.

review.author: Amber P.
review.description: I wish I could give this place 5 stars as I LOVE wildlife images. I haven't been there in 15ish years and was really excited to share it with my family. Everything was clean and our tour guide seemed knowledgeable about the animals and facility. My husband myself and our two kids ended up with a pretty large group during our tour. There were really too many people to all go through the tour at the same time and get to appreciate what is there. There was another group with our tour and the older guy was making animal calls at all the animals while our guide was speaking preventing us from being able to hear what she was saying. After a little while the two kids with him began doing the same thing. It was very disruptive and frustrating as the tour guide said nothing to quiet them down.

review.author: Marina F.
review.description: Place was pretty cool, for the price, the tour was a little short, but the animals that we did see were neat. Would love to have seen more animals (especially the ones being rehabbed and not just the permanent residents) but I understand why this isn't allowed. Another couple joined us halfway through the tour and they were very annoying and obviously on a lot of drugs. When we left we noticed they had left a dog crying in the car that whole time. The guide was very friendly and knowledgeable about the animals.

review.author: Char W.
review.description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!! Great tours and very informative. If you are looking for something to do and or want to know more about all living creatures this is the place to go. Everybody is so very friendly and very very reasonable priced. Awesome gift store that is also reasonable priced. If you love and care about animals, you need to go and visit.  They're wonderfully loving to the animals. They do awesome work to help rehabilitate animals and return them to the wild. Those that are not able to survive in the wild will have a home there. The animals there in the facility are happy, healthy, well cared for and loved. \nI HIGHLY recommend going & touring. There are Wolves, Cougars, Black Bears, Grizzles, Bobcats, Raccoons, Owls big & small, Eagles, Hawks, Vultures a lot of types of birds, so many others I can't name them all. You'll meet Nestle who stared in a movie, you'll meet Nubs who will walk on a leash and harness. You'll also meet Scratch and Sniff two sibling who love to play with each other, you'll meet Baby who loves to play and is not a raccoon. \nPLEASE GO HAVE FUN!!!!! HELP THEM HELP ANIMALS!!!!

review.author: Carri K.
review.description:
I had the best time here. Our guild was very informative. When we started the tour it was just my Cousin and I, a few others joined along the way. It was a very small group so everyone was able to ask questions they had. You are able to get right up close to the animals, it is so amazing to be that close to Cougar and Bears. It was feeding time when we were there so it was interesting to watch them being fed. It was also frightening watching them stalk the girls as they would bring their food out. Wild Animals are amazing creatures. It is not often you get to observe them so closely. 
I love what they do at this facility. It must be such a satisfying job saving and helping these injured animals that would otherwise not be here. 
I wish some of the fencing was easier to see through. It is hard to take pictures of a lot of the animals because of hard to see through fencing. I realize why it is there, for our protection of course but there must be an easier way to provide safety for us and the animals and observation ease. 
Great Job Wildlife Images!

review.author: R M.
review.description:
Wildlife Images has two main purposes: education, primarily through its zoo operations and rehabilitating injured or orphaned animals.
As a zoo, it operates on the economical side with small cages for small animals and fenced enclosures for the large animals (all predators)  and guided-only tours. The volunteer docents vary in knowledge and personality; one old man needlessly insulted some members of our party.

Perhaps the saddest exhibit is the albino ground squirrel that incessantly runs around its small cage. The animal is obviously insane but its frantic antics provide amusement to visitors. 

A close up, unobstructed view is provided to some bald eagles and a sad-looking turkey vulture. You can also walk close to the wire fences to observe the bears, wolves and other predators.

For a couple of hundred dollars the staff will bring some animals to a school, organization or group and give a presentation. Special tours can be arranged, though I didn't have much luck getting one since the staff never got back to me about available dates.

Many sick, injured or orphaned baby animals are treated and, if they can survive on their own, released. However, taking an overall, less emotional approach, your money might be more effectively spent donating to a major conservation organization that will save endangered species and tens of thousands of other animals.

That being said, Wildlife images is a good place to bring youngsters to show them what the local wildlife looks like.

review.author: Beth S.
review.description: I took my nieces and nephew this afternoon. It is a fun and educational visit. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable. I look forward to visiting again.

review.author: Anne C.
review.description:
Check out the bald eagle who thinks she's all that (Miss Patty), a squirrel who loves to entertain (Cheerio), and a previous house-cougar (Clark). I don't want to give too much away- you have to see it for yourselves. 

I'll be honest, I started off disappointed. I saw animals in small enclosures, by themselves, but as we toured the place, we heard about what they were doing with the animals and it all made sense. It really is a great place and these people are doing such a service to animals that might otherwise be dinner for another, instead of an educational tool for us. While dinner is important, public education is more so in my mind. 

Make sure you read Erin B's and Nick Y's reviews- they echo what I would have told you. (No, I don't know them.)

review.author: Rina L.
review.description: Wildlife Images is a really special place to visit! We had a lovely tour from a passionate and well spoken guide, Chase. She was so knowledgeable about all the animals that were available for us to see. They genuinely care for these animals and it shows in how the staff discusses and educates the public on how they rescue these animals in hopes they can return to the wild!

review.author: Amanda R.
review.description: I was lucky enough to have my now 9 year old daughter with Crystal from age 2 to age 4, when she was head teacher at another Montessori school that has since closed. My willful child learned so much under Ms. Nott, from how to utilize her excess energy to how to deal with her classmates. I have been waiting for my youngest to be old enough to join Crystal at Little Hands.
