Every staff member my son has had has been fantastic!

If you need daycare, schooling, or both start here!

review.author: Branden L.
review.description: I toured here and loved it although I found a place that was closer to where I needed to be. The staff was great with the kids and the environment was very welcoming. From my first impression is recommend this place if it fits your and your kids needs.

review.author: Gordon L.
review.description: My daughter attended Snell's for two years. I loved the staff and the environment. I can't wait for my next child to be old enough to go to Snell's!

review.author: Vincent D.
review.description:
Kohl open school in Stockton, California.

 This school has been apart of my life for the last twelve years. My eldest daughter started to come to Kohl when she was in Kindergarten. She was here all the way till eighth grade. 

 My Son started started the same grade kindergarten till the eighth grade. 

My baby girl is still here at Kohl and started just like her siblings at the Kindergarten level. 

 We have so many beautiful memories here at this school. When they all were here . I would  love to  come and spend time with them during the after school program and have fun with them. My children never wanted to come home. All they wanted to do is play with their classmates. 

 I can go on and make this review long. But I'll keep it simple. 

 Here at Kohl, we always felt like being apart of one giant family. I was pretty close to all the teachers my children had and all of them are wonderful. 

 I have to say that Bud West our Principle is one of the best If not the best Principles in SUSD. 

 So I have four more years at Kohl to make some more beautiful memories. It's been a beautiful ride these last twelve years here at Kohl. Thank you 

Vincent D *VD* Enjoying the simple things in life

review.author: Austin O.
review.description: There are not words to explain how great this school is. I was a student (attended from preschool, before it was moved, all the way to 8th grade) and so were my two older siblings. The community, faculty and students are among the brightest in Stockton. If you track down some of the alumni you will find they are doing very well and credit it to the open education the school provides. Kohl will always have a special place in my heart.

review.author: Emma G.
review.description: As a Kohl student, my daughter has had the opportunity to participate for two years in an organization founded at Kohl, Student Stewards of the Lower Calaveras (SSLCR). They have an ongoing fieldwork project on a section of the Calaveras between the school, which is near Stagg HS, and the University of the Pacific. Their teacher and two retired university science professors are teaching them how to do real fieldwork. They distinguish native plants from invasive plants and identify (and plot on a map) all of the plant, insect, and animal species that they find. Last week, a volunteer group from Kohl planted some native species of plants on a Saturday. One student road his bike across town to get there. My daughter, who is part of the PR group in SSLCR, walked over to take pictures to document the event. Her class gives presentations to local organizations such as the Audubon Society and, later this year, they will visit a couple third-grade classes at another school. I think it is safe to say that this sort of thing does not happen at every school.\n\nThis is a small school where, as their theme song says, "everybody knows your name." Two or three grade levels are taught in the same classroom. Older students mentor younger students, and the students learn how to manage their time balancing "menu work" listed in the board (e.g., daily math) with ongoing projects such as SSLCR. They've been working this way for 46 years now and somehow have managed not to lose their soul during all those years when SUSD doubled down on direct instruction, corporate curriculum, and worksheet after worksheet. Now all of the employment trends point to the need for the types of skills and personal qualities that this school cultivates: responsibility, collaboration, problem solving, and emotional intelligence. Wake up, SUSD. You've had this gem for nearly half of century. It's time expand this model of project-based learning and give this school the recognition it deserves.

review.author: Sandy S.
review.description: My girls LOVE Mathnasium! The program motivates them and stretches them to think beyond our school district curriculum to apply math practically throughout day to day activities. We could not be more pleased with the South Barrington Mathnasium program!

review.author: Richard H.
review.description:
My son has been going to Mathnasium to supplement his Geometry instruction.

We have seen my son's grades improve since going to Mathnasium.  I guess that is the bottom line when you go to a tutor center.

The director who runs it, Jennifer, is super nice and flexible.

The two main instructors who work with my son, Matt and Nick, are able to explain Geometry in a way that my son relates to.

It is one thing to be able to explain a subject.  it is another to be able to teach it to someone else.  I am really impressed by the South Barrington Mathnasium location.

review.author: Jacky A.
review.description: I work for Club Z! and just want to say it really is a great company to work for! I've tutored high school students in physics, pre-calc, Spanish, and ACT/SAT Prep. It's great working with students who really want to learn, and I have met many nice parents/family members along the way  I love seeing that "ah ha!" expression on a student's face once a problem makes sense. Often times a student would say, "Ugh I hate these king of problems," and after going over it with them, it gives me joy to hear the student say, "that wasn't that bad actually."

review.author: Dale S.
review.description:
Adorable little student restaurant right in the middle of the campus. It's a bit hidden, but well worth searching for!
I took my son who is a student here so we could spend a little time together one day between his classes and I was absolutely amazed. 
The service was so friendly! The decor is nice with linen table cloths and napkins; you feel like you've been whisked away to a little  5 star restaurant. The prices are more than reasonable and everything we ordered was delicious! Many looked like little works of art. 
There were a few issues with organization, time management, etc of course but that is to be expected in a learning environment. 
I am so glad we found this little gem and I can't believe it wasn't packed full of people. I guess the secret's not out yet. I will be back the next chance I get!

review.author: Teresa C.
review.description:
This is the unsung jewel of Stockton!  (My little private oasis)

These students cook their hearts out.  There's white linen tablecloths.  There's light music.  There's even a few outdoor tables complete with a sun-umbrella.  

Sometimes you get a novice server but they're never rude.  The food is a leap of faith:  sometimes they knock it out of the park and on a few occasions it was average.  But I've always LOVED something (or more than a few) things on my plate.  They are much more accomodating regarding dietary restrictions, the veggies are fresh and so are the desserts!  

The desserts are to die for...you MUST leave space for dessert or else you'll hate yourself as you drool over something about to be devoured at another table.  

Last week I had a great chicken tagine and for the sweet stuff -  chocolate lava cake with raspberry drizzle...OMG it was LUSCIOUS!  

Also, I took a friend to lunch here and as it was her birthday I asked the servers to sing "Happy Birthday" when they brought her dessert out.  They did one better, they sang and wrote "Happy Birthday" on her plate in chocolate!   

You are NOT going to get this kind of food value in Stockton, I guarantee you.  

Hey - tip well, these students pool their tip $$$ for an end-of-the-school-year trip to the Bay for a culinary tour.  

INSIDERS TIP:  They have a Student Chef Hot Plate Express inside the cafeteria.  For $5.50, you get a hot entree with a carb and veggie -  the most bang for your buck!  Again, I've never been disappointed.  They also have a cold counter where they have sandwiches and salads.  

No - they haven't paid me off.  They deserve all the accolades and then some!

Here's a link to the menu, but if you take my corner table by the window I'll have to kill you.  Slowly.  I'm just kidding.  Well, not really. :)

http://www.deltacollege.edu/dept/foodservice/student_chef/menu.html

review.author: Don I.
review.description: Best bargain for a white table cloth restaurant.\nFood is tasty and service is very good.\nDownside is the limited opening days and hours.

review.author: Jay M.
review.description:
"Fool me once, shame on...shame on you; fool me, you can't get fooled again" 
- George Bush

Advanced idiocy causes one to say the above, as keen discernment would cause one to eat at the Student Chef Restaurant.

Dis food is bushi; and the patio set up is tight...

Gourmet food for under $10...hell yes.

Here is a sample menu:
________________________
Entrees served with choice of Soup or Salad  (Soup or Salad available $3.50 ala carte.)

Cream of Victoria Island Asparagus Soup
or
Classic Spinach Salad
or
House Salad

Spice Rubbed Loin of Pork
w/Sage and Apple, Corn Bread Pudding
and Grilled Asparagus

Individual Seafood Gratin
Bay Shrimp, Scallops, Prawns and White Fish
w/Rice Pilaf and Spinach Saute
Portabello Mushroom Wellington
w/Pepper Jack Cheese Sauce
and Grilled Vegetables
__________________________
Desserts $3.00
-----
Angel Food Cake
w/ Fresh Strawberries and Field Berries
or
Summer Melon Sorbet Cocktail 

Coke, Diet Coke, Sprite, Iced Tea, Coffee or Hot Tea
$1.25
"To go" orders accepted until 10:30 - dial: 5099
__________________________

You straight up stooPido  if you don't eat here.
Food: 5
Ambiance: 5
Professionalism: 5
Racism: 0
White Folks: 4/5
Brown Servers: 5/5

review.author: Stefanie Q.
review.description: If you're at Delta, explore a bit further into lower Danner, tucked in the corner behind the cafeteria, to find Student Chef. If you're going to bother splurging on buying a school lunch because you left the brown bag at home, I highly suggest shelling out a few extra bucks here rather than eating in the cafeteria. The food is fresher, tastier, and seemingly healthier; plus you're helping students refine their food industry skills. I've been twice so far this semester, and loved the relish that comes w/ the potstickers; the Cornish game hen w/ butternut squash & spinach was tasty too. Keep it coming!

review.author: Alma M.
review.description: Perfect gourmet food without the ridiculous prices. I enjoy coming here the servers are great, the food is delish, and the best part I'm not broke at the end of the meal.

review.author: Scot M.
review.description:
You want a smaller university that is has an amazing campus that has that large campus feel, this is the place. 

Tons of educational options here to choose from. Hit up and open house or just come take a tour. 

You will love it.

review.author: Yahary B.
review.description: An institution with a variety of interesting courses and great professors. The environment makes for a safe and enjoyable experience.

review.author: Sabrina S.
review.description: If you're going to going to school for anything in the medical field, this university is rated top in our state.

review.author: Dave S.
review.description: A number of local portrait photographers use the University as a backdrop for their photos. Always beautiful in every season, the campus hosts Morris Chapel, a favorite for wedding photographers. \nMy forté isn't people portraits, but architecture and flora, both of which are plentiful here.

review.author: Jennifer Z.
review.description: I've had many people in my close network who enjoy UOP for its community mission and graduate programs. The Dental Program and Pharmacy Program are among the top in health professions. The location is ideal and best for families especially with its close distance to the city and Sacramento. Consider enrolling your kids and applying to their graduate programs. 100% guarantee the university takes good care of your children, their college experience and ability to get a job afterwards (job security).

review.author: Christine H.
review.description:
Have you ever watched Gilmore Girls?
Me neither.
But I get a feeling that the school in the show looks like UOP.
UOP literally reminds me of a brick castle (ya literally have to cross a bridge over a raging river?) community...that happens to have a lot of people who want to become pharmacists or dentists (I say this cause everyone I know from UOP fall under these two categories (with the exception of those music majors and such.

The campus is pretty small and isolated. The outside community is the polar opposite of UOP. UOP kinda looks like a miniature version of Harvard (never been there...but I just googled it, so I think you can trust me). When I went to the Chevron just five minutes outside of UOP though, I felt like I was back in a more ghetto version of San Jose's Alum Rock (don't worry, I grew up there-ish). 

But anyways, I never was a student here, so I have nothing else to say. Toodles.

review.author: Joey B.
review.description:
Never been to this college before, but knew a friend who graduated here. And never been to her campus till my friend's graduation day because I as well was going to school full-time and had a semi-part time job to pay off my student loans as quick as I can before interest kicks in while going to school full time as well.. We both understand, but kept in touch via FaceTime or when we both visit back home almost at the same time for the holidays to catch up. 

Boy, during graduation day, I must say what a huge crowd of Pharmacists and Future Doctors... Very impressed! :) Great school to go to if you're majoring in the medical field, other than that, look else where, since University of the Pacific is well known to have a good reputation for future students majoring in the Pharmacist Field.

Ive always wanted to go to UOP back several years ago as an under graduate, but the price to go to this school deterred me away when I did my research online without even visiting the Dean nor the campus itself in person... But after now just scrolling down to READ ALL the under 3 rating reviews or less... I see a clearer picture of how some students felt cheated out of their education. 

Im not going to voice any more of my opinion about this University since Im not a student nor didn't go to this school, but great campus though. And am definitely listening to the people who posted THE REAL WORLD issues here on THE PRICE IT COST to go to this school... Some scary stuff! 

I advice any new prospect students, is to do some research, read all the 3 or less star reviews, and that'll paint a clearer picture if you think its worth it to go to this school, open up a student loan, and be forever in debt paying that loan back. 

Anyways, good luck on your endeavors future doctors if you decide to go to this school. :)

PS: Was told that 1/2 the students here find their husbands/wifes here, and can get a discount going to the chapel if you're a UOP student.... BONUS yo! "May I pronounce you, Husband and Wife, you may now kiss."

review.author: Shawn L.
review.description: Very tasty food except for the part where the students of the University purposely steal food from others.

review.author: Irina V.
review.description: I was a vendor at San Joaquin Home and Garden show. The gymnasium building where the show was held was nice and comfortable. But I geuss not so easy to find because there were not many attendees that came to the show. It was more vendors than customers in the building. At least that what it felt like. But that might not be the University's fault but more like the show organizers fault. But besides the show its a beautiful campus

review.author: Nate T.
review.description: Great campus and swim facility. Just one thing, why don't you have shade cover for bleachers? The sun rises in the east and blinds the #$%^ out of your eyes.

review.author: Lyn G.
review.description: If you are thinking of taking Calculus I with Prof. Mouchumi Bhattacharyya (aka, the Bad Explainer) avoid this class and search for another. Bad explainers use roundabout methods of explaining the solution to a problem, have disorganized lectures and do not highlight key terms. Professors who stink at explaining things might also be too smart for their own good. They think that if they understand the material, their students are bound to understand it as well. If she was a good professor she should make herself OPENLY available during office hours, hold question-and-answer sessions when reviewing homework and give THOROUGH explanations when you get an answer wrong.

review.author: Revolutionair E.
review.description:
No, no, no, NO! You're all WRONG! Please read this, especially if you are a prospective student.

I was at UOP for four years of undergraduate, plus a couple years of graduate school. The good part is that I've got two valuable degrees and a small handful of good memories. But believe me, I've seen a lot of what's changed at UOP and I know for a fact that it's not even close to being worth it. Not anymore. So don't post here with your "The commencement ceremony was great! Five stars!" or "I was here in '97 and I loved it!" or "I made so many friends!" You're influencing other people's decisions and it's wrong.

Here's why:
I'm not sure that you all understand just how expensive this school is. You will spend $40,000-$50,0000 per year for undergraduate and $50,000-60,000 per year for graduate (think housing, meal plan, books, tuition, graduation/admin costs, parking fees). I was personally mislead (maybe even lied to) by a Dean when he told me in person that I could probably do graduate school for $30k/year. I kid you not. I paid $60k/year. Goodluck getting a scholarship to cover that.

So how do you justify these costs? Quality of education? If you major in anything but some type of Engineering, Comp Sci, Accounting, or maybe Biochem you're S.O.L. and will have a very hard time finding a job. Pharmacy almost made this list because UOP does have a crazy hard and reputable pharma program. But there's very few quality pharma jobs out there from what I hear. I was fortunate enough to choose a decent major, but I still had a brutal time getting a good job. I suspect it's because during interviews I said "I went to UOP," and got one of two responses: "Never heard of it." or "Oh, University of Phoenix Online. You don't say." 

Sure, some of the professors (maybe 20-30%) are exceptional. But they're also the most busy. I found that most professors either needed to retire, dislike their students, or simply don't have any passion. It's a disgrace. And if you think they get paid well because tuition is high then you're wrong. In fact, I've heard many of them voice complaints about how little they're paid. I spent a couple of summers taking courses at a different college and I was stunned by how much clearer their instruction was. And guess what? It literally cost me less than 5% of what I paid at UOP.

Alright, so it's not in-classroom education that's worth it. 

Maybe UOP makes up for it's costs with a vibrant social scene? I was in a Greek house at UOP for many years. It was great - everyone had a good time, nothing bad happened because we were careful and responsible. Unfortunately, this wasn't the case with many other houses. There were multiple alleged rape incidents over the years. The school shut everything down. The bulk of the party scene has since moved off-campus where the school doesn't have to accept legal liability. 

This would've been fine if UOP wasn't in Stockton, which is unanimously agreed to be a disastrous place to live. There are currently over 70 gangs in Stockton. 70. It's bankrupt. There is no police force. People still get mugged on the bridge near north campus. Granted, the campus police do a decent job of controlling what they can, but it's no joke. Sure, you can go to clubs and do sports on-campus. That helps. But overall it's a big stretch to call it socially "thriving." More like high school part two unless you want to risk getting robbed and shot by a gang (this actually happened to students I know).

So where does the school's $204 million in annual revenue go? Go ahead and look at their website. I don't know what "General Administration" and "General Institutional" are, but for a combined $101 million dollars I doubt it's doing much for anybody except the people that run UOP. And $62.5 million in financial aid? So the school costs students a lot because it's aiding students? How does that make sense? Probably just means a free ride for somebody's relatives.

One last thing I want to talk about is the school's technical department. UOP's internet has about 90% uptime. It's horrendous. Most organizations with this many resources have 99% uptime. Add to that their awful support and technical management. I had my PC broken into by one of their staff without my permission and they literally broke it. I didn't even get an apology.

Look, my point is that we should be more upset about schools like this. I didn't get to where I am because I went to a good school. I got here by reading on my own, and doing real things in my field, and working nonstop, and figuring it out without UOP's help. Don't let this happen to you.

Prospective students: Don't go here unless you're ready to suffer. You've been warned.
Former students: Please complain. Talk about it. Warn others. 
School officials: Lower tuition. Help students prepare for real jobs. Oh yeah, and stop $@^&ing calling me for money because you won't get another cent, bloodsuckers.

review.author: Jerline H.
review.description:
I LOVED PACIFIC! Still love it! 
I had gone to the orientation for University of Arizona and hated the weather and called UOP in July asking them if I could still come. 
Sure. 
Do I still have my scholarship? 
Yes. 

I was in for the best 5 years of my life. 

It's a private school where everybody knows about everybody else's dirty business. After two years at this school you will most likely know everybody on campus. College is what you make of it, and with the pre-pharm schedule I was able to rush and pledge a sorority, two professional fraternities and join a dance crew in my two years of undergrad. It's do-able and I've had friends who have pledged a sorority and fraternity in the same semester. You just need to put your mind to it. 

Pacific is fun! Things like fashion shows, sorority and fraternity charity events, TEDx, comedians and singers at the Lair, and rock guarding (actually rockguarding is not fun) are all happening right on campus! But there are also the lame parts, like not having a car, everybody cheating in classes, gaining the freshmen 30, and so forth.  

Granted, us folks in the accelerated program sometimes wonder why anybody would pay so much at a private school to get a major in say, Art. (I love art! My dad wouldn't let me go to a UC because he was afraid I'd change my major to art). Otherwise, the 3 years of pharmacy school is great: there are tons of ways to get involved with leadership opportunities, research, make friends, and continue on with the profession. 

Stockton itself is also not as bad as everybody says it is. They only say so because they're so scared that they haven't been anywhere outside of campus. There are ballet classes in Stockton, really good restaurants in Lodi, wine festivals and so forth. College is what you make of it. If I could do it over again, I would choose Pacific every time.

review.author: Jessica G.
review.description:
I love the University of the Pacific!!!
This is because of all it's great resources such as a huge library (3 Stories) filled with primary sources (From John Muir and Stagg...just to drop a few names) at the Western Americana section! Also they provide students with study rooms, even electronic journals and books that can be accessed anywhere online!! 

Not only that they have great well-educated professors who actually care and take time to help you in your educational needs! I had a professor who had her emails sent to get Blackberry.. (This was before iPhones haha ) and once she replied back to be in a record of a minute!!! Now that's dedication!

They offer small class sizes which can be from 8 to 90 (in the case of a bio g.e class, but I have never seen that limit reach before).

Overall, I am very happy being a tiger! Go UOP!

review.author: Karen G.
review.description:
I love UOP!  It looks like an Ivy League college but it is located in Stockton.  I love the campus, the small classes, Greek system and the great education I received.

I made some really great friends as a student and have some great memories.  I remember trying to decide which dorm to live in freshman year.  A good friend who was a student at UOP told me Grace Covell was THE place to live.  I also remember going through rush, getting my bid and initiation.  Fraternity parties and exchanges were definite highlights.  I was both excited and sad during graduation.  No more safety net of college.  

I look back fondly at my years at UOP and at times, wish I could go back and relive those days.

review.author: Ron L.
review.description:
This review is for the commencement exercise held on May 16. 

University of the Pacific did a great job with the commencement exercise. There is a general session for everyone, plus after the general session, each school had its own smaller session. 

After parking at the campus, there were lots of signs directing you to the ceremony. There were also information booths staffed with ambassadors and maps to help you navigate. Restrooms were also well signed. 

Now the ceremony. It was approaching 100 degrees, luckily we found a seat in the shade. A huge plus were the refreshment tents, offering free sodas, water, and fruit. They also handed out fans for souvenirs, which came in handy. 

Best part was the short speeches. We got out of there in an hour! All university graduations should be like this.

review.author: Gene B.
review.description: They have a very nice campus I must say, but a majority of the male students have Mohawks which made me feel out of place. My dog however did not feel out of place. He enjoyed playing on the grass doing his b-boy dance as other students passed by. He is such a show off and enjoys the attention. \n\nBy the looks of things I believe they have a great program here. The classrooms are nice and well equipped. The staff are friendly and very detailed on what to expect out of campus life at UOP.

review.author: Leo L.
review.description: UOP has the worst internet on earth....i m currently a freshmen and the internet disconnect averagely every 20 mins... i mean they charge us a really high tuition...do we really deserve a crappy internet? Even my professors complain about it all the time.....seems the internet has been very unstable for a long time....have no idea why the school does not fix it...

review.author: Pacific V.
review.description: Disclaimer: the review I am writing is geared towards the sciences.\n\nI went here for my B.S. in Biological Sciences and just graduated in May. I really enjoyed my time here at Pacific. The professors are all so nice and willing to help their students. The class sizes are small, even for general science courses. My friends at larger universities are always complaining about how there are too many people in their general science courses, so they can't get to know their professors. Then when it comes time for them to get a letter of recommendation from a professor for their professional program, they don't know who to approach. This definitely isn't a problem at UOP. I know all of my professors, and talk to them in office hours all the time. When I applied for medical school, I was able to get letters from 1 professor in the Mathematics Department, 1 from the Chemistry Department, and 2 from the Biology Department. Another thing that my friends complain about a lot is not being able to get a research position at their university. At UOP, I was able to obtain a research position during my second semester there. I also got a fellowship grant and a departmental award to fund my research. Right now as someone who just graduated with a bachelors, I also have 2 scientific publications, so I am very satisfied with this university.

review.author: Stacey P.
review.description:
3.5 rating

Seriously this school is only good if you're coming here for the pre-pharmacy or pre-dentistry program since it is accelerated.  I don't know why english, history, etc students would even want to major here.  The night life is not that good here and we get emails on a weekly basis on how a student was held up at gun point or was almost raped while running around campus.  It is a beautiful school but I don't think that should be it's winning factor.

The undergrad science teacher are pretty horrible and the chemistry department is constantly getting new teacher because we never get anyone thats worth keeping.  One of my past chemistry teachers even lied on her resume about her credentials.  GOOD JOB FILTERING UOP.

Even though I'm pretty much ranting on and on but I did make some pretty great friends here.  I am currently in pharmacy school and it's a lot better because the classes are more interesting and the curriculum was just updated 2 years ago so it's up to date.

p.s. I think the about 1/5 students find their husband or wife here. EEEEP! And you do get a discount on the chapel if you a UOP student so I guess you could get married here too!

review.author: Gregoria T.
review.description: I'd give this place "0" stars if I could. I really thought this would be a great daycare for my 2 year old granddaughter. If you have children (toddlers) with any behaviors whatsoever I'd think twice about enrolling them here. This place has no patience or compassion for children who may possibly be on the spectrum, but are to young to be diagnosed. They didn't try to see how they could accommodate her to see what works for her, what intrigues her, what she's interested in so that she could be calm and quiet during nap time. They just gave up! According to them nap time is mandatory, and she was being disruptive. You can't force a child to go to sleep! God forbid your child be on a different sleep routine and not as quiet as a mouse at this place, they will just get rid of them. Children who are different didn't ask to be born that way. They kindly told my daughter on multiple occasions that maybe she should look into another daycare that could possibly help her. And made my daughter and granddaughters life that much more difficult. This just saddens me. I will never recommend this heartless place to any family.

review.author: Eileena T.
review.description: My daughter just had her last day at kindercare yesterday 03-14-22 and had started just in late august of last year. In the beginning everything seemed fine, but then the complaints started coming in. Before I go into detail I must start by saying my daughter is on the spectrum of autism and I will admit she is a bit difficult but what 2 year old isn't. The first complaint about my daughter I had received from them was that their nap time was "mandatory " and if their kiddos didn't take a nap then it would be a problem. They had told me that my daughter was having a hard time taking naps and would disrupt other kids and that supposedly other parents were complaining about why their kids were looking so tired so basically they were trying to blame my daughter for other kids not getting sleep. Then their second excuse was that she would have "rough days" and be disruptive during circle time etc. Not once was I told that they tried accommodating her all I received were complaints. Sometimes when I would drop and pick her up I felt an unwanted feeling towards my daughter which feels horrible for a parent and no parent should feel this. I know my daughter is no angel but I believe every kid deserves a chance. When we had our tour for the center before my daughter started we were told that they do help with potty training at the center and to just let them know when she's ready, that was not the entire truth, I had told one of the main ladies who was in the class that I was starting potty training at home and if they could help do it while my daughter was in their care and her response was with a unwelcoming expression "no I dont think were going to do that yet" completely shut me down and didn't even consider it ! One of the main ladies at the center had also mentioned that if these problems were to continue then their only option would be to un enroll her. So I had no other choice but to find her a new daycare to go to. Once I had found a new daycare and I explained my situation to them they even said themselves that the whole situation from kindercare was unfortunate and that they actually have a kid who is on the spectrum there and they do everything in their power to accommodate him hooray to them!! Thats how kindercare should be but I guess they just want the easy way out. On the other hand when I told one of the administration ladies that my daughter would be leaving soon her reaction was " im so happy, oh no I didn't mean it like that" and her eyes lit up like a weight was off her shoulders. How unfortunate and disrespectful is that. I felt offended. So to end my rant I just want to warn parents if you are thinking of enrolling your child and they are on the spectrum or even a bit difficult be aware of what happened to me and my daughter.

review.author: Jonalyn V.
review.description:
KinderCare Stockton has been apart of our family for over 15 years. They are absolutely AMAZING teachers and staff.  Cleaniness & safety is their highest priority. They have grown with our children and have become like family. 

If you are hesitant about childcare, KinderCare is the BEST in town. This is not any typical daycare. My children come home learn new things everyday. You can keep up with their daily activities with photos and class posts right from their classroom teacher through out the day. 

 I have had all my 5 children attend KinderCare  Stockton from infant to school age. It always gives piece of mind, that my children were always in great, excellent, caring hands.

Thank you Stockton KinderCare Teacher & staff. Our family will forever be great full for caring for our children through out the years. Est. 2003-2021

review.author: Kayla H.
review.description: I highly recommend Kindecare to any and everyone. At this facility we are treated like family. My oldest has been there since he was 2 he is now 8 turning 9 . I can't trust just anyone with my children and I trust them with all 3! I love them so much ! They are truly a second family to us ! I couldn't have asked for anything else I am truly blessed to know all the staff there ,they are so good with my kids! I love them

review.author: Cameron J.
review.description: Hands down best daycare in Stockton! Always flexible, staff is friendly and my kids never want to leave!

review.author: Nicole M.
review.description: My kiddos have been attending kinder care for3 years now and it's truly become family! The all woman staff have been amazing in teaching, playing and keeping my kids focused on their studies. Highly recommended daycare in the Stockton Area.

review.author: Michelle F.
review.description: I recently received a class schedule (non-credit) brochure in the mail from Harper College and found a mosaic class taught by artisan and glass artists Urii  Guchenia and Nathalie who has her very own studio in Willowbrook. The class was very inexpensive and well worth it! Kristin the librarian was very efficient in sending us a friendly email reminder along with the campus map to find the building where the class was. The class was held in "The Make Shop" within the library. All supplies were furnished and setup for us. Nathalie and Urii gave a us brief history of glass mosaics and were so helpful while we created our pieces. They had a vast array of glass tiles in every color imaginable! It was so much fun and gave us all a whole new appreciation of mosaic artisanry!

review.author: Steve B.
review.description:
Smart is not what it used to be. 

Anne with the Doctorate decided to throw away the Commercial & Residential Inspection program away because she did not understand practical matters. She should not be engaged in matters that effect the public.

When are we as people and tax payers going to look at a Junior College as an entity that should serve the public?

A two year degree should prepare a person to earn a living - anything other than that is failure and stupidity.

Over educated bureaucrats who do not understand their purpose need to be removed from these positions. BTW - I said this directly to "Dr." Anne. 

Where's Dr. Dre when You need him?

review.author: Karyn S.
review.description:
I'm an Alumnus, and proud to be. I've scanned some of the negative reviews, and having attended a 4 year school after getting my associate's degree, I can address some the issues mentioned and relate them to another community college or university.  I had a great time, made great friends, had amazing classes and teachers, and even participated in extracurriculars. I've gone back, post graduation, to take some continuing ed classes, as well as to meet with the career center. I would recommend this school to anyone. 

TEACHERS
I attended Harper for 3 years, and took classes across a variety of subjects, disciplines, etc. Yes, I had some weird teachers (my sociology teacher wasn't a bad teacher, but he was super weird and I found his approach to be... weird. However, I still learned a lot and ultimately enjoyed the class), I had some bad teachers (my chemistry teacher was an adjunct, and not awesome). I also had some amazing teachers, including some who are still at Harper. Bad teachers (or teachers you don't get along with) are not unique to Harper, or any school. Adjuncts in general are underpaid, and the one adjunct I had was a high school teacher who drove to Harper to teach after school. Yeah, he was sometimes late, but then again, so was I - and for the same reason, traffic. One of the benefits of college is that you often have options for which teacher/section - do your research and talk to other students/teachers/consult online review websites. 

COST/WITHDRAWING
Harper was far cheaper than the 4 year school I attended, which is one of the reasons I started at Harper (that and to find out what I wanted to major in). My average cost at Harper was, if I remember, roughly $2-$4k a semester for full time. University was $15 - $20k per semester for full time. In terms of policies related to dropping a class - every school has their own dropping/refund policies, and they are always clearly stated on the school's website/in their materials. I think when I attended, you were allowed to drop/switch sections with no penalty/a refund for the first week of semester/class. After that time, you could drop (but still had to pay) for another 8 weeks (example) and after that, you weren't allowed to withdrawal without it showing up on your transcript (so that you couldn't reach the last week, realize you weren't going to get the grade you wanted, and drop with no penalty). 

Every college/university I have attended (at least 4), have had a similar structure. Drop with refund/not on your transcript by X. Drop with no refund, not on your transcript by Y. Drop with it on your transcript as a W by Z. No drops allowed after that. None of them allowed a partial refund, you either dropped in time for a refund, or you didn't. This is normal, and standard.

PARKING
Yes, certain buildings hold more classes/are more populated and trying to park in the lots closest to the building can be difficult. There is ALWAYS parking available, it just may not be the closest to your building. Lots on the backside campus, like Lots 12, 13, and 14 always had spots available. ALWAYS. If the complaint is that it's too long a walk to class, or between buildings, it is comparable or better than other community colleges I've been to, and a standard university. Most universities charge for parking, and the lots are often far away. Walking is good for you, it's exercise, and you're going to have to walk around no matter where you attend school. That is not a Harper issue.

review.author: Jen S.
review.description:
Fast track program rip off! 
Advisors don't advise.
I had a professor that has ZERO tolerance for late assignments in class and on line. The on line work is time stamped and there are no exceptions for late work. 
0 points is what you'll get.  Watch out for this especially on the fast track program. I had to withdrawal because her homework assignments were worth more points than an actual test. If you fall behind in this program there's really no recovering and now your money is gone too. I also called the advisor and she was "not aware of how the program is run." 
Does that even make sense?
 How can you advise about something you don't even know about?? 
Took my money and didn't care.

review.author: Bernadette P.
review.description: I can't say enough good things about Harper.  Our son requires special accommodations because of his learning disability and unlike other community colleges, we considered Harper has a robust accommodations department staffed with experienced professionals who are truly vested in his success.

review.author: Mayra S.
review.description:
Gez, how do I wish I would have gone here straight out of high school and not COD. Unfortunately I was out of district when I graduated from high school.

I was turned off by community college when I went to COD I felt like I was just tossed into school. I didnt understand what I was doing and lacked guidance. I came from immigrant parents so, I really didn't have anyone to help me through my decision making since they never went to college. There wasn't an orientation or supporting staff that helped guide me I was just "there". I took a different route and went to vocational school feeling that was the choice for me.

Fast forward to now, recently I decided it was time to give college a try again so I showed up to Harper (Yes!! this time I'm in district) and told them about myself, my career background and what I wanted out of college. Every single step of the way they have provided me with assistance and support. I went to admissions, filled out paperwork, registered. Then I took placement tests, as I've been out of school for many years. I Then went to orientation, met with an adviser who helped me pick my classes. Next thing you know Im a college student! 

I look forward to attending my classes, my professors so far are great. I can tell they are genuinely interested in helping me, love what they do, and make me feel comfortable. Looking forward to a couple more years at Harper.

review.author: Bridget Jack J.
review.description:
I just completed an 18-credit Human Resources Certificate via the Fast Track program. From mid-September '15 through mid-May '16, I spent my Tuesday nights from 6 PM - 10 PM taking classes at the Harper Professional Center in Schaumburg. I had to drop out of the last scheduled class in the cohort due to travel plans in June '16, and Harper stepped in and created an independent study section of another HR class just so that I could finish with my cohort by July '16. 

The pros: 

- The Fast Track office is really helpful and professional
- Two of the four professors that I had were fantastic, and a third was decent. I have a bachelor's degree and a master's degree and that I found two of the most enjoyable lecturers of my long educational career here at this little community college is pretty impressive
- My June travel was career-related and I think they showed a lot of caring for me as a single mother and a busy professional by creating an independent study class just for me so that I could graduate
- My cohort was great. We had two professors tell us that we were the most enjoyable class they'd ever had, and a third professor liked us so much that she seized us for three of our classes and tried to get us for a fourth (more on that in a second). I made friends here that I think I'll keep in touch with for years, and it was the cohort model---keeping us together for back-to-back classes---that made that possible. 
- The schedule allowed me to keep classes away from work and still take care of my kids. 
- The Rita & John Canning Women's Program paid for ALL of my textbooks and tuition and fees because I am a single mother. That's all six 3-credit classes and the books. (Harper actually gave me my last textbook for free because the textbook company sent them a sample, which was nice of them. We didn't have to use women's program funding for that one.)

The cons: 

- We were paired with the same teacher for 3 out of 6 classes, and she tried to snag our cohort for a 4th class, but another teacher signed up for us first. Most of us found this teacher to be frustrating and difficult and would not have wanted more than 1-2 classes with her; we wanted to pull our hair out when we saw we would have a third class with her. There was another HR cohort that met at the exact same time for the exact same classes, but Harper adamantly refused to let any of us switch to the other cohort. Harper really needs to change some policies in order to ensure variety in cohort schedules. 
- There is a weird textbook racket at Harper. Professors are required to assign really expensive books from companies like McGraw-Hill, even if they think they are terrible textbooks and don't want to use them. New editions are frequently released and the bookstore seldom sells used or buys back your books. 

In the end, 10 of the 16 members of my cohort graduated on-time, and several others should be done in the fall, which is not a bad ratio. Overall my experience with Harper was a good one and I am so pleased with my HR certificate and the efforts that Harper faculty made towards helping me succeed. If I still live in the northwest suburbs area in 8 years, I would be honored if my daughter chose to pursue an Associate's at Harper.

review.author: Christopher L.
review.description: The good: The curriculum and teaching is good. It will prepare you for university level courses.\n\nThe bad: The school is too fuckin massive to move from class to class. Parking is a pain in the ass,  having to walk half a mile from the lot to class, and once class is over, the next class could be so far away that you would have to walk to the parking lot again to drive your car and deal with the parking bullshit again.

review.author: Steven S.
review.description:
I am so saddened to see all these negative reviews. (especially the one just because of slow internet)

Due to family circumstances I had to drop University and work. 2 years later, getting back into school led me to Harper. For my Associates Degree, I only had one teacher that proved an issue and was fired thus removing said issue for future students. I had a few adjunct faculty members along the way and had no issue, save for the previously mentioned. Most of my teachers though, had their Ph.D and quite a few also taught part-time at the larger universities. 

I felt challenged and really ready for University again thanks to Harper. I got great grades, joined their Honors Club and their chapter of the International Honors Society, Phi Theta Kappa. I got involved, I created relationships with teachers, and I loved my experience. 

From several friends of mine, their Nursing Program is one of the best 2-year RN programs around. Their dental hygienist program is also apparently quite competitive and great. 

If you value education but cannot quite afford the big ticket price of a 4-year university, start at Harper and get more than your money's worth.

review.author: Tammy P.
review.description: Harper College is the worst!!!!  I had to drop a course due to medical reasons the second week of class. I Completed an appeal and it was denied!!!  I have to pay 1600 for the class!!  Most college will take percentage not whole cost!!!  I am saddened by this system. Students pay enormous amounts to get an education and they are required to pay total amount of a course they dropped 2 weeks into course. If Harper really appreciates students This would not happen. I am 22 live on my own and pay my own school like many others. This makes me  feel no one wants students to come ahead in their future   Thanks

review.author: Carla L.
review.description:
I couldn't have asked for a better experience at college.  I studied Fashion Design and must say that the program is top notch and you get an amazing set of creative professional professors that care about the students 110%.

Harper has consistently produced year after year winners in the Chicago Student design scene and the program is so good Harper Design students compete regularly on an international level in Paris as well.  Need I say more?

Besides the excellent design program to get my degree I did have to take plenty of academic courses that were quite excellent which I had already known but it was emphasized even more when I transitioned into University and noticed some of the classes I was required to take weren't as good as the ones at Harper.

Great College.

review.author: Jack K.
review.description: I attended this school for one semester. While at this school, the best experiences I had were neutral. The grounds are nice and well kept, but there are a lot of problems with the way the university operates under the hood. First, some of the adjunct faculty are not of the best quality. My statistics professor was always late. She also made transphobic remarks on multiple occasions and was generally unkind to the students. I can't imagine how uncomfortable a trans or LGBTQ+ student would be in her class. She also would call students out if they were covered by the ADA for extra time and make them come in front of the class to talk to her where everyone could view the ADA student and listen to their conversation (the process is supposed to respect the students privacy). Parking is also bad. On most days, you will have to walk up to half a mile through the parking lot to your classroom. Parking gets filled up VERY quickly. You have to be extremely early to get a decent spot. This is especially bad during the winter months. They have a parking garage, but it is expensive to get a pass and it shouldn't be needed. Many of the students are fresh out of high school. Many students do not wish to take college courses, but take them due to family expectations. This leads to some bad learning situations. Students will be on their phones, talking, or interrupting the teacher. The overall student populations vibe is not one that values or is serious about education. The college police is very unhelpful and in most cases inconsiderate to the students. The administration follows this trend as well. Academic advising meetings are short, and if you are a student with ADA or other situations happening within the school, you will have to work very hard to get your needs met. This is because the departments do not communicate with each other very well at all. I am glad I transferred. I could not imagine another year at this community college.

review.author: Marc C.
review.description:
This speaks to my experience. While I've read things that may be problematic and require correction, they didn't shape my student experience.

Administration: Passable. Generally I could get the things done in one or two visits. There is a marked lack of communication and system integration between related departments, such as financial aid and the business office. I ran into problems where, even though my request was within policy guidelines, home-grown software limitations caused problems. Student employees usually provided the best service.

Faculty: The permanent staff I encountered were all quite good, some first rate. The adjunct faculty was VERY hit and miss.

Cohort: Most students I encountered were disappointing. There are several who were great stand-outs, but most presented themselves as entitled and lacking awareness. I took one class with a terrible adjunct who's "review" immediately before the exams included ONLY the exam answers, and somehow there was a curve. Students got C's on multiple choice exams that they received the answers to immediately beforehand. This is the level of student you will most commonly encounter. (And this is probably some of our coworkers now.)

Harper is a little expensive for a community college, but it has some great resources, good faculty, and some motivated, sharp students. This is the kind of college where YOU really determine what you get; if you really try, you can get a pretty good jump on your education, but if you slack, you can escape with a C average and not learn anything.

review.author: Victoria E.
review.description: I am a fan of learning, and even though I have a bachelors degree - I will forever see myself as a student.\n\nHarper keeps education fairly cheap, and the grounds spoiled me. I loved so many professors there and I consider a couple lifelong friends.  I highly recommend this educational institution for those that seek knowledge, and are trying to cut college costs down.

review.author: Sara N.
review.description:
The teachers are dedicated and wonderful- particularly the teachers in the psychology and education departments. I have been able to develop close relationships with some of my professors and appreciate their genuine interest in imparting their knowledge onto their students. The quality of faculty is great. There are many professors who teach here who have accomplished great things- one of my teachers worked for NASA and conducted his own research. Several of the professors at Harper also teach at schools like Loyola University, among other well established universities.

My disappointment lies in the students. I am surrounded by kids freshly out of high school who don't care about education and are only taking classes because their parents forced them to. While I try to take notes during class, there are too many students gossiping, texting, tweeting, sleeping, laughing, and talking over the teacher. It's frustrating for me, because I have a career goal and need a degree. Meanwhile, for group projects, I get paired up with students who roll their eyes, refuse to talk, and drop the class. 

Long story short, teachers are fulfilling. Students, not so much.

review.author: Alyssa Ann T.
review.description: Great teachers! All the councilors are not fully informed on transfers, programs, and credits  so definitely do your own college transfer research.

review.author: Jenny J.
review.description: I attended Harper part time for 3\nyears and with the exception of 1,\nI had exceptional teachers. They were always available if I had questions, they were challenging, and they really knew the material. The campus is beautiful and in a very convenient location. I never had any problems with FA or the business office. In fact, attending classes there was so simple, I did 99% of the registration and paperwork online. I would definitely recommend this college to anyone looking around.

review.author: Leanne M.
review.description:
As far as schools go, I've never had a worse experience. And I love school, I swear.  Lifelong education is a thrill for me. Harper College was a headache.

I took the Event Planning Certification Course with a teacher who shall remain nameless (I'm not that cruel).

This teacher 
1. HAD LOW ATTENDANCE: She missed 3 out of 8 of the classes.  For the days she was not there, she had us working in the library in groups. I did not pay to go to the library, I paid to learn, thank you.

2.  GAVE LITTLE EFFORT: She was clueless about the material and wasted as much time as possible in class.  She answered questions rhetorically.  She assigned a massive project which took 20 hours to complete outside of class, and graded it with a check or check plus.   

3. WAS UNORGANIZED: She gave us an outdated syllabus 3 weeks after classes started, and then changed quiz dates on the day of. Students who studied all week had to study again the next week because she hadn't made copies yet of the quiz scheduled that day.

THE WORST PART OF ALL: this did not surprise the school. they barely batted an eyelash.

When I brought this information to the attention of  Russell Mills, the Dean of Continuing Education, he said "You are expecting the caliber of a Professor, while Ms. {No Name } is just an adjunct teacher, and you should not expect so much of her."  Well, the least I expect is for a teacher, regardless of knowledge or expertise, to actually teach us for the 3 hours a week I paid for.  

Now, I cannot speak for their regular Associate Degree courses, but for the Continuing Education school, I can tell you the Dean did not seem alarmed nor upset that his teacher was so unprofessional.

BEWARE. Go somewhere else. For continuing education try COD.

review.author: Brooke J.
review.description:
I'm a graduate student with my bachelors of arts who recently moved to the Harper college area. I decided to go to Harper to fulfill my science and math courses for another bachelors or med school. I had no idea the college was so nice when I applied because I did not go to any of the orientation, but I was very impressed with the college as soon as I pulled up in my car. 

I would like to say the college is new construction and therefore is no annoying blocked off areas of renovations like my old school. The school is very clean there is no graffiti anywhere and the bathrooms are always clean as well. Every hallway and door entrance has a hand sanitizer on the wall. There is a great security team there roaming the halls which makes me feel safe.

I've taken the principles of biology with mrs. Rovani as my professor and she is one of the most caring and knowledgeable instructors I've had in the total of my 5 years of attending school. She will work with you to help you succeed and she tutors for her own class! I would recommend taking any of her classes.

review.author: Mark S.
review.description:
I did a full four years at Harper College!  Yup, Harper High, the University of Southern Palatine, whatever you want to call it, I loved Harper community college.

So what did my four years get me?  Well, in addition to a goofy "Associate of Science" degree, I was able to take a wide and varied assortment of classes with universally good professors for one.  Because Harper focuses on preparing students for transition to a 4-year program, they cover everything in the book!  Friends who started at 4-year schools had the "benefit" of skipping book sections/topics which the professor could be confident would not be needed later in that particular school's curriculum.  Not at Harper- we covered everything, which meant serious learning!  When I finally transferred, I found Harper had taught me as well or better than my non-transfer peers.

The other great part about Harper was the cheap tuition!  Cheap classes meant I could take whatever I wanted, including a bunch of interesting electives/liberal arts classes that I couldn't have fit or afforded at the school I ultimately got my Bachelor's degree from.  Then there was the time where I doubted if Engineering/Science was my calling- going to Harper gave me the cost flexibility to explore and drop classes that would have been expensive at a 4-year school!  

Yeah, going to Harper can be challenging because everyone there's a commuter and it lacks the study-buddy atmosphere.  School based social life is non-existent- it's hard to not end up treating your parents as hotel proprietors if you have friends in the city.  Owning a car is essential.  But really, none of this is Harper's fault, and Harper offers all the academic challenge a person could ask for while offering it at a price that makes taking educational chances less costly.  With reasonably hard work I was accepted to transition into the engineering undergrad program I wanted (IIT) and never had any regret about going to Harper.

review.author: Maly B.
review.description:
Delta is a great place to go to if your transferring or wanting join a vocational program. It's a lot easier to get into upper division courses than G.E.

Unfortunately with budget cuts the selection of classes is limited in certain departments or only offered once a year. Be sure to take advantage of the computer labs, writing center, math/science center, and tutors. They actually know what they're talking about and explain things pretty well.

Personally I took time off from school and now ready to transfer have gotten into every class I need easily.

review.author: Sunny Z.
review.description: It's utterly chaotic. I feel like Alice in Wonderland here. You think you have it figured out and then they tell you something completely opposite. You don't receive much help you have to already know your path and classes yourself. The online classes seem to just be about writing papers or comments for everything it's boring. You don't have any interaction with people. I feel bad for anyone who has to go to college online.

review.author: Gabrielle K.
review.description:
Lack of communication availability for those who have limited transportation ability. Now requires on-campus counseling, phone service is unresponsive, school website UI is difficult to navigate including the student portal "My Delta". Even the campus itself is confusing - after consolidating input from more than 4 people including staff as to the location of certain buildings and event locations, even they were not sure or lacked up-to-date information.  

Not sure what is going on with the board but office processes and overall the way everything is run needs to be ironed out in order for students' success, satisfaction, and retention rates to rise and become steady.
 
If I could go back in time I would have chosen Livermore's Las Positas College.

review.author: Chavela L.
review.description: The HVACR and Welding instructors are great. Good luck with administration. If you need help with submitting any kind of petition, you will have to advocate constantly for yourself for anything to get done. I have been going for 4 semesters and never had any problems with the teachers, but the Interim Dean didn't want to do hardly anything because soon it would be someone else's problem. You have to push hard to get your needs met by admin and stand up for yourself or they will bully you. Chat is almost useless as you will be waiting for a response after they say "Hello. How May I help you?" Make sure you save ALL your email interactions so you have proof you have been reaching out to the correct channels and just ignored. And in live chat, click on the three dots in the upper left corner of chat to have a transcription of the chat sent to your email so you have proof you were ignored and then the chat was stopped due to lack of interaction. There aren't many options for community colleges in San Joaquin County, but that is no reason for us to have to deal with admin having a laissez-faire attitude when it comes to our education

review.author: Taylor M.
review.description: Good luck getting in contact with someone if you need assistance. They prefer you to chat online but you literally are waiting 30+ minutes and your number 1 in the queue. Just terrible!

review.author: Laura O.
review.description: i got my tuition free because of fafsa, but it's a headache trying to get any kind of help here. i transferred in 2020 with all the requirements that the counselor had told me i needed for an associate's but then last minute my account said i was deficient in credits and no one could tell me why since i passed every class. i never got my associates and i can never get a hold of anyone in 2 years who can give me a straight answer. an associate's isn't much and im done with my bachelors after transferring now so im not trippin but if it was actually something i needed it would be very inconvenient. the place honestly looks like it needs a lot of work and more professors who actually care about the students.

review.author: Jana T.
review.description:
Just to be clear; I completed and received my certificate of completion for the LVN; Licensed Vocational Nurse program in 2004 from Delta College. 

Not sure what has taken me so long to write a review; life I suspect. 

The LVN program was an amazing experience and it was a full-time program for one year. It was not easy but I learned so much and it turned my mind into more of a critical thinker not to be confused with being a critic.  Critical thinking is a skill set that can assist a person in making well-thought-out decisions and plans. 

I had Patricia Noma, RN MSN and I believe she has additional credentialling behind her name and she was strict and a fantastically effective instructor. My clinical's were at San Joaquin General Hospital in French Camp, California and the OB and Obstetrics portion of the schooling was at St. Joseph's hospital; I made the right choice for me in choosing San Joaquin General Hospital as it was a teaching facility and I learned so much about the disease process and nursing. 

There was another instructor and due to how many years have passed since I graduated in 2004 my memory is only remembering her first name of Nenita. She was amazing as well and taught the majority of our classroom education. Tough, funny, and smart as a whip!

I met one of my friends there and we went through the course together and she went on to get her RN and works as an OB nurse now and loves her career. 

One area I was heartbroken over and so in disbelief about was how SJDC at the time and for years later forced students to repeat courses (if you wanted to be eligible to apply for programs) due to time frames from when the course was taken to when they were applying for programs such as LVN to RN. What a gimmick and how unfair. MJC does not do this.

I switched to Modesto Junior College, MJC, and have had the best experience to date. They have an amazing Disability Services department where if you qualify can be assigned a DSPS (disability services) counselor who works with you to create the most amazing Educational Plans so you know your on the correct track. 

Also in this department, are accommodations for those with qualifying disabilities where you can receive extra testing time and other accommodations that for me have assisted me greatly in achieving passing grades each semester. I am now an English major.

I had my heart set on transitioning from LVN to RN at Delta College however their continual changing of their programs, prerequisite courses and forcing you to retake courses you originally passed to meet some new guideline wasted years of my life, but made them hundreds of thousands of dollars if not more, as they continued to change requirements; year after year. I would speak with people who endured the same type of unethical actions so I knew I wasn't alone. Modesto Junior College accepted my coursework from SJDC and has not once informed me I needed to retake courses due to the age of the course. This is how it should be as its ethical and reasonable. 

I hope for you a better outcome.

review.author: Anmarie F.
review.description: Good luck ever getting a hold of someone. THEY SUCK!!! I've graduated (during covid) and never got my associate degrees in the mail !!! & can't get a hold of anyone + no one gets back to you...

review.author: Amy W.
review.description: I went to their campus last year with my husband for a conference on nursing careers they held, the conference was great but, that campus is not very ADA accessible, they have an elevator which was tiny but if your in a walker or wheelchair, your lucky to fit in it, there is barely room to turn let alone allow more than 2 people in it, the classrooms were by far worse, I have mobility issues and the classrooms were small and I was having a hard time getting into the classrooms with just a walker mobility device, I imagine wheelchairs are nearly impossible, I felt so uncomfortable during that conference because my walker was taking up so much room in the aisle because nobody could get by, that I opted instead to wait outside in the cold on a bench for my husband who was attending the conference lectures. This school is far from accessible! Second, my husband has been attending this school for 3 semesters, and this semester we had to pay out of pocket because during his first semester his GPA was not so great, his second semester was better but, He tried for 3 months prior to his 3rd semester to get help or any information about his PELL Grant because we are a low income family and we rely on his pell grant to get him through school, low and behold after months of no replies to phone calls, emails, and portal messages, he finally got a hold of someone through the chat portal only to find out he was disqualified for his PELL Grant because of his first semester GPA, So, he appealed it, and we have called, emailed, messaged, trying to get some sort of help so he can get information on what's going on with his appeal, and its been almost 4 months.....4 MONTHS....nobody is returning our messages, our emails, let alone phone calls!! They took the money to pay for his tuition well enough, their good at that....but helping their students when it comes to financial aid.....seems to not exist at all. His semester is almost over and he has not had ANY help from the financial aid department or the school for that matter because nobody ever picks up the phone because.....nobody is there! They left their students to just ponder and sit and wonder as to their educational future!! They dont care at all it seems like and I am truly disappointed at how they are handling the welfare of their students during this pandemic,service or help for their students was not that great before the pandemic, but since the pandemic, everyone but the teachers have disappeared into the veil of shadows never to be seen or heard from again!! I give credit to the teachers who have graciously and patiently dealt with all the students who are coming to them for answers and have kindly and patiently tried to do what they can to answer questions and help, they are to be commended, but this school as far as their handling of their students, their financial department and the handling of answering phones or helping anyones concerns, has been disappointing to say the least, and thats putting it nicely. They have fallen greatly from the once great school they used to be, I truly hope they get their stuff together and make this right for their students!! Truly shameful.

review.author: Be N.
review.description: SUSD Specialty School Fair today at Danner Hall. Took all five kids. They were so excited to see some of their teachers and Administrators. Introduce them so some Principals, Director and Asst. Sup. HCA and Commodore booths we're their favorite. #SUSDPROUD.

review.author: Vanessa B.
review.description: I had turned in my fafsa information over a month ago now and still haven't received anything. It says it has not even been reviewed. I couldn't start this semester because I didn't have money so I'm just going to plan b and going to a different school. Thanks a lot financial aid office.

review.author: Jacob N.
review.description:
I always hear excuses from the staff that usually are along the lines of, "We have a lot of students and it is hard for us to get to help them as fast as they would like." This is such a terrible excuse when I attended a college, that at that time had over 10,000 more students in attendance, that was able to meet the needs of the students at such rapid rates. I also attended another college is a rural area that had 1/4 the student and much less than 1/10 the administrative staff that met every need with such expedience. The staff at Delta do not seem to be aware of what is going on with the office next to them, or what is going to happen the next day even. Getting an answer out of the staff is next to impossible, and when you do it sounds like a recorded response and when you rephrase the question you still get the same verbatim answer.

This does not mean that the professors at Delta are all too horrible, in fact they are mostly all quite fantastic. I do not think that there are but a few professors that are a bit off and not quite fit to teach. One professor was asking his students to solicit child pornography and touch people uncomfortably on the shoulder to gauge their response. This did however go unheard by his dean, until a few of us students presented this info to him. We were told by the dean's office, "We do not know what our professors are doing, it is not our job to keep them in line. It is the job of the student to report to us when something is not right with the classroom or professor." That seems pretty terrible to me.

Another quarrel I have with the school is the crowding in the classroom. TAKE THIS NOT AS AN EXAGGERATION! There are classrooms that are so incredibly cramped that there is less than 6 inches to walk down isles, so you have to fill up the back row by moving desks then fill to the front. What would happen in a fire, and with only one exit as well? Not up to CA fire codes. Most of the older classrooms have less than 24inches between desks which makes it impossible to get down an aisle without bumping into every student along the way.

I was in a classroom that had 64 desks and 3 chairs for students while the Max Occupancy of the class (which was posted) was 48 seated. This school is in serious need of budgeting and the Trustee Board needs a pay cut; if the school is hurting so hard for money, then ask the trustees to take a cut in pay. That would mean they would not be able to buy the new year of the Mercedes SLK 600, but hey, we all have to sacrifice. 

DO NOT GO HERE IF YOU CAN HELP IT, GO SOMEWHERE ELSE. I APPLIED FOR ANOTHER COLLEGE ALREADY, I SUGGEST YOU YOU DO NOT GO HERE.

review.author: Blong Y.
review.description: Great Community College! Never thought I would come to San Joaquin Delta College but, here I am still at this college learning!! The Automotive Program is Awesome! The instructors are great!! They will always guide you to get better at fixing cars and teach you more about cars!

review.author: Antionette S.
review.description: I am a transfer student from another educational institute that was located here in Stockton, so far i am enjoying educational experience at San joaquin delta college!

review.author: Desiree B.
review.description: SJDC is an awesome school.  There are many professors there that care about their students and help them succeed. In the ADN program, you have to work hard and do whatever it takes to become a nurse.  It's life learning and growth experiences. If you have negative comments about instructors, welcome to the real world.  I recently achieved my goal to be an RN.  Delta has a great reputation for spitting out the best nurses.  Because of this school, I am successful.  And my instructors want "us" to succeed.  Wish me luck!!!

review.author: Makenzie M.
review.description: Not sure why Delta has so many bad reviews.... I always have gotten the classes I needed & was able to transfer to a CSU in 2 years. Teachers have been great for the most part, and the staff have always been welcoming and helpful.  Really enjoyed my time here at Delta College

review.author: Paul M.
review.description: Great campus, friendly people. Easy to get around though it's pretty large. Very fun and active environment, with little disturbance.

review.author: Neianne C.
review.description: I have been a student part time to full time since 2010. The professors are awesome however I cannot say the same for the Financial Aid department.  I do not understand how this level of incompetence and disrespect could be acceptable or allowed.  Pass the Buck... "It's being reviewed" and "You need to allow time for processing". We are more than half way through the semester and I have yet to receive my financial aid.  I am writing the Director and the Dean and will forward my concerns to the governing board!

review.author: Arely P.
review.description:
Like every other college, Delta has a cafeteria for access to students. Though the food may not be nutritious, it provides students with some sort of food. 
Danner hall is located at the center of the campus where many students gather there to hangout or study. There are tables set up for students to use while on break between classes. 
The food is usually cold, over priced, and they do not provide a variety. It seems as if the food has been sitting there all day and they don't rotate it out. The environment is very noisy and there is no music to set the mood. 
Overall it is convenient for students to grab a bite to eat. Though, it might be overpriced and I recommend you buy better quality food outside of campus.

review.author: Eric N.
review.description:
Delta College is a shining star in Stockton.  

You think I am joking around with you...

I kid you not.   

In the land of Stockton where so many things seem to go wrong it seems like Delta College has gotten it right over the years. Like many people I know I went here a couple times...once to finish some high school stuff early and then again to start my GE credits for later college. 

The parking can be kind of a hard sell sometimes...especially if you plan on taking classes at peak times like MWF 10:30am...when everyone else and their mom does.  Maybe get a class that starts earlier?  

The financial aid office while always pretty busy was always helpful in my quest to keep my finances down while in school and the guidance department was also very helpful in making sure the classes I was taking would transfer to my chosen institution.  

The school itself is really nicely laid out.  For the huge amount of classrooms they have they still do a nice job on making everything work.  Do yourself a favor and go find your classroom before the first day of class so you know where to go on day one.  

I remember many a day sitting in the quad with my friends waiting for a class in the forum to start or just hanging out by the Koi pond studying or every once in a long while studying in the actual library!  

Delta is a Community College...not a place to get a BA or BS...its a place where you get your AA and be done or get your early credits done and then go somewhere else.  If you do one of those two things you will be happy and done. 

Sure there could be small improvements but you could say that about any institution in any city.  Delta does a great job of meeting the needs of the community surrounding it, Stockton.

:0)

review.author: Jazmyn V.
review.description: If you are looking to get your CNA license do it here! Erica is the best instructor and gives you all the help and practice you'll need. The program is fast and worth it. I recommend it 10000000/10. You definitely get your money's worth so sign up when you can! Thank you Bradford!!

review.author: Bret S.
review.description: Mike and Edwin are growing one hell of school for Emts!
